question: Does a barium meal X-ray hurt?
answer: A barium meal X-ray doesn’t hurt. The barium milkshake is chalky and can taste a bit funny though so sometimes it’s flavoured.

question: Will a blood test hurt?
answer: A blood test can feel a bit scratchy and pinch a little bit but it’s over in seconds. Ask the person taking the blood if you can have some cream or cold spray to stop you from feeling it.

question: Does a bone marrow transplant hurt?
answer: A bone marrow transplant doesn’t hurt. It’s a bit like having a blood transfusion.

question: What is a bowel movement?
answer: A bowel movement is another way of saying that you’re going for a poo.

question: Does a brain tumour hurt?
answer: A brain tumour can sometimes give you headaches or make you have seizures or fits. They can make you feel sick or weak too.

question: What is a call handler?
answer: A call handler takes phone calls from people when there’s an emergency and makes sure the ambulance gets to them as quickly as possible.

question: What is a calorie?
answer: A calorie is a way of measuring the energy in food and drink.

question: What is a cardiographer?
answer: A cardiographer is someone who uses special equipment to find out how your heart is working.

question: What is a cardiothoracic surgeon?
answer: A cardiothoracic surgeon does operations on people’s hearts or lungs.

question: What is a catering manager?
answer: A catering manager makes sure there’s lots of healthy, delicious food for everyone at the hospital.

question: What is a catheter?
answer: A catheter is a tube that goes into your body. Things can be put in or taken out of your body using this tube.

question: What is a Central line?
answer: A Central line is a tube that goes into your body so doctors can give you medicines easily.

question: What is a chaplain?
answer: A chaplain is someone that you can talk to about your feelings and what you feel in your heart.

question: What is a children’s nurse?
answer: A children’s nurse is a nurse who looks after children of course!

question: How old are the other kids?
answer: A children’s hospital looks after people from when they are babies to 16 years old, so the children you meet will be all different ages. Nurses try to keep children of the same age in the same rooms together.

question: What is a clerk?
answer: A clerk does all the important office work at a hospital.

question: What is a clinical geneticist?
answer: A clinical geneticist helps people who have illnesses that run in the family.

question: What is a clinical neuropsychologist?
answer: A clinical neuropsychologist helps people who have a problem with their brain.

question: What do clinical nurse specialists do?
answer: A clinical nurse specialist is a nurse who is an expert in something.

question: What is a clinical pharmacologist?
answer: A clinical pharmacologist is a doctor that is an expert in how medicine works.

question: What is a clinical psychologist?
answer: A clinical psychologist is someone who talks to you about your feelings.

question: What is a clinical radiologist?
answer: A clinical radiologist uses X-ray pictures of the inside your body to work out how to look after you.

question: What is a consultant?
answer: A consultant is a doctor who is an expert in one particular type of medicine.

question: What is a cook?
answer: A cook makes food in the hospital - yum yum in my tum!

question: What is a counselling psychologist?
answer: A counselling psychologist helps people understand their feelings.

question: What is a counsellor?
answer: A counsellor is someone who helps people talk about their feelings.

question: Does a CRP blood test hurt?
answer: A CRP blood test doesn’t really hurt. You might feel a sharp scratch and a pinch when the needle goes in but it’s very quick.

question: What is a dental hygienist?
answer: A dental hygienist shows you the best way to look after your teeth. Smile!

question: What is a dental nurse?
answer: A dental nurse helps out a dentist.

question: What is a dental support worker?
answer: A dental support worker helps dentists to look after you.

question: What is a dental technician?
answer: A dental technician makes false teeth.

question: What is a dentist?
answer: A dentist looks after your teeth. Smile!

question: What is a dermatologist?
answer: A dermatologist helps people with skin problems.

question: What is a diabetologist?
answer: A diabetologist looks after people who have problems with glands.

question: What is a diagnostic radiographer?
answer: A diagnostic radiographer uses all sorts of scans like X-rays and MRIs to work out what’s causing your illness.

question: What is a dietetic assistant?
answer: A dietetic assistant helps you understand what the best things to eat are to keep you healthy.

question: What is a dietitian?
answer: A dietitian helps you pick the right kind of food to eat to stay healthy.

question: What is a dramatherapist?
answer: A dramatherapist helps you understand your feelings by acting and if you’re lucky they’ll bring masks, puppets or other cool things!

question: What is a femur?
answer: A femur is a bone in the top part of your leg. It’s in the thigh and it’s the longest bone in your body.

question: What does a Fentanyl Lozenge taste like?
answer: A Fentanyl Lozenge is raspberry flavour, like a lollipop. Yum!

question: How does the Fentanyl Lozenge work?
answer: A Fentanyl Lozenge just disolves on your tongue while you’re sucking it.

question: What is a Fentanyl Lozenge?
answer: A Fentanyl Lozenge looks a bit like a lollipop and contains medicine. It usually raspberry flavour! Yum.

question: Does a finger prick hurt in a blood test?
answer: A finger prick feels a bit scratchy and pinches a little bit but it’s over in seconds.

question: What is a fungal infection?
answer: A fungal infection is a type of bug that comes from mould or yeast.

question: What is a gastroenterologist?
answer: A gastroenterologist is a doctor who helps you if you have problems with your tummy or liver.

question: What is a general anaesthetic?
answer: A general anaesthetic is when doctors give you medicine to make you sleep while you have an operation so you can’t feel anything.

question: What is a general practice nurse?
answer: A general practice nurse is a nurse who works at your doctor’s surgery instead of at a hospital.

question: What is a genome?
answer: A genome is like the instruction book for how living creatures are made and live. It is made up of tiny things called chromosomes which are in your cells, and in turn are made from a thing called DNA.

question: Does a GFR test hurt?
answer: A GFR test is a blood test and it doesn’t really hurt. You might feel a sharp scratch and a pinch when the needle goes in but it’s very quick.

question: What is a gynaecologist?
answer: A gynaecologist is a doctor that is only for women and girls.

question: What is a haematologist?
answer: A haematologist looks after people who have problems with their blood or bone marrow.

question: What is a healthcare assistant?
answer: A healthcare assistant helps doctors and nurses look after you.

question: What is a healthcare science assistant?
answer: A healthcare science assistant helps scientists at the hospital do their job.

question: What is a healthcare science associate?
answer: A healthcare science associate helps scientists at the hospital do their job.

question: What is a Hickman line?
answer: A Hickman line is a long thin tube that is inserted into a big vein so doctors can give you medicines easily.

question: What is a histopathologist?
answer: A histopathologist is a doctor that studies diseases.

question: What is a learning disability nurse?
answer: A learning disability nurse helps people who have a learning disability.

question: What is a lesion?
answer: A lesion is a change in your body which is caused by either an illness or an injury. There are lots of different types of lesion and your doctor will be able to explain it to you.

question: Does an LFT hurt?
answer: A liver function test or LFT is a blood test and it doesn’t really hurt. You might feel a sharp scratch and a pinch when the needle goes in but it’s very quick.

question: What is a local anaesthetic?
answer: A local anaesthetic is a type of medicine used to stop you feeling anything in one particular part of your body. You might have one if you’re having a very small operation where you don’t need to be asleep.

question: Why is a cannula called a long line?
answer: A long line is a special type of cannula that goes into your vein but is a lot longer than a normal one.

question: Are the beds comfy in hospital?
answer: A lot of children and young people have said the hospital beds are comfy. You’ll have to decide when you lie on it!

question: Does a lumbar puncture hurt?
answer: A lumbar puncture can be a bit awkward and uncomfortable so the doctors will give you some medicine to make you sleepy then they will put some special cream on your back so you don’t feel anything happening. It might be a bit uncomfortable afterwards but you can have some medicine to help stop it.

question: What is Macmillan Coffee morning?
answer: A Macmillan coffee morning is a charity event where people get together to drink coffee or tea and eat cake while they raise money for the Macmillan cancer charity.

question: What is a Macmillan nurse?
answer: A Macmillan nurse is a nurse who is an expert at helping people with cancer.

question: What does a matron do?
answer: A matron is a nurse who looks after all the wards, like the big boss of nurses!

question: What is a medical oncologist?
answer: A medical oncologist is a doctor that looks after someone with cancer.

question: What is a medical ophthalmologist?
answer: A medical ophthalmologist looks after you if you have a problem with your eyes.

question: What is a medical psychotherapist?
answer: A medical psychotherapist helps you understand your feelings by talking about them.

question: What is a medical secretary?
answer: A medical secretary does office work at hospitals.

question: What is a mental health nurse?
answer: A mental health nurse is a nurse who helps you understand feelings.

question: What is a morphine infusion?
answer: A morphine infusion is a strong medicine which helps reduce pain.

question: What is a music therapist?
answer: A music therapist can help you understand your feelings using music - pretty great hey?

question: What is a nasogastric tube?
answer: A nasogastric tube is a thin tube which goes in your nose then into your tummy and helps you take in food and medicine.

question: Does a neoplasm hurt?
answer: A neoplasm doesn’t usually hurt. If they grow big enough they can sometimes push on another part of your body like a bone and that can be uncomfortable.

question: How do I go to the toilet if I can’t get out of bed?
answer: A nurse will be able to explain what to do if you need the toilet and can’t get out of bed. You might have a thing called a urinary catheter which is a tube to help you wee, which the nurse will show you.

question: Who brings my medicine?
answer: A nurse will bring you your medicine. They will check a few things before giving it to you to make sure they are the right ones for you and that you are not allergic to them. Often they will have a second person helping them check and give out medicine.

question: What is a paediatric oncologist?
answer: A paediatric oncologist is a doctor who looks after children with cancer.

question: What is a paediatric surgeon?
answer: A paediatric surgeon is a doctor that looks after children and babies.

question: What is a paediatrician?
answer: A paediatrician is a doctor that looks after children and young people.

question: What is a pathologist?
answer: A pathologist is a doctor who does experiments to work out what causes diseases and what they do.

question: What is a patient transport service driver?
answer: A patient transport service driver drives you to and from hospital and looks after you in an ambulance.

question: What is PEG?
answer: A PEG is a tube which goes into your tummy to help feed you.

question: What is a personal assistant?
answer: A personal assistant helps hospital bosses with their office work.

question: What does a pharmacist do?
answer: A pharmacist makes medicines and sorts out tablets for people.

question: What is a physiotherapist?
answer: A physiotherapist helps you get better after an operation by using exercises.

question: What is a podiatrist?
answer: A podiatrist is someone who looks after your feet. Ew smelly! Ha ha ha!

question: What is a portacath?
answer: A portacath is a very small container that goes under your skin, it has a tube attached to it and doctors use it to give you medicine.

question: How will I get to my operation?
answer: A porter will wheel you to your operation on a bed or in a wheelchair.

question: What is a prophylactic?
answer: A prophylactic is a type of medicine that stops an illness from starting.

question: What is a prosthesis?
answer: A prosthesis is another name for an artifical body part, like a false arm or knee.

question: What is a prosthetic?
answer: A prosthetic is another name for an artifical body part, like a false arm or knee.

question: What is a prosthetist?
answer: A prosthetist helps people with false arms or legs.

question: What is a psychotherapist?
answer: A psychotherapist looks after people who are upset or sad.

question: What is the difference between a radiologist and a radiographer?
answer: A radiographer is a person who does scans of you like an X-ray, MRI or CT, and a radiologist is the person that works out what the scans mean.

question: What is a radiographer?
answer: A radiographer is someone who does scans of you such as X-ray, MRI or CT scans.

question: What is a radiography assistant?
answer: A radiography assistant helps out when you’re having an X-ray or radiotherapy.

question: What is a relapse?
answer: A relapse is when a disease comes back again after it’s gone away.

question: What is a resection?
answer: A resection is an operation to remove something from the body.

question: What is a respiratory medicine doctor?
answer: A respiratory medicine doctor takes care of people who have problems breathing and with their lungs.

question: What is a rheumatologist?
answer: A rheumatologist is a doctor who helps you with problems in your skeleton and muscles.

question: What does a senior sister do?
answer: A senior sister is the most senior nurse on each ward.

question: What is a social worker?
answer: A social worker is someone who helps you and your family with things besides your medical treatment.

question: What is a speech and language therapist?
answer: A speech and language therapist helps you if you have trouble talking, eating, drinking or swallowing.

question: What is a speech and language therapy assistant?
answer: A speech and language therapy assistant helps out the speech and language therapist.

question: What is a sport and exercise medicine consultant?
answer: A sport and exercise medicine consultant helps make you better with sports and exercise.

question: What is a surgeon?
answer: A surgeon is a doctor who does operations.

question: What is a switchboard operator?
answer: A switchboard operator answers the phones when someone calls.

question: What is a T Cell?
answer: A T Cell is a special white blood cell which helps to keep you well by fighting off infections.

question: What is a T&O surgeon?
answer: A T&O surgeon treats people who have problems in their bones and joints. T&O stands for Trauma and Orthopaedic.

question: What is a theatre nurse?
answer: A theatre nurse is a nurse who helps out with operations.

question: What is a theatre support worker?
answer: A theatre support worker helps out in the operating theatre.

question: Why do I have to do the thumb prick?
answer: A thumb prick lets the doctors know what is going on inside your body. Some children have this test before or after they have medicine so the doctor knows how it is working.

question: What is a trauma and orthopaedic surgeon?
answer: A trauma and orthopaedic surgeon helps people who have problems in their bones and joints. It’s sometimes shortened to T&O.

question: Will a tutor help me carry on with my school work?
answer: A tutor is a teacher that comes to your home. They’ll help you carry on with your school work and will understand how you are feeling so they won’t make you do more than you can manage.

question: What is a typist?
answer: A typist writes letters and other documents.

question: What is a urinary catheter?
answer: A urinary catheter is a tube that goes inside your body to help you wee.

question: What is a urological surgeon?
answer: A urological surgeon is a doctor who helps you with kidney and bladder problems.

question: What is a urologist?
answer: A urologist is a doctor who helps you with kidney and bladder problems.

question: Does a U & E test hurt?
answer: A U & E test is a blood test and it doesn’t really hurt. You might feel a sharp scratch and a pinch when the needle goes in but it’s very quick.

question: What is a vascular surgeon?
answer: A vascular surgeon is a doctor who helps you with problems in your arteries and veins.

question: What is a Venflon?
answer: A Venflon is a small flexible tube that goes into your vein and is used to give you medicine. It is a type of cannula.

question: What does a ward clerk do?
answer: A ward clerk helps you and your family find out about the ward and where to find things.

question: What is a Wiggly?
answer: A Wiggly is another name for a Central line and that’s a tube that goes into your chest to help give you medicine.

question: What is an abdomen?
answer: Abdomen is another name for your tummy.

question: What is Actinomycin D?
answer: Actinomycin D is a medicine used to treat people with cancer.

question: Will I have a scar?
answer: After an operation you’ll have a red line which might be a bit lumpy. Eventually this will fade though you might have a scar which doesn’t go away completely.

question: What happens after surgery?
answer: After surgery you’ll need loads of rest because you’ll be very tired. The team at the hospital look after you really well - they’re great!

question: Will I get a blood test reward?
answer: After you have had your blood test you will be given a sticker. If they forget and you would like one then just ask!

question: Can I see the X-ray?
answer: After you have had your X-ray, and you go to see your doctor, you can ask them if they will show you your X-ray on their computer.

question: Will it bleed too much in my blood test?
answer: After your blood test, the place where the needle has gone in may bleed a little bit but this will stop really quickly. The person who takes your blood will ask you to press on it with a cotton ball to stop it.

question: What can I eat after my operation?
answer: After your operation you will be asked to have a drink before you can have something to eat to check it doesn’t make you feel sick. If you can drink without feeling sick you will be offered some food. This is usually something small like a sandwich or toast.

question: Will someone tell me what to do after my operation?
answer: After your operation you will be looked after by nurses who will let you know what you can and can’t do after your operation. If there is anything that doesn’t make sense or you don’t understand then just ask.

question: Where will I wake up after my operation?
answer: After your operation you will be taken to an area called recovery which is where you wake up. There may be other children there waking up from their operations too.

question: What happens after my treatment?
answer: After your treatment has finished you’ll still need to see a doctor every now and again to make sure everything is okay and the cancer is staying away.

question: Where do blood cells come from?
answer: All blood cells come from a special type of cell in your bone marrow called a stem cell.

question: Are the doctors and nurses nice? Are the staff nice?
answer: All of the staff in the hospital are nice and try their best to make you feel safe and relaxed.

question: Are the doctors nice?
answer: All of the staff in the hospital are nice and try their best to make you feel safe and relaxed.

question: Are the nurses nice?
answer: All of the staff in the hospital are nice and try their best to make you feel safe and relaxed.

question: Does alopecia hurt?
answer: Alopecia doesn’t really hurt but your head might feel a bit tender if your hair is falling out because of chemotherapy. It’s a bit strange but remember, it will grow back again after you’ve finished your chemo.

question: What is alopecia?
answer: Alopecia is when you lose your hair. Sometimes this happens when you’ve had chemo but don’t worry, your hair grows back when the chemo stops.

question: What does amputation mean?
answer: Amputation is when part of an arm or leg which isn’t working properly any more is taken away.

question: What is an allergist?
answer: An allergist is a doctor that helps you if you react badly to something you’ve eaten or drunk .

question: What is an anaesthetic?
answer: An anaesthetic is a type of medicine that numbs you so you can’t feel anything while you’re having tests or an operation.

question: What is an anaesthetist?
answer: An anaesthetist gives you medicine to make you sleep when you’re having an operation.

question: What is an antigen?
answer: An antigen is something that makes your body start fighting against infection.

question: What is an art therapist?
answer: An art therapist is someone who helps you understand your feelings by drawing and painting. Sounds fun hey?

question: What is an assistant clinical psychologist?
answer: An assistant clinical psychologist helps people understand their feelings.

question: What is an assistant practitioner?
answer: An assistant practitioner helps out nurses and doctors in the hospital.

question: Does an audiogram hurt?
answer: An audiogram doesn’t hurt. There might be a bit of poking about in your ears but that’s it.

question: What is an autograft?
answer: An autograft is when a doctor uses a healthy part of someone’s body to replace an unhealthy part.

question: What is an ear, nose and throat surgeon?
answer: An ear, nose and throat surgeon looks after people who have problems with their ears, nose or throat as well as their head and neck.

question: Does an ECG hurt?
answer: An ECG doesn’t hurt. The sensors they stick to your chest when they do it feel a bit like a plaster being removed afterwards but that’s it.

question: What is an ECG?
answer: An ECG is a test to see how well your heart is working. A doctor puts sensors on your chest so they can detect your heart beat.

question: What is an echocardiogram?
answer: An echocardiogram is a test to see how well your heart is working. The doctor will roll a small sensor across your chest and a video of your heart will show on the screen.

question: What is a endocrinologist?
answer: An endocrinologist looks after people who have problems with glands.

question: What is an ENT surgeon?
answer: An ENT surgeon looks after people who have problems with their ears, nose or throat as well as their head and neck.

question: Does an epidural hurt?
answer: An epidural doesn’t hurt because the area on your back that you are given it is numbed before so you don’t feel it. When you’ve had it you might feel a bit sick or itchy because it has something called morphine in it. There is medicine to help stop this though.

question: What is an epidural?
answer: An epidural is a lilttle tube that goes into your back and is used to give you medicine after an operation.

question: Does an FBC test hurt?
answer: An FBC test is a blood test and it doesn’t really hurt. You might feel a sharp scratch and a pinch when the needle goes in but it’s very quick.

question: What is an immunologist?
answer: An immunologist is a doctor who is an expert in how your body fights off infections.

question: What does infection mean?
answer: An infection is when germs or viruses that shouldn’t be there get into your body and make you poorly.

question: What is an infectious diseases doctor?
answer: An infectious diseases doctor looks after people who have an illness caused by a virus or germs.

question: What is an intensive care doctor?
answer: An intensive care doctor looks after extremely poorly people.

question: Does an investigation hurt?
answer: An investigation is when doctors do some tests to work out why you are poorly. The tests don’t hurt but you might feel some scratches and pinching when you’re having blood tests.

question: What is a MDT?
answer: An MDT is a group of doctors and nurses who all do different things and work together to help make you better. It stands for Multi-Disciplinary Team.

question: What is an occupational therapist?
answer: An occupational therapist helps you get used to doing everyday things again after you’ve been poorly.

question: What is an oncologist?
answer: An oncologist is a type of doctor that looks after people with cancer.

question: What is an operating theatre?
answer: An operating theatre is where operations happen in a hospital.

question: What is an oral and maxillofacial surgeon?
answer: An oral and maxillofacial surgeon is a doctor who looks after your mouth, face and neck.

question: What is an orthopaedic practitioner?
answer: An orthopaedic practitioner is the person that puts a plaster cast on someone when they break their arm or leg.

question: What is an orthopaedic surgeon?
answer: An orthopaedic surgeon is a doctor who does operations on people’s bones and joints.

question: What is an osteoclast?
answer: An osteoclast is a type of cell which breaks down bits of bone your body doesn’t need any more when your body is growing.

question: What is an osteopath?
answer: An osteopath will help you get better by using movement and exercises.

question: What is an osteoblast?
answer: An osteoblast is a type of cell which makes bones grow.

question: What is an otolaryngologist?
answer: An otolaryngologist is a type of doctor who looks after people’s ears, nose and throat.

question: What is an otorhinolaryngologist?
answer: An otorhinolaryngologist is a type of doctor who looks after people’s ears, nose and throat.

question: What does outcome mean?
answer: An outcome just means how a disease affects someone.

question: How will the X-ray feel?
answer: An X-ray doesn’t actually feel like anything, it is just like getting a photograph or a selfie taken but with a special machine that can see inside you.

question: Does anaemia hurt?
answer: Anaemia doesn’t hurt but it might make you feel tired.

question: What is anaemia?
answer: Anaemia is when you have lower numbers of red blood cells than usual and it can make you feel tired and look a bit pale.

question: How will the anaesthetic make me feel?
answer: Anaesthetics make everyone feel differently. Some children feel sleepy when they wake up and some can feel refreshed. However you feel is okay and normal.

question: What is an analgesic?
answer: Analgesic is a name that doctors and nurses use for medicines which stop you from feeling pain or hurting.

question: What are antiemetics?
answer: Antiemetics are a type of medicine to stop you from feeling sick.

question: Do antiemetics hurt?
answer: Antiemetics don’t hurt, they are a medicine to stop you from feeling sick.

question: Do antibiotics hurt?
answer: Antibiotics don’t hurt, they are a medicine which helps fight infections

question: What are antibodies?
answer: Antibodies are something that your body makes which helps you recognise infections so they can be fixed.

question: Can only humans have an X-ray?
answer: Anything can be x-rayed. People and animals have X-rays to see what things look like or to work out what is going on inside the body.

question: What is aplastic anaemia?
answer: Aplastic anaemia is when your bone marrow stops making blood cells.

question: When’s dinner time?
answer: Are you hungry already? Ask a nurse, they’ll be able to tell you what time dinner is today.

question: Can I have a snack?
answer: Ask a nurse if you want a snack and they’ll see what they can do.

question: How can I carry on doing homework and school work when I am in hospital for a long time?
answer: Ask someone to talk to your teachers who can help sort out some school work for you. It’s a great idea to do some while you’re away from school, even if it’s just a little bit when you feel up to it. It will stop you falling behind and you can talk to your friends about it too.

question: What is asparaginase?
answer: Asparaginase is a medicine which you have with chemo.

question: What is Christmas like in hospital?
answer: At Christmas there are decorations and Christmas trees around the hospital just like everywhere else. As many children as possible go home for Christmas but for those that need to stay Father Christmas comes to visit and gives everyone a present.

question: Where will I wait before my operation?
answer: Before your operation you’ll be in a big waiting room with a few other children so it can be quite noisy. It can be boring waiting around so it is worth bringing things with you from home to help pass the time.

question: What is behind the desk?
answer: Behind the desk is where the nurses work and it’s called a nurse’s station. They keep all sorts of things there like medicines, information about patients and small pieces of equipment. There’s also a computer there.

question: Should I be calm in hospital?
answer: Being calm can help you feel better when you come into hospital but it is okay if you can’t be calm. Whatever you are feeling when you come into hospital is okay and you can speak to anyone at the hospital about any of your worries.

question: What is it like being in a room with other children?
answer: Being in a room with other children can be nice because you have other people to chat to and play with. It can get a bit noisy at visiting times but this doesn’t last long.

question: What does benign mean?
answer: Benign is when a lump doesn’t contain any cancer and doesn’t spread to other parts of the body.

question: Does a benign tumour hurt?
answer: Benign tumours don’t usually hurt. If it begins to you should tell your doctor straight away.

question: How is blood made?
answer: Blood is made of red and white blood cells, platelets and plasma which all do different things. The blood cells and platelets are made by bone marrow which is the spongey stuff inside bones. The plasma is mostly water which you take in from what you eat and drink then the liver adds some special ingredients called proteins.

question: What is blood made of?
answer: Blood is made of white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets and plasma which is the liquid it’s all held in.

question: What if I need a blood test?
answer: Blood tests are nothing to worry about, a nurse or doctor will take a little bit of your blood so they can work out how best to help you. Your body makes more blood, so you will always have enough.

question: What can I do to make friends with other children on the ward?
answer: Board games, card games and computer games are good for helping you get to know the other children and make friends on your ward. Ask a nurse or a play specialist if they can think of a good place to hang out.

question: What is bone marrow?
answer: Bone marrow is the soft, spongy stuff in the middle of bones, it’s where new blood cells are made.

question: What are bones?
answer: Bones are hard, whiteish things that make up your skeleton. It’s a living part of you that makes your body strong and able to stand up as well as protecting more delicate things like your lungs and brain. Blood cells are also made inside your bones by a thing called bone marrow.

question: What should I bring to the hospital?
answer: Bring some favourite things to the hospital to stop you from getting bored, like toys or games. If you’re staying over bring some PJs and comfortable clothes and don’t forget your toothbrush!

question: What are Cancer Growth Inhibitors?
answer: Cancer Growth Inhibitors are medicines which stop cancer cells from growing properly.

question: What is Cancer Research UK?
answer: Cancer Research UK is a charity which raises money to pay for research into cancer and its treatments.

question: What is a cancer vaccine?
answer: Cancer vaccine is an injection that makes your body fight off cancer.

question: Does a carcinoma hurt?
answer: Carcinoma can be in a few different places. If it’s on your skin you might have a rash or feel itchy. If it’s in another part of your body like your chest or kidney, you might have a lump which can feel a bit sore to the touch.

question: What does CAT scan mean?
answer: CAT stands for Computerized Axial Tomography. It shows up things a normal x-ray doesn’t show.

question: What are cells?
answer: Cells are the building blocks of the body. They are very small and can only be seen under a microscope. All living things are made up of cells, even you!

question: Do you know what chemo is?
answer: Chemo is what they call different medicines which fight cancer.

question: Why does chemotherapy make your tastebuds change?
answer: Chemotherapy attacks cancer cells which grow very quickly. Your tastebud cells also grow very quickly and the chemo affects them too which can make some foods taste different.

question: What is chemo?
answer: Chemotherapy is a type of medicine which is used to treat cancer.

question: What does chemotherapy feel like?
answer: Chemotherapy might make you feel more tired and poorly than usual. Sometimes it can make you feel sick and you might need the toilet more too. You might also lose your hair for a while but it’s all a normal part of making you better.

question: Why does chemotherapy stop fast growing cells?
answer: Chemotherapy stops fast growing cells at the point when they are splitting in two. It does this by either interrupting the chemical process that makes it happen or by damaging the control centre inside the cell itself.

question: Do I have to fast during Ramadan?
answer: Children and poorly people don’t need to fast at Ramadan. Ask your family what they think.

question: How do the beads of courage work and how can I collect them?
answer: Children are given beads of courage to recognise different treatments and stages of their illness. They are a great way of remembering how brave you’ve been and you can show them to people so they can understand better what you have been doing during your treatment.

question: Will I get Easter Eggs in hospital?
answer: Children usually get an Easter Egg at Easter time in the hospital. You’ll have to check with the nurse how much chocolate you can have.

question: Why can’t I have my blood test at my doctors?
answer: Children usually have to come to hospital to have a blood test done as GP surgeries don’t always have people who are specially trained to do it. It is safer to have it done in hospital by someone who is specially trained.

question: What are clinical support staff?
answer: Clinical support staff help doctors and nurses look after you.

question: What does CNS mean?
answer: CNS stands for Central Nervous System which is basically your brain and spinal cord.

question: Is hospital as bad as I think?
answer: Coming to hospital can feel a bit scary but that’s quite normal, it’s not as bad as you think and you’ll quickly get used to coming. You can ask as many questions as you like but if you’re still not sure tell your parents how you’re feeling, they should be able to help.

question: Does a CT scan hurt?
answer: CT scans do not hurt. You’ll have to lie very still while you’re being scanned which can be a bit awkward but it doesn’t hurt.

question: What does CT scan mean?
answer: CT stands for Computed Tomography. It shows up things a normal X-ray doesn’t show.

question: What is curettage?
answer: Curettage is an operation to remove cancerous cells.

question: What is cytomegalovirus?
answer: Cytomegalovirus is a virus that is usually harmless but can cause problems if you’re having a stem cell transplant.

question: What are cytotoxic drugs?
answer: Cytotoxic drugs are medicines that kill cancer.

question: What does cytotoxic mean?
answer: Cytotoxic means that it is toxic to cells. If a medicine is cytotoxic it will kill cells.

question: What is in dairy food?
answer: Dairy foods are things like milk, cheese, butter and yoghurt. They’ve got protein, fats and vitamins in them and are good for you.

question: What is diabetes?
answer: Diabetes is when your body can’t manage sugar in your blood. The body normally creates stuff called insulin which keeps sugar levels at the right amount. If you have diabetes your body either can’t make insulin at all, it can’t make enough of it or the insulin it does make doesn’t work very well.

question: What is the diaphysis?
answer: Diaphysis is the main part of your bone which is sometimes known as the shaft.

question: What is diarrhea?
answer: Diarrhea is when your poo is watery or liquid. If you’re being treated for an illness like cancer it’s important to let your doctor or nurses know if it happens.

question: What is Diclofenac?
answer: Diclofenac is a medicine which stops you feeling pain.

question: What do the different medicines do?
answer: Different medicines do different things. You can ask your nurse, when they are giving you your medicine, what the medicine does and what you are having it for.

question: Can you feel the medicine going into your veins?
answer: Different medicines feel different when they go in to your vein. Some medicines can feel cold, some feel warm, others tingly and some you can’t feel at all. Ask your nurse before they give you the medicine what it will feel like.

question: In my blood test, how do they know what bottles to put the blood?
answer: Different tests have different coloured bottles. The person doing the test knows exactly which one to use because they’re experts and they’ve done it lots of times before.

question: What are the different uniforms?
answer: Different uniforms show the different jobs of the people who work in the hospital.

question: Does a virus hurt?
answer: Different viruses do different things. Some can make you feel tired and achey, some can give you a fever and some can make you feel like you have a cold.

question: What is DNA?
answer: DNA is a chemical that every living thing has and carries information about how it is made. It is shaped like a spiral ladder.

question: What is the thing the doctors listen to my chest with?
answer: Doctors use a thing called a stethoscope to listen to the inside of people’s chests. It’s like a pair of headphones with a round, metal bit attached to it which might be a bit cold when it first touches your skin.

question: What are domestic services staff?
answer: Domestic services staff keep the hospital clean and tidy.

question: How will I be entertained at my blood test? What shall I do if I have nothing with me to do?
answer: Don’t worry about being entertained, there are lots of things to do in the room where they do blood tests. There are toys and books and a TV to watch, you can even bring something from home if you want.

question: Where do the nurses sit when I stay overnight?
answer: During the night time the nurses may sit at the nurse’s station. They will also come in and out of the room you are in to check you and the other patients are okay.

question: How long will my my operation take? How long will I be asleep for?
answer: Each operation takes a different amount of time. Your doctor will let you know how long they think yours will be. Going to sleep before can take about half an hour and waking up after can be another half an hour. If your doctor says your operation will be an hour this means it might take two hours in total.

question: Will I be in a room alone or with other people?
answer: Each ward has different rooms and layouts. Some have areas where patients have their own rooms and some have rooms with up to four children in them. You won’t know whether you will be on your own or with others until after your operation.

question: What will the ward look like?
answer: Each ward looks different. Some have lots of beds in each room and some just have one. Wards are usually quite busy with children and staff.

question: What is engraftment?
answer: Engraftment is when new bone marrow starts growing in your bones.

question: What is epiphysis?
answer: Epiphysis is the part of your bones, at the end, that grows.

question: What if I feel too poorly to eat?
answer: Even if you feel too poorly to eat it’s important to try so you stay healthy. Don’t worry though, you won’t be forced to eat if you really don’t want to.

question: Can I play and do things as normal after my operation?
answer: Eventually you should be able to play and do normal things but you might have to take things easy for a while. Your doctor and nurses will be able to advise you.

question: When can I do sport again?
answer: Every operation is different and each person is different at getting better. Your doctor should let you know when they feel you will be ready to do sports again. If they forget to say it’s okay to ask them.

question: When can I go back to school after my operation?
answer: Every operation is different and each person is different at getting better. Your doctor should let you know when they feel you will be ready to go back to school. If they forget to say it’s okay to ask them.

question: What are the names of the nurses?
answer: Every part of the hospital has different nurses. Everyone that you meet will tell you their name and what their job is.

question: Do you get food when you are in hospital?
answer: Everyone gets food when they are in hospital. You will get to choose your breakfast, lunch and dinner from a menu every day.

question: What is a brain?
answer: Everyone has a brain. It’s inside your head and it is the HQ for your body. Your brain tells your body what to do and is in charge of keeping your at the right temperature, making sure you don’t fall over, breathing, growing and thinking. It’s what tells you you’re hungry, solves problems and even makes you dream.

question: What is a liver?
answer: Everyone has a liver, it’s near your tummy, under your ribcage. It’s a type of organ which cleans your blood, makes a liquid which helps you absorb food, and stores energy as a special sugar called glycogen.

question: Is this a nice place to stay overnight?
answer: Everyone tries to make it as nice as possible to stay over night. You can have extra pillows or blankets if you want and sometimes there are snacks. You can have a parent stay overnight with you too. It can be quite noisy though and sometimes a nurse will check you in the night.

question: Will I wake up fresh after my operation?
answer: Everyone wakes up feeling different after an operation. Some people wake up and feel fresh, others wake up and feel they are really tired and want to go back to sleep. Both of these feelings are normal.

question: Are the people kind when they do their work?
answer: Everyone who works in the hospital does their best to be kind to every patient. They work with children and young people every day and try their best to make them feel as safe and happy as possible.

question: How long does chemo take?
answer: Everyone’s treatment is different and unique to them. The length of time it takes can change as it goes on depending on how well it works so you’ll have to check with your doctor about that.

question: How long does the treatment last?
answer: Everyone’s treatment is different and unique to them. The length of time it takes can change as it goes on depending on how well it works so you’ll have to check with your doctor about that.

question: What time do I have to arrive?
answer: Everything you need to know will be sent in a letter to your parents including what time you should arrive at.

question: Where do I go?
answer: Everything you need to know will be sent in a letter to your parents including where you should go when you arrive.

question: Does external radiation hurt?
answer: External radiation doesn’t hurt when you’re having it done but it can make your skin a bit dry or sore afterwards. The nurses will be able to get you something to soothe it though.

question: Will Father Christmas come?
answer: Father Christmas comes to visit all the children that have to stay in the hospital over Christmas.

question: What is fatigue?
answer: Fatigue is when someone is tired or exhausted. It can be a side effect of many illnesses and also the medicine used to treat them.

question: What is FBC?
answer: FBC is a type of blood test that checks how many cells are in it. FBC means Full Blood Count.

question: What is Febrile Neutropenia?
answer: Febrile Neutropenia is when you don’t have enough white blood cells and you have a fever at the same time.

question: I’m always tired and bored, what can I do?
answer: Feeling tired can be annoying, especially if you love being active! Watching a DVD with family or friends isn’t too tiring. It might sound strange, but getting a bit of exercise can help when you feel tired too.

question: What if there’s a fire?
answer: Fires are extremely rare in hospital but if you hear a fire alarm it’s important to do exactly what the nurses tell you. They are very well trained in what to do and will make sure you are taken out of the hospital to safety.

question: What is GCSF?
answer: GCSF is a type of medicine which helps boost your white blood cells.

question: What is a general practitioner?
answer: General practitioners are also known as GPs and they help people with day-to-day illnesses. They’re usually the first doctor you’ll see when you’re poorly.

question: What is a general psychiatrist?
answer: General psychiatrists help people understand their feelings.

question: What is a general surgeon?
answer: General surgeons do operations on people’s tummies.

question: What are genes?
answer: Genes are the instructions for how to make your body.

question: What is GFR?
answer: GFR is a test to see how well your kidneys are working.

question: What is haemoglobin?
answer: Haemoglobin is the part of your red blood cells which helps to move oxygen around your body.

question: How long will it take for my hair to be shoulder length after my treatment has finished?
answer: Hair grows at different rates for everyone so it’s tricky to say when it will be long again. After chemo it usually takes a few weeks to start growing and is fuzzy at first before your normal hair comes back. After about two months it should be a couple of centimetres long.

question: Will my hair grow back?
answer: Hair usually grows back after chemotherapy though sometimes it can look different than it used to.

question: Will it be a blood test be scary?
answer: Having a blood test might feel a bit scary, especially if you’ve not had one before but you can ask questions and they will explain everything to you so try not to worry. You can also take someone with you when you have the test.

question: Does a feeding tube hurt?
answer: Having a feeding tube put in feels a bit weird and uncomfortable at first but it doesn’t really hurt and you get used to it quickly.

question: Does an IV hurt?
answer: Having an IV means that you’ll have a needle with a tube on it put in your arm or leg. It can feel a bit like being scratched or pinched when the needle first goes in but it’s not too bad and it’s pretty quick. When the needle comes out the tube stays in place and that doesn’t hurt.

question: Is an X-ray like having a selfie?
answer: Having an X-ray is a bit like having a selfie except someone else is taking the picture.

question: Is an X-ray dangerous?
answer: Having an X-ray is not dangerous but it might cause problems if you have loads of them so you will only have them when you really need them.

question: Is an X-ray safe?
answer: Having an X-ray is very safe but it might cause problems if you have loads of them so you will only have them when you really need them.

question: Is it bad having an X-ray?
answer: Having an X-ray isn’t bad, it’s like having a photo or selfie taken just with a special machine that can see inside you.

question: Does having stitches removed hurt?
answer: Having stitches removed is quick and doesn’t hurt. The stich is snipped at the top and pulled out. You might feel a bit of tugging when this happens.

question: What does a health care assistant do?
answer: Health care assistants do all kinds of helpful jobs around the ward.

question: What are health play staff?
answer: Health play staff play with you to help you get better, sounds like fun!

question: What is a health psychologist?
answer: Health psychologists help people deal with how their illness has affected them.

question: What are health records staff?
answer: Health records staff make sure that important information about patients is kept properly.

question: Could you show me a map of the hosptial?
answer: I haven’t got a map of the hospital I’m afraid. Ask a nurse if they have one.

question: What is high dose chemotherapy?
answer: High dose chemotherapy is a very strong medicine that helps beat cancer.

question: Does hormone therapy hurt?
answer: Hormone therapy doesn’t hurt but it can make you feel tired.

question: What are hormones?
answer: Hormones are chemical messengers which your body makes. They affect how your cells work and grow.

question: What is a hormone?
answer: Hormones are chemicals that your body makes. They affect all sorts of things like how you grow or how you feel.

question: Why are there guard rails on my bed?
answer: Hospital beds are higher than normal beds, so the guard rails stop you falling out.

question: Does the bed move?
answer: Hospital beds are really fancy. They’re on wheels so they can be wheeled about, they also move up and down and the back can be tilted.

question: What is the hospital like?
answer: Hospitals are really big buildings with loads of different places all working to make people better when they are poorly. There are places where people go just for tests like X-rays or blood tests and there are places where people sleep when they stay in hospital for longer. There are also other things like the cafe and a shop.

question: Is there a radiator in the ultrasound room?
answer: Hospitals don’t have radiators. They have special heating in the ceiling that blows warm air if it’s a cold day and blows cool air into the room if it’s a warm day.

question: What do housekeepers do?
answer: Housekeepers look after the ward and also help out in the kitchen.

question: How long will it take me to get better?
answer: How long it takes to get better depends on what kind of treatment you have and how well it works for you. Everyone is slightly different you see. Ask your doctor about that one.

question: How long until I get out of hospital?
answer: How long till you get out of hospital depends on what kind of treatment you’re having and how quickly it is working. Ask a doctor or a nurse, they should be able to give you a good idea.

question: How long am I here for my MRI scan?
answer: How long you are at the hopsital for your MRI scan all depends on what part of your body is being scanned and whether you need to be asleep when it happens or not. It could be as quick at 10 minutes or it might be more than an hour. Just ask your doctor or radiographer, they can tell you.

question: How long will I have to wait after surgery?
answer: How long you wait after surgery depends on the operation you have. Your doctor should let you know how long you will have to stay in hospital for when they come to talk to you about your operation.

question: How long will I be in hospital for?
answer: How long you’re in hospital depends on your treatment. Ask a doctor or nurse next time you see them and they should be able to give you an idea.

question: How long do people stay in hospital for?
answer: How long you’re there depends on what you’re in hospital for. For some people it’s just a few hours and some are there a lot longer. Ask your doctor or nurse, they will be able to tell you.

question: How is my treatment going?
answer: How your treatment is going is private between you and your doctor so you’ll have to ask next time you see them.

question: How old is the doctor / nurse?
answer: I don’t know how old they are, you’ll have to ask them.

question: Can I have a party on the ward?
answer: I’m afraid you can’t have a party on the ward because there are lots of poorly children around but if it’s your birthday you can have visitors who can bring you presents and cards!

question: I want to see inside the X-ray machine.
answer: I’m afraid you can’t see inside the X-ray machine because they can’t take it apart, but you can ask to have a look at it before your X-ray.

question: Do you get to take the X-ray picture home?
answer: I’m afraid you can’t take your X-ray home but when you get your results from the doctor you could ask them if you could see the picture on their computer.

question: Can my pets visit me in hospital?
answer: I’m afraid your pets can’t visit you in hospital. Sometimes pets can carry germs and there are lots of poorly children at the hospital who might pick something up.

question: What can I do to feel more confident?
answer: If you’re not feeling very confident at the moment try talking to someone you trust about how you’re feeling. It can really help.

question: Will I still go to school?
answer: If it’s a quick appointment you may be able to go to school before or after it. If you are staying in hospital all day or for a few days then you will miss school. Your doctor or nurse should be able to tell you when you can go back to school.

question: My big brother doesn’t want to talk about my cancer. How can I help him open up?
answer: If they don’t want to talk about your cancer why not suggest that they write their thoughts down? It’s a good idea to tell your parents that you’re worried, so they can try to help them too.

question: My little sister feels left out. What would make her feel better?
answer: If they feel left out maybe you could all do something together, like a trip to the park or a movie evening at home. You could suggest that your parents do something just with them so they feel special too.

question: What room will I have my blood taken in for my blood test?
answer: If you are coming into hospital for a blood test this may happen in a room on the ward or a clinic where you see your doctor. This room is especially for blood tests.

question: What is immuno-compromised?
answer: If you are immuno-compromised it means that your body doesn’t fight off infections properly.

question: What things do I need to bring to hospital?
answer: If you are staying in hospital overnight you could bring some pyjamas, slippers, clean pants or knickers, a flannel or facecloth and a toothbrush and toothpaste. You can also bring some things to keep you entertained like a toy, a book or an iPad.

question: Do you have to bring your own clothes to hospital?
answer: If you are staying in hospital you should bring some of your own clothes with you. When you have your operation you may wear a gown but you will need some clothes to go home in. It’s nice to bring some comfy clothes like pyjamas or tracksuit bottoms.

question: What if I can’t sleep when I’m in hospital?
answer: If you can’t sleep ask a nurse if there’s something they can suggest like counting sheep or slow breathing. Nurses know all sorts of things to help you sleep in hospital.

question: Do I have to stay in hospital for my scan?
answer: If you don’t have to go to sleep for your scan you can usually go home right away. If you do have to be asleep when you’re having a scan then you’ll have to wait at the hospital for a couple of hours after you wake up so the sleeping medicine can wear off properly.

question: How can I stop everyone asking me questions when I go back to school?
answer: If you don’t want everyone asking you loads of questions when you go back to school ask your parents to have a chat with your teacher. They can talk to your class about what’s been happening while you’ve been away. You might even want to talk to the whole class yourself and explain things to them. It’s up to you.

question: I feel sick.
answer: If you feel sick let a nurse know, they might be able to help you.

question: Sometimes foods I usually like taste different and sometimes they make me feel sick. What can I do?
answer: If you feel sick talk to a nurse or a doctor who can give you something to help.

question: Will I feel sick after my operation?
answer: If you feel sick tell a nurse and you’ll be given some medicine to stop it - simple!

question: I sometimes get easily angry with my brother. Is there a way to keep calm?
answer: If you feel yourself getting angry see if you can stop, take some deep breaths, and count to 10 before you say something you may feel unhappy about later. It might be helpful to talk to your family about how you are feeling too.

question: Does a Central line hurt?
answer: If you have a Central line it will be put in while you are asleep so you won’t feel anything. Once it’s in it doesn’t hurt and you won’t really notice it.

question: Does a CVC hurt?
answer: If you have a CVC or Central Venous Catheter it will be put in while you are asleep so you won’t feel anything. Once it’s in it doesn’t hurt and you won’t really notice it.

question: What can I do about a dry mouth?
answer: If you have a dry mouth you could try sipping cool drinks or eating food with sauce or gravy on it. Try and keep away from chewy or sticky food. Ask a nurse if they can think of anything to help too.

question: Does a Hickman line hurt?
answer: If you have a Hickman line put in you will be asleep when it’s done so you won’t feel anything. Once it’s in it doesn’t hurt and you won’t really notice it.

question: Does a Wiggly hurt?
answer: If you have a Wiggly put in you will be asleep when it’s done so you won’t feel anything. Once it’s in it doesn’t hurt and you won’t really notice it.

question: Who should I talk to if I have any questions or problems?
answer: If you have any questions or problems you can talk to your doctor or nurse, they will be able to explain everything. If you don’t want to, then ask your parents to find out.

question: Do they know I am in a wheelchair?
answer: If you have been before they will know you are in a wheelchair. If you have never been before they may not but don’t worry, it’s not a problem.

question: Does a curettage hurt?
answer: If you have curettage you will be given a local anaesthetic which will make you numb so you don’t feel anything. You might feel a bit uncomfortable afterwards but there are medicines to help stop that.

question: What can I do about diarrhea?
answer: If you have diarrhea make sure you let a doctor or a nurse know and be sure to drink lots of liquids till it gets better.

question: Does surgery hurt?
answer: If you have surgery you will be given special medicine to make you sleep so you don’t feel anything. You might feel a bit uncomfortable afterwards but there are medicines to help stop that.

question: How long will it take to fall asleep after the anaesthetic?
answer: If you have the mask and gas it can take you around a minute to fall asleep. If you have the cannula and medicine it only takes around 20 seconds to fall asleep.

question: Why can’t I move my hand when I have a cannula?
answer: If you have to have a cannula put in, the area you have it in can feel a bit stiff. You are okay to move these areas but if it makes you feel better you can keep it still while the cannula is there.

question: Why do I have to do so much school work in hospital?
answer: If you keep up with your school work while you’re in hospital it won’t take as long to catch up when you go back to school. You don’t want to get left behind do you?

question: Can I have the spray before the cannula?
answer: If you need a cannula putting in, it can help to have spray or magic cream before it is done. Just let your nurse or doctor know which one you would like.

question: Why do I have to have a cannula needle?
answer: If you need a drip the nurse will give you a cannula which is a needle with a thin straw over it. They need the needle to get the cannula in but they take it away again leaving the straw behind.

question: What happens if I need an operation?
answer: If you need an operation you’ll be given some medicine to make you sleep while the doctor does it and a team of people will look after you until you wake up again later.

question: How can I get another chair?
answer: If you need another chair just get one of your visitors to ask a member of staff.

question: How can I get a top up / more data on my phone?
answer: If you need more data on your phone you’ll have to ask your parents.

question: When I have a headache, what can I say to my sisters to stop them from being too loud?
answer: If you need someone to be quiet you should just tell them how you feel, you might be surprised by how understanding they are.

question: Do stitches hurt?
answer: If you need stitches during an operation you won’t feel it because you’ll be asleep. If you need stitches at any other time you will be given some cream or gel to numb the area so all you will feel is some tugging as the doctor puts the stitches in.

question: Where can I charge my phone / iPad / tablet?
answer: If you need to charge your electronic device you’ll need to check with a nurse because all charging cables need to be safety tested before you use them in the hospital.

question: In hospital, is there anywhere for brothers or sisters or family to sleep? Where will my mum and dad sleep?
answer: If you need to stay in hospital you can have one person stay with you, this has to be an adult. There will be a pull down bed next to your bed for this person to sleep.

question: What will happen if I need to stay the night at the hospital?
answer: If you need to stay the night at the hospital you might have your own room or you might be in with some other children, but your parents can stay and the rest of your family and friends can visit too.

question: How does PCA work?
answer: If you start to feel uncomfortable just press the PCA button to give yourself some medicine. A nurse will explain how to use it properly.

question: How do I deal with my friends treating me differently?
answer: If you think your friends are treating you differently just try to be yourself. Let people know that you’re still the same old you. Stay in touch with friends, let them know when you’re ready to hang out and do the things you enjoy doing together.

question: How do I call a nurse over?
answer: If you want to call a nurse over and it is not urgent there is a round orange button you can press. If it’s an emergency then pull the red triangle on the wall and a loud alarm will sound.

question: Can I still exercise when I am having treatment?
answer: If you want to exercise during your treatment you should talk to your doctor and nurses first but it should be okay at some point because exercise helps to keep you healthy.

question: How can I explain what is happening to me to my friends?
answer: If you want to explain to your friends what is happening you might be able to ask a nurse or social worker to go to your school and tell them. If you are happy to answer questions then tell them whatever you can. But it’s also okay to say if you don’t want to talk about it.

question: How do I contact my parents?
answer: If you want to get in touch with your parents one of the nurses will be able to help you.

question: How can I let my school friends know what is going on when I am not at school?
answer: If you want to let your school friends know what’s going on while you’re away you could text or phone them. Maybe school can set up a skype call or you could facetime people.

question: Should I look while they take the blood at my blood test?
answer: If you want to look while they do the blood test that is fine, if you don’t want to that is okay too.

question: Can I still ride my bike while I’m having treatment?
answer: If you want to ride your bike you’ll need to check with your doctor that this is okay first and if they say yes then go for it!

question: Can I stay in touch with the other kids on the ward when they’ve gone?
answer: If you want to stay in touch with the friends you make in hospital make sure you get their phone number or address.

question: How can I stay in touch with friends at my sports club?
answer: If you want to stay in touch with your friends you could see if you can go down and watch them play or get in touch with the club and get them to send you news and updates.

question: What can I do not to be bored?
answer: If you’re a bit bored there are toys and games in the waiting room which you can play with and on the ward there will be a play specialist who has lots of fun things for you to do. You can also bring your own things from home if you want.

question: I feel a bit lonely sometimes. What can I do to stay close to my friends?
answer: If you’re feeling lonely it’s important to talk to people about how you feel. Why don’t you ask some friends to visit or you could phone, message or facetime them.

question: What is there to do when I’m not being treated?
answer: If you’re looking for something to do when you’re not being treated the wards have TVs and radios and there’s loads of other things too. You can also bring your own things like a tablet or toys if you want.

question: What can I do to make me feel hungrier?
answer: If you’re not feeling very hungry you could try food that smells really good? Sometimes the smell can make you hungry.

question: What do I do if I’m not hungry?
answer: If you’re not very hungry try just eating a small amount of food every two or three hours instead of three big meals a day. That might help.

question: What will happen when I get to the hospital?
answer: If you’re staying at the hospital the first thing that will happen is you’ll be given a bracelet to wear which has your name on it. That’s so the doctors and nurses know who you are and can keep track of your treatment.

question: Will I have breakfast / lunch / dinner / tea in bed?
answer: If you’re well enough you can go to the ward dining room and you can eat there with the other children or your family.

question: I’ve lost my slippers / toy / water cup, what can I do?
answer: If you’ve lost something and it’s definitely nowhere to be seen the nurses can help you, just ask one of them if they’ve seen it.

question: I’ve put on loads of weight since I started treatment. What might make me feel better about this?
answer: If you’ve put on some weight why don’t you try a bit of exercise? That can help. You could also talk to someone about the best foods to eat to keep you healthy.

question: My chemotherapy treatment makes me feel so tired. What can I do?
answer: If your chemo is making you tired, rest and sleep whenever you can and remember to have some quiet time away from computer games as this can help you sleep better. Sometimes doing a bit of exercise, like going for a walk might help you feel more energetic.

question: My mouth is sore from the chemotherapy, what can I do?
answer: If your mouth is sore from chemo it’s important to keep it nice and clean so make sure you brush your teeth three or four times a day and use a soft toothbrush.

question: Why have my parents gone back to treating me like a little kid since my cancer diagnosis?
answer: If your parents have started treating you like a little kid again just remind them that you’re still you! You could suggest some little things you could do for yourself like making your own breakfast or going to a friends house. They’re just worried about you - try not to get too annoyed by it.

question: Do I have to take my jumper off for my blood test?
answer: If your sleeves of your jumper can roll right up to the top of your arm you may be able to keep it on while you have your blood test. If not you may be asked to take your jumper off. It might be worth wearing a t-shirt or a short sleeved top if you need to have a blood test.

question: What is immunoglobulin?
answer: Immunoglobulin is a thing that sticks to germs in your blood and helps to destroy them.

question: What is immunosuppression?
answer: Immunosuppression is a reduction in your body’s own defence system.

question: What can I do to keep myself busy while they take my blood at my blood test?
answer: In the room where they do the blood test there are some toys, books and a TV which you can watch to keep you busy. You could bring in a tablet or a phone and listen to some music if you like.

question: I haven’t lost my hair and people don’t realise I’m ill. How do I tell my friends I’m not allowed to do things without getting upset?
answer: It can be hard when your friends don’t understand and lots of people expect you to lose your hair when you have cancer even though some people don’t. Why not think of some of the things you can tell them to explain and practise how you’re going to say it with your parents?

question: Will I sleep through the night? Will they wake me up in the night?
answer: It can be tricky to sleep through the night in hospital because it’s quite noisy. Sometimes your nurse might check up on you in the night as well. If it helps you can have an adult stay with you.

question: I’m a bit embarrassed about the scar I have from surgery!
answer: It can take a while to get used to a scar but try not to worry about it. It will fade a lot over time.

question: Does total body irradiation hurt?
answer: It doesn’t hurt and you won’t feel anything during total body irradiation. When you’re getting to the end of your treatment you might feel some dryness on your skin and it might feel warm when you touch it.

question: Does chemotherapy hurt?
answer: It doesn’t hurt when you’re having chemotherapy but you might have some side effects afterwards like feeling sick which isn’t very nice. The doctors and nurses can help with that though so let them know how you’re feeling.

question: Does it matter which arm I have the injection in?
answer: It doesn’t usually matter which arm you have an injection in but sometime they are given in the opposite arm to which you write with so you can still write properly or play games afterwards.

question: Is it normal having an X-ray?
answer: It is completely normal to have an X-ray. Radiographers do lots of X-rays every day on all kinds of people for lots of different reasons.

question: Will the operation go wrong?
answer: It is very rare that an operation goes wrong as the doctors have done lots of training and do loads of operations every day.

question: My class is going on a trip two hours away. Is it OK for me to go?
answer: It might be okay to go on a school trip. Ask your parents to have a chat with your teachers and your doctor and they can work out if it’s okay to go. And don’t forget to ask your teachers if you’re worried about anything.

question: Will it feel strange going home?
answer: It might feel a bit strange when you go home but don’t worry, you’ll get used to it really quickly.

question: How long will the recovery be from my operation?
answer: It usually takes around 30 minutes to wake up in recovery, someone will be with you while you wake up. It’s different for everybody but your doctor should be able to tell you how long it will be before you can go home.

question: What does it feel like when the cancer has gone?
answer: It’s difficult to say what it will feel like after the cancer has gone. You may have some physical side effects still from the treatment and you may have some emotional things to think about too. Whatever you feel it’s important to know there is no right or wrong way to feel.

question: Do I have to be on a bed for my ultrasound?
answer: It’s easier for them to do the scan if you’re on the bed but if you really don’t want to you can ask to sit on a chair instead.

question: What if my pet is poorly?
answer: It’s important that if your pet is poorly you don’t get too close to them until they’re better. Ask someone else to take them to the vet.

question: Why is it important to eat well?
answer: It’s important to eat well because it helps you cope better with your treatment and fight off new illnesses. It will help you keep your strength up and feel better too! Yay!

question: Can my Hickman line get wet?
answer: It’s important to keep your Hickman line dry otherwise you might get an infection through it.

question: I worry a lot about upsetting my family when I’m not feeling well. What can I do?
answer: It’s important to talk to your family even if you’re worried about upsetting them because they might be able to help you. If you want you could also talk to another grown up you trust instead.

question: How will I feel?
answer: It’s impossible to say how you’ll feel because everyone feels different but don’t worry, whatever you’re feeling is okay.

question: I feel a bit nervous about seeing all my classmates again. What can I do to prepare myself?
answer: It’s normal to feel a bit nervous about going back to school. Why don’t you talk to your social worker or nurse and see if they have any ideas. They might even go and talk to your class before you go back.

question: Can I get a new pet?
answer: It’s not a great idea to get a new pet until you’re better because sometimes they can carry germs. Ask your doctor though and they can let you know what they think.

question: What if I feel scared?
answer: It’s okay to feel scared but remember you will always have someone with you and everyone at the hospital is there to look after you. Try not to worry and remember you can ask questions about anything you want.

question: What if I am squeamish about my cast being removed?
answer: It’s okay to feel squeamish about your cast being taken off. You don’t have to watch if you don’t want to and you’ll have someone with you.

question: What if I am squeamish about blood for my blood test?
answer: It’s okay to feel squeamish, just make sure you tell the person doing the blood test and if you feel faint stay sat down till you feel better.

question: I feel angry that I have cancer and I’m taking it out on my family. Why am I doing this?
answer: It’s horrible being unwell, and it’s easy to take that out on your family. But try to remember that your cancer isn’t anyone’s fault. Remember it’s okay to feel angry, but maybe you can talk to your family about how you’re feeling.

question: Can I choose what arm they take the blood from for my blood test?
answer: Let them know which arm you would prefer your blood test from if you want to and they’ll try their best though they may have to use the other.

question: What’s an LFT?
answer: LFT means Liver Function Test and it’s a test to see how well your liver is working.

question: What is limb sparing surgery?
answer: Limb sparing surgery is an operation for cancer in the arm, leg, shoulder or hip where the cancer is taken away without having to have the arm or leg removed too.

question: What are linen services staff?
answer: Linen services staff make sure there’s enough sheets, towels and uniforms for everyone.

question: How many people will help me?
answer: Loads of people will help you at the hospital. All sorts of doctors, nurses and other staff all work there to help get you better.

question: What is lymph?
answer: Lymph is a clear fluid that travels round your body helping you fight infections.

question: What is Macmillan?
answer: Macmillan is a charity which supports people with cancer and their families. They offer advice and help so people can cope better with the changes that the illness makes to their lives.

question: What if I am allergic to something from my blood test?
answer: Make sure you tell the nurses and doctors if you are allergic to anything. It’s nothing to worry about, they will know how to look after you.

question: How can I explain to my friends I still need to go to hospital when I don’t need medicine anymore?
answer: Maybe you could tell your friends that you still need to go to hospital so the doctors and nurses can keep an eye on you for a while to check that you stay healthy.

question: What is morphine sulphate?
answer: Morphine sulphate is a type of medicine that stops you from feeling pain. It is usually taken as a tablet or a syrup.

question: Where will my operation happen?
answer: Most operations take place in an operating theatre.

question: What is a kidney?
answer: Most people have two kidneys, they are about the size of a computer mouse and they’re near your tummy but round the back. They help clean your blood and get rid of things your body doesn’t need through your wee.

question: How long will I need the morphine infusion for?
answer: Most people usually need a morphine infusion for just a few days but ask your nurse or doctor and they’ll be happy to tell you.

question: What does MRI stand for?
answer: MRI stands for Magnetic Resonance Imaging, it is a scan which can see more things than a normal X-ray.

question: Does mucositis hurt?
answer: Mucositis can hurt and be quite uncomfortable. There are lots of things that can help though like drinking more liquids, keeping your mouth and teeth extra clean and even eating ice chips. Your doctor and the nurses will be able to give you more tips to help you.

question: What is mucositis?
answer: Mucositis is something that can happen when you’ve had chemo and it makes your mouth, throat and stomach swollen and irritated.

question: What is a neonatal nurse?
answer: Neonatal nurses look after babies that are born too soon or are poorly.

question: What is a nephrologist?
answer: Nephrologists look after people with kidney problems.

question: What is a neurologist?
answer: Neurologists look after people who have a problem with their brain, nerves and muscles.

question: What is a neurosurgeon?
answer: Neurosurgeons do operations on people’s brains, spines and nerves.

question: What are neutrophils?
answer: Neutrophils are a type of blood cell which helps your body fight off disease.

question: What does the NHS stand for?
answer: NHS stands for National Health Service.

question: Has anyone’s arm ever fell off from a blood test?
answer: No, don’t worry no one’s arm has ever fallen off from having a blood test.

question: Will the blood test needle go right through my arm?
answer: No, the needle won’t go through your arm. It’s far too small for that.

question: Will I miss my school work?
answer: No way! School work comes to you in hospital so you don’t fall behind.

question: Are there any side effects of a CAT scan?
answer: No, CAT scans only cause side effects if you have loads of them so the doctors make sure you only have them if you really need them.

question: Are there any side effects of a CT scan?
answer: No, CT scans only cause side effects if you have loads of them so the doctors make sure you only have them if you really need them.

question: Will something go wrong in my blood test?
answer: No, nothing will go wrong when you have your blood test. The people who do it are experts and they do it all the time. If you’re worried about something, ask them and they’ll explain everything to you.

question: Can people see the medicine on the outside for my MRI scan?
