answer: No, the medicine is hidden inside your body. It works a bit like glow in the dark paint which shows up on the MRI picture.

question: Will it be sore from my CAT scan?
answer: No, the CAT scan doesn’t hurt. It can be a bit awkward lying very still but it’s really quick and there’s nothing to worry about.

question: Is there anything to worry about for a CAT scan?
answer: No, there’s nothing to worry about when you have a CAT scan. It doesn’t hurt, it’s pretty quick and you just have to lie on a bed which slides in and out of a big metal doughnut. Easy peasy!

question: Is there anything to worry about for a CT scan?
answer: No, there’s nothing to worry about when you have a CT scan. It doesn’t hurt, it’s pretty quick and you just have to lie on a bed which slides in and out of a big metal doughnut. Easy peasy!

question: Do they do blood tests at weekends?
answer: Normally blood tests are done on a Monday to Friday but sometimes they are done at weekends too.

question: What is a nursery nurse?
answer: Nursery nurses look after really young children and babies.

question: Which nurses do which jobs?
answer: Nurses do lots of different jobs in the hospital. Ask them if you like.

question: What is a nursing associate?
answer: Nursing associates help nurses look after you.

question: What is obesity?
answer: Obesity is when someone has lots of fat on their body and it might cause health problems.

question: What is oedema?
answer: Oedema is a swelling when fluids build up in parts of your body.

question: Does a malignant tumour hurt?
answer: Often a malignant tumour doesn’t hurt at first but can begin to as it gets bigger and presses against other parts of your body.

question: What is Ondansetron?
answer: Ondansetron is a type of medicine which stops you feeling sick.

question: Can I go on Facebook?
answer: Only children over the age of 13 are allowed to use Facebook but if you’re old enough, have an account and a device you can get it on, you can use it like you would at home. Make sure your parents know though.

question: What is an ophthalmic physician?
answer: Ophthalmic physicians look after you if you have a problem with your eyes.

question: What is oxygen for?
answer: Oxygen reacts with sugars from the food we eat and makes energy for our bodies to use.

question: Does palliative medicine hurt?
answer: Palliative medicine doesn’t hurt, it makes you feel better.

question: What does palliative mean?
answer: Palliative medicine stops you from feeling poorly but it doesn’t cure your illness.

question: What is pancytopenia?
answer: Pancytopenia is when you don’t have as many blood cells as usual.

question: Can you park at the hospital?
answer: Parking is available at the hospital but sometimes there is a charge for it. Your parents should ask a member of staff about prices and permits. If possible it’s best for visitors to come on public transport.

question: What is a patient transport service (PTS) call handler?
answer: Patient transport service call handlers, or PTS call handlers, help people get to the hospital and sort out ambulances or buses for them.

question: What is PCA?
answer: PCA is a type of medicine which you give to yourself. It stands for Patient Controlled Analgesia.

question: Why do people act so weird when you say you have cancer?
answer: People sometimes act weird when you tell them you have cancer because they don’t know what to say and because they’re worried about saying the wrong thing. Sometimes they just feel sad that you’re poorly. Just be yourself and let them know you’re the same old you!

question: What are the jobs of the people taking the X-rays?
answer: People who take X-rays are called radiographers. Their job is to use different machines to take pictures of different parts of your body.

question: What are petechiae?
answer: Petechiae are small red or purple spots on the skin.

question: What is a pharmaceutical physician?
answer: Pharmaceutical physicians help to make new types of medicine.

question: What is a pharmacist?
answer: Pharmacists are experts in medicines and how to use them.

question: What is a pharmacy assistant?
answer: Pharmacy assistants help prepare and give out medicines.

question: What is a pharmacy technician?
answer: Pharmacy technicians make complicated medicines.

question: Does physiotherapy hurt?
answer: Physiotherapy doesn’t usually hurt but it might make parts of your body ache from being used again. This is normal and it’s not painful.

question: What is physiotherapy?
answer: Physiotherapy is when you do exercises that help you move around and become stronger again after an operation.

question: What is plasma?
answer: Plasma is the liquid part of your blood that blood cells move around in.

question: What are play specialists?
answer: Play specialists help children stop worrying about stuff when they’re poorly by playing with them - pretty cool hey?

question: What do the play specialists do?
answer: Play specialists make children’s stay in hospital as happy and fun as possible. They have lots of things for you to do to keep entertained. They can also help distract you while you have something done.

question: What do the play staff look like?
answer: Play staff look ordinary like you and your family and friends.

question: What is a porter?
answer: Porters push people around the hospital as well as moving equipment and other stuff around.

question: What is prednisolone?
answer: Prednisolone is a steroid. Steroids are used for lots of different things - the doctors & nurses will explain to you why you need steroids if you are given them.

question: What is Promethazine?
answer: Promethazine is a medicine to help you sleep and it can also help with allergies.

question: What is Prophylaxis?
answer: Prophylaxis is a type of medicine you’re given to try and stop you getting a certain illness or disease.

question: What is a prosthetic technician?
answer: Prosthetic technicians make false legs and arms.

question: What kind of food contains protein?
answer: Protein is in all sorts of things like meat, fish, eggs, beans, cheese and even nuts. It’s also in mushrooms, tofu, Quorn, milk, lentils and loads of other things.

question: What does radiotherapy feel like?
answer: Radiotherapy can make you feel a bit poorly and make your skin a bit sore and red.

question: Does radiotherapy hurt?
answer: Radiotherapy doesn’t hurt when you’re having it done but it can make your skin a bit dry or sore afterwards. The nurses will be able to get you something to soothe it though.

question: What is a receptionist?
answer: Receptionists welcome people to the hospital or clinic, they’ll be the first person your parents will speak to when you arrive.

question: What are red blood cells?
answer: Red blood cells are the part of your blood which help carry oxygen around your body.

question: What is rehabilitation?
answer: Rehabilitation means getting you back to doing things you did before you were poorly.

question: What is a secretary?
answer: Secretaries write letters and other documents.

question: What do senior health care assistants do?
answer: Senior health care assistants help nurses with some of their jobs.

question: What is a sibling?
answer: Sibling is just another name for a sister or brother.

question: What are side effects?
answer: Side effects are something that happens to you because of your treatment but it’s not part of the cure.

question: Will I cry at the end of my operation?
answer: Some children cry before they have had an operation as they have been worrying about it and some cry after their operation as they might be a bit sore or because they are glad it’s over. It is okay to cry at any point you are in hospital.

question: How come the medicines are at different times?
answer: Some medicines are given at different times because they don’t work if you mix them together. If you need more than one medicine the doctors and nurses will plan so there is a gap between them.

question: Will I be sick?
answer: Some medicines make you feel sick and some don’t. Your doctor will tell you if they might do before you have them but you can always ask if you’re not sure.

question: I used to love my food, but I just can’t eat. Help!
answer: Some medicines make you feel sick or change the way things taste. If your mouth is dry or sore, soft foods like macaroni cheese and mashed potato, or cold foods like ice cream, are good. How about a homemade milkshake? See what the dietitian at the hospital suggests too.

question: Will I have to wear a gown for my operation?
answer: Some operations mean you have to wear a gown while some operations you can wear pyjamas or loose clothes with no metal. The nurse who checks your height and weight will let you know.

question: What if I get nervous or worried about a blood test?
answer: Some people are nervous or worried about blood tests and that’s fine. It can help if you know what’s going to happen so ask lots of questions. You can also bring things from home to keep you busy during the test and take someone in with you to hold your hand. There are things to stop the test hurting too like magic cream or cold spray which make your skin numb.

question: Do I have to wear a wig?
answer: Some people wear a wig or head scarf or even a funky hat if they lose their hair and some don’t. It’s up to you really but the main thing is to try carrying on life as normal.

question: What can I do to make myself feel better if my hair falls out?
answer: Some people wear a wig or head scarf or even a funky hat if they lose their hair. It’s up to you really but the main thing is to try carrying on life as normal.

question: How long do side effects last?
answer: Some side effects go away pretty quickly but some can last weeks, months or even years. It all depends on your illness and the treatment you have. Your doctor should be able to give you a better idea so just ask.

question: Will I lose hair everywhere?
answer: Some treatments make you lose hair so it’s possible. Your doctor should be able to tell you if they think you will. Try not to worry too much though, it will grow back when your treatment is finished.

question: Can I have flowers?
answer: Some wards don’t allow flowers because they can carry germs so you’ll have to ask a nurse to see if your family or friends can bring you flowers or not.

question: What can I do in hospital? Are there things to play with and read?
answer: Some wards have a play area with toys and books to play with. Every ward has a play specialist who has fun things for you to do. You can also bring some things in from home.

question: Am I going to lose my hair when having chemotherapy?
answer: Sometimes chemo can make you lose your hair but sometimes it doesn’t. Your doctor will be able to tell you. Try not to worry too much about it as hair grows back when the treatment is finished.

question: Why can’t I go near dogs?
answer: Sometimes dogs can carry germs which might make you poorly when you’re having your treatment. Check with the doctor so see if you can go near dogs or not.

question: Will it hurt after my operation?
answer: Sometimes it can be a bit uncomfortable after an operation and hurt a little bit but don’t worry, the doctors and nurses will give you medicine to help stop it.

question: Will they need lots of attempts for my blood test?
answer: Sometimes it can be tricky doing a blood test so they might have to try more than once. They will tell you before they try again and if you want them to stop, just say so.

question: What if I wet the bed?
answer: Sometimes people wet the bed and it’s nothing to worry about. Let a nurse know and they’ll get your sheets changed and help you get cleaned up.

question: How will steroids make me feel?
answer: Sometimes steroids can make you feel really hungry and you will want to eat loads and sometimes they can affect your feelings and make you a bit moody.

question: How will the PCA make me feel?
answer: Sometimes the PCA can make you feel a bit sick or even itchy.

question: Why can’t I go to school?
answer: Sometimes the treatment you have means that you’re not able to go to school. Don’t worry though, you can keep up to date with everything while you’re in hospital.

question: What is a shared care hospital?
answer: Sometimes treatment happens in more than one hospital. A shared care hospital is usually the one that’s closest to home.

question: Will I lose my hair?
answer: Sometimes treatments can make you lose your hair, you’ll have to ask your doctor if they think it’s going to happen to you. Try not to worry though, it will usually grow back afterwards.

question: Can I choose how my treatment is given?
answer: Sometimes you can pick between liquid medicine or tablet but sometimes you can’t. It all depends on your treatment so you’ll have to ask your doctor.

question: Why do I have to come on a Saturday?
answer: Sometimes you have to go to the hospital on a Saturday because it gets really busy during the week.

question: Is it safe to play rugby?
answer: Sports and exercising is really good for you but it depends on whether you are well enough and if you’re having treatment at the moment so ask your doctor what they think. Rugby might be a bit rough at first.

question: Can I play sports after an operation?
answer: Sports and games can help you get better after an operation but make sure you ask your doctor first so they can help you work out which one is best for you.

question: Why should I stay active?
answer: Staying as active as possible during treatment can help you stay fit and well and it will make you feel better in yourself too.

question: The steroids I’m on make me very hungry. What can I do?
answer: Steroids can make you really hungry, don’t worry about it though, it’s quite normal. If you want to talk to someone about it ask a nurse or a dietitian.

question: Can stress cause cancer?
answer: Stress does not cause cancer although some of the things people do when they feel stressed, like smoking or eating unhealthy food, can sometimes lead to cancer.

question: Can I stroke my pet?
answer: Stroking your pet is fine just make sure you wash your hands afterwards.

question: Can my friends visit me in hospital?
answer: Sure, they can come and see you in hospital as often as you like during visiting time. Do you want to know when visiting times are?

question: Why does the surgeon wear that hat?
answer: Surgeons do complicated operations on people in an operating theatre which has to be kept very clean. They wear the hats to stop their hair falling onto the floor or equipment when they’re doing operations.

question: What is surgery?
answer: Surgery is when you have an operation to remove or fix something in your body.

question: What does systemic treatment mean?
answer: Systemic treatment is when you’re given medicine which works around your whole body.

question: Can I shout if removing my plaster cast hurts?
answer: Taking your plaster cast off shouldn’t hurt you but if it does you can let the nurse know and they will stop.

question: What is a telephonist?
answer: Telephonists answer the phones when someone calls.

question: Can I eat before I come to the hospital?
answer: That depends on why you’re coming to the hospital, if it’s for an operation you might not be able to eat before you come, but your doctors or nurses will tell you.

question: Sometimes I don’t want to talk about my cancer. What can I do?
answer: That’s fine. If you don’t want to talk about your cancer just ask if you can chat about it later. Ask them about something you want to talk about instead, like what’s going on at school or a new film.

question: What treatment will I need after my operation?
answer: That’s tricky to answer because everyone is different and it depend on what happens during your operation. Ask your doctor though, they should be able to give you an idea what treatment you’ll need after your operation.

question: Do I need chemotherapy?
answer: That’s tricky to answer because everyone is different but if you ask your doctor they’ll be able to tell you if you need chemotherapy or not and how it will work.

question: Where does the blood from my blood test go?
answer: The blood goes into a coloured bottle and it’s sent to a laboratory where scientists can test it. The result of the test will help the doctors understand what’s going on inside your body.

question: What does the blood test cream feel like?
answer: The blood test cream feels a bit cold at first then the skin where the cream is feels a bit weird and you can’t feel anything there, but it’s okay, it doesn’t hurt.

question: How long does a blood test take? How long will I be here?
answer: The blood test itself just takes a couple of minutes but you may have to wait for a bit before you go in. It can be a bit boring so bring something with you to play with.

question: What does the cannula look like?
answer: The cannula is about the same length as half your middle finger and looks like a small needle covered in a plastic straw with a little coloured tap at the end. Once it is in, the nurses attach a clear tube with a bung on the end, so they can add the medicine to your cannula.

question: Why do all the beds have different numbers?
answer: The beds have different numbers so the doctors and nurses know which bed is which on the ward.

question: What is the big machine in the anaesthetic room used for? How does it work?
answer: The big machine in the anaesthetic room is used to help you go to sleep as well as checking other things like how hot or cold you are and how fast your heart is beating when you’re asleep. The machine has a mask which goes over your mouth which gives you oxygen while you’re asleep.

question: Where does the blood come from for my blood test?
answer: The blood is all around our bodies. It travels in tubes called veins and arteries. When you have a blood test they take it from your vein but don’t worry, your body quickly makes more to replace it.

question: Will the blood test cream work?
answer: The blood test cream is covered by a clear plaster and then left on for about half an hour. After this you shouldn’t be able to feel anything where the cream has been. The nurse will then wipe it off and do the blood test.

question: Why do I have to have so many blood samples taken?
answer: The blood tests are because the doctors need to check that you’re well enough to have the treatment and also that the medicines are working. They’re not much fun but hang in there, it won’t be forever.

question: What is a bowel?
answer: The bowels are also known as the intestines and it’s where the remains of your food goes after it’s been through your stomach so your body can absorb water and nutrients from it as well as get rid of waste before you poo it out.

question: How big is the cannula needle?
answer: The cannula needle is small and it’s only there for a second while the plastic straw, called a cannula, is put in your vein then it’s taken away.

question: What is a care team?
answer: The care team is the group of people that look after you when you’re in hospital.

question: Does the cast cutter cut your skin?
answer: The cast cutter doesn’t cut your skin. It jiggles about a lot to get through the plaster but it doesn’t touch you.

question: What are they doing a CAT scan for?
answer: The CAT scan is so the doctors can see what’s inside your body and work out what they need to do to make you better.

question: How long will a CAT scan take?
answer: The CAT scan itself only takes a couple of minutes but they might need a bit of time first to set everything up. Your appointment should take no more than about 15 minutes.

question: How does the CAT scan machine work?
answer: The CAT scanner is like a giant camera which can take pictures of your insides. It takes loads of them to make a 3D picture.

question: Is the CT scanner dark?
answer: The CT scanner isn’t dark, it’s open at both ends and is well lit.

question: What is the hospital’s charity?
answer: The charity is called the Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital Charity and it helps raise money for equipment, research and to make children’s time in hospital a bit more comfortable.

question: What is a chef?
answer: The chef cooks food for everyone in the hospital - yum yum in my tum!

question: How does chemotherapy work?
answer: The chemo medicine stops cancer cells from working.

question: How come the blood test cleaning wipe smells funny?
answer: The cleaning wipe smells funny because it has special stuff on it to keep your skin clean. Your skin needs to be clean so no germs get in your when you have the blood test.

question: What is a colon?
answer: The colon is also known as the large intestine. It does part of the job of absorbing liquid from your food and it contains bacteria which help break what’s left down into poo.

question: Do I need to have cream? What will the cream do?
answer: The cream makes your skin go numb and stops you from feeling the needle going in. You can decide if you want to have the cream or not, you do not need to have it if you don’t want to.

question: What are they doing a CT scan for?
answer: The CT scan is so the doctors can see what’s inside your body and work out what they need to do to make you better.

question: How long will a CT scan take?
answer: The CT scan itself only takes a couple of minutes but they might need a bit of time first to set everything up. Your appointment should take no more than about 15 minutes.

question: How does the CT scan machine work?
answer: The CT scanner is like a giant camera which can take pictures of your insides. It takes loads of them to make a 3D picture.

question: What is the curtain for?
answer: The curtain is to give you some privacy when the doctors and nurses come to see you.

question: Will someone explain what is going on for my surgery?
answer: The doctor will explain everything about your surgery when they come round to talk to you. If there is anything that doesn’t make sense or you don’t understand then it is okay to ask questions.

question: Will they look after me?
answer: The doctors and nurses will look after you and make you feel safe and comfortable.

question: What are the doctors like? What do the doctors look like?
answer: The doctors are just normal people. They are kind and they’ll make you as happy and comfortable as possible.

question: Why doesn’t the doctor do my blood test?
answer: The doctors have loads of people to see so they don’t have time to do the blood tests, instead they ask a nurse or phlebotomist (a person who takes your blood) whose job it is to do it.

question: Is there anything I need to know about my blood test procedure?
answer: The doctors or nurses will let you know if there’s anything else you need to know about your blood test but if you have any questions, just ask.

question: Will I be okay when I go to sleep for my operation?
answer: The doctors who help you go to sleep, called anaesthetists, have done lots of training to make sure you will be safe and okay. They also stay with you and check you are okay through the whole of your operation.

question: Can I still walk around with the drip?
answer: The drip usually has a stand that goes with it. Sometimes they have wheels on so you can wheel it round while you have a walk or go to the toilet. Ask your nurse if it is okay for you to walk around with the drip.

question: What’s the most popular film?
answer: The films change all the time! There’s bound to be one that you like though.

question: What is the foam for?
answer: The foam is called hand sanitiser and it’s used to keep your hands clean and stop germs from spreading.

question: What is on the food menu?
answer: The food menu changes every day, you’ll have to ask a nurse to let you know.

question: What is the gel for?
answer: The gel is called hand sanitiser and it’s used to keep your hands clean and stop germs from spreading.

question: I’m too hot. Can the heating be turned down?
answer: The heating can’t be turned down or up but ask a nurse if there’s something they can do to help like bringing a fan or some cold water to drink.

question: I’m cold. Can the heating be turned up?
answer: The heating can’t be turned up or down I’m afraid but you can ask a nurse for extra blankets if you want.

question: Is the hospital scary?
answer: The hospital can seem a bit scary but that’s quite normal at first. In reality it isn’t and you’ll quickly get used to it. Everyone who works at the hospital is there to help you. Don’t forget you can ask as many questions as you like and if you’re still not sure tell your parents how you’re feeling, they will be able to help.

question: How will I find my way around the hospital?
answer: The hospital has a big map when you first walk in so you can see where you are and where you need to go. There are also signs pointing to where different things are.

question: Is this hospital a safe place to be?
answer: The hospital is a safe place to be. All of the staff are very well trained to look after children and young people and keep them safe.

question: Can I get vegan food?
answer: The hospital kitchens make food for everyone no matter what they eat, including vegan food.

question: What is a housekeeper?
answer: The housekeepers keep the hospital clean and tidy.

question: What is an immune system?
answer: The immune system is all the different parts of your body that help protect you from illness.

question: Is the ward dark at night?
answer: The lights are switched off at night and the ward is dark so everyone can get to sleep. Ask a nurse if you’d like to use your lamp for a bit longer but don’t stay up too late!

question: Does the Linac machine hurt?
answer: The Linac machine doesn’t hurt when you’re having it done but it can make your skin a bit dry or sore afterwards. The nurses will be able to get you something to soothe it though.

question: What is the lymphatic system?
answer: The lymphatic system is made up of thin tubes that run around your body, carrying a liquid called lymph and fighting infection.

question: Will it tickle taking off my cast?
answer: The machine used to take the cast off jiggles about a bit and can make it feel tickly.

question: Will it hurt when I have my plaster cast taken off?
answer: The machine used to take your cast off is pretty noisy but it doesn’t actually touch you so it won’t hurt.

question: Are any of the machines dangerous?
answer: The machines aren’t dangerous. Everyone who uses them is an expert and has loads of training in how to use them. You’ll be completely safe.

question: Why does some treatment make your hair fall out?
answer: The medicines or radiotherapy that’s helping you get better sometimes damage the cells where your hair grows making it fall out. Don’t worry about it though, it will all grow back when you’re better.

question: Is the barium milkshake good for me?
answer: The milkshake isn’t like a drink you’d have at home, it’s just for when you have an X-ray but it’s not bad for you.

question: How do the monitors work?
answer: The monitors measure different things in your body like your blood pressure to see how hard your heart is pumping, and your heart rate to see how fast it is beating. Ask the nurse, they’ll be happy to explain everything to you.

question: Does an MRI scan smell?
answer: The MRI machine doesn’t smell but sometimes there’s a whiff of the stuff they use to clean the hospital with.

question: How will the MRI machine make me feel?
answer: The MRI machine shouldn’t make you feel any different and it doesn’t hurt. It is quite loud though so you will be given some headphones. If you have some medicine through a cannula in your hand it might make you feel like you need a wee but you won’t wee and it’s quite normal so don’t worry about it.

question: Does the MRI hurt?
answer: The MRI scan won’t hurt you. It’s just like lying on a bed. It’s a bit cramped but you’re not in there for long so don’t worry.

question: Is the MRI dark?
answer: The MRI scanner is not dark, it’s open at both ends and is well lit.

question: What does the cannula/blood test needle do?
answer: The needle goes into your arm so the person doing the test can take blood out to test it. If you have a cannula it is left in so you can be given medicine easily too.

question: Is the cannula needle long?
answer: The needle used to put the cannula in is about the length of half of your little finger. The straw that is left behind once the needle is removed is like a super thin drinking straw and is around 3 cm long.

question: How do they know how much medicine to put in?
answer: The nurse is given a note called a prescription which tells them what medicine you should have and how much.

question: How many friends can you play with at visiting time?
answer: The nurses will be able to tell you how many of your friends can visit at the same time.

question: How do I get ready for an MRI scan?
answer: The nurses will help you get ready for an MRI scan so there’s no need to worry, it’s really easy. The most important thing is to make sure you don’t have any metal things with you or on your clothes because there’s a massive magnet in the scanner. You can take a special toy with you if you like.

question: Are the nurses friendly?
answer: The nurses, doctors and all staff within the hospital are very friendly. They try to make your time in the hospital as happy and as comfortable as possible.

question: What is the person called who puts you to sleep?
answer: The person who gives you medicine to help you go to sleep is called an anaesthetist.

question: How do you turn the X-ray machine on and off?
answer: The person who takes the picture turns the X-ray machine on and off with a switch behind the glass panel where they stand.

question: Is it like A&E taking your cast off?
answer: The place they take the cast off is a bit like the plaster room at A&E but with more children there. There might be up to four of you there at one time.

question: What do the play staff do?
answer: The play staff help make your stay in hospital as happy as it can be. They’ll help you relax if you feel worried about anything and cheer you up.

question: How does the pump work with my cannula?
answer: The pump works by letting small bits of medicine go from the drip bag or the syringe into your cannula.

question: Is the radioactive drink going to taste nice?
answer: The radioactive drink doesn’t really taste very nice but you can have chocolate or strawberry milkshake powder added to it to make it taste better.

question: Can they add something to the barium milkshake to make it taste nice?
answer: The radiographers, the person taking your picture, can add some chocolate or strawberry milkshake powder to the drink to make it taste nicer.

question: Does the radiotherapy mask hurt?
answer: The radiotherapy mask doesn’t hurt but it can feel a bit awkward. Don’t worry though, it’s not for a long time and you can keep it when your treatment is finished.

question: What is the red string for in the toilet?
answer: The red string in the toilet is an alarm and you should only pull it in an emergency, like if you fall over or hurt yourself.

question: What are the risks of chemotherapy?
answer: The risks of chemotherapy are side effects which include feeling sick, being very tired, and losing hair.

question: What is the orange button for?
answer: The round, orange button is to call a nurse over if you need help with anything and it is not urgent. It will light up and you’ll hear a call bell sound. A nurse will come as soon as possible.

question: What do sisters do?
answer: The sister is the nurse that’s in charge of a ward. Sisters rule! If they are a man they’re called a charge nurse.

question: How big is the X-ray picture?
answer: The size of the X-ray picture depends on what you are having x-rayed. Your leg will need a bigger X-ray picture than something small like your hand. Your doctor can make the picture bigger and smaller on their computer.

question: What is the spray for a blood test? What does the spray do? How does it work?
answer: The spray makes your skin feel cold so you don’t feel the blood test. It’s like having an ice cube on your arm.

question: Does the table go up and down / move?
answer: The table can move about on wheels as well as go up and down so it can go over your bed. Ask a member of staff or one of your visitors to help if you can’t manage it.

question: What are the tattoos for?
answer: The tattoos help the Linac machine line up properly so the treatment is done in exactly the right place.

question: Am I going to be okay?
answer: The team at the hospital are very well trained to look after young people. They do everything they can to make sure you will be safe and okay.

question: It’s been a long time since I played any sport. What if I can’t do it as well?
answer: The trick to getting back into sports is to start doing some gentle exercise as soon as you are feeling well enough. This will help you start to feel fitter again. You could ask the people looking after you in hospital if you can start doing a bit more activity.

question: Will my chemotherapy be tablets, injections or a drip?
answer: The type of chemotherapy you have depends on what your doctor decides will be best for you. Ask them next time you see them.

question: How cold is the ultrasound gel?
answer: The ultrasound gel isn’t too cold, it’s around the same temperature as a glass of water being put on your skin.

question: Is it hot or cold in the ultrasound room?
answer: The ultrasound scan room is the same temperature as the rest of the hospital. There is air conditioning too which will cool it down or warm it up depending on the weather.

question: Can I see my insides on the ultrasound screen? Do I have to see my insides?
answer: The ultrasound scan shows up on the computer next to where you are. These are pictures of what is inside of you. If you would like to see it, the person doing the scan will be happy for you to watch but you don’t have to. It’s up to you.

question: How long does it take to get the blood test results?
answer: The wait for your results depends on what type of blood test you’re having. Some tests only take a few hours but others can take up to a week. Ask the person doing the test, they will be able to tell you.

question: Can I download films / TV shows / games?
answer: The Wi-Fi is quite slow I’m afraid so if you want to download something like a film you should ask your parents if they’ll do it at home and bring it in for you.

question: Why do I need to wear a wrist identification bracelet?
answer: The wrist band lets the nurses and doctors know important things like your name, birthday, and it has a special number so they can see all the information about you on the computer.

question: How big is the X-ray machine?
answer: The X-ray machine is about the same size as a desk at school. The area with the light that takes the picture is about the same size as a computer screen.

question: How does the X-ray machine work?
answer: The X-ray machine is like a giant camera which produces a special light that travels through your body to a metal sheet. When it hits something hard like your bones it shows up as white on the sheet and when it’s something soft like skin the picture is black. This is how the doctor can see inside you.

question: How friendly will the X-ray staff be?
answer: The X-ray staff are very friendly, they do X-rays all the time so they know how to look after you well.

question: What fun activities are on today?
answer: There are different activities every day to stop you getting bored, There are play rooms, sensory rooms, youth clubs and craft clubs. There are computers and a Nintendo, TVs and games too. For younger children there are Theodora Clown Doctors who visit every now and then and teens have their own relaxation room with a pool table.

question: What is my doctor’s name?
answer: There are loads of doctors here, far too many for me to remember everyone’s names! Next time you see them just ask, they won’t mind.

question: What is my doctor called?
answer: There are loads of doctors here, far too many for me to remember what everyone is called! Next time you see them just ask, they won’t mind.

question: What is my nurse’s name?
answer: There are loads of nurses here, far too many for me to remember everyone’s names! Next time you see them just ask, they won’t mind.

question: What is my nurse called?
answer: There are loads of nurses here, far too many for me to remember what everyone is called! Next time you see them just ask, they won’t mind.

question: What do I do in the day?
answer: There are loads of things to do at the hospital when you’re not having treatment. There are games and toys as well as TVs. Ask a nurse or a play specialist who will be able to give you some ideas or you can bring some things from home.

question: What can I do to keep busy in hospital?
answer: There are loads of things you can do to keep you busy in hospital like playing board games, reading books, and playing with toys. You could even write a story or do some drawings maybe. Don’t forget to bring things with you from home too.

question: Do side effects hurt?
answer: There are lots of different side effects to different kinds of treatment and they’re all different. Some can make you feel poorly but the doctors and nurses can help you feel better if they do.

question: Chemotherapy makes me feel really sick. Is there anything I can do to feel better?
answer: There are lots of medicines which can stop you feeling sick when you’re having chemo, but it may take a few goes to find the one that works best for you.

question: Why are so many people looking after me?
answer: There are lots of people looking after you because there are so many different jobs to be done to make sure you get everything you need to get better.

question: Is there a sink to wash my hands and face?
answer: There are lots of sinks for hand washing as well as gel in dispensers which also keep them clean.

question: Who are the staff here?
answer: There are lots of staff at the hospital who all do different jobs. Depending on why you are in hospital you will meet lots of different members of staff. Some you will see only once and some you will see a lot.

question: I’m going back to school soon. What can my school do to help me settle back in?
answer: There are lots of ways your school can make settling in easier for you so don’t be afraid to ask. You might need to just go back for a couple of days a week or maybe you need someone there to help you - just ask them. Don’t forget to tell your teachers if you’re worried about anything.

question: Why are there open wards/rooms?
answer: There are open wards and group rooms so that the nurses can look after a few children at the same time. It’s nice to be around other children so you can chat and play with them.

question: Why is there an oxygen tank in the blood test room?
answer: There are oxygen tanks and other equipment in all rooms of the hospital. These are for children who come into these rooms and are unwell.

question: Why is my blood pressure high?
answer: There could be a few reasons for having high blood pressure, ask a nurse of your doctor, they’ll be able to tell you.

question: Is there a bed for my parents to sleep in at night?
answer: There is a bed your parents can stay in at night but you can only have one of them stay at a time.

question: Is there mobile phone reception in hospital?
answer: There is mobile phone reception in the hospital but in some places in the hospital it is not the best connection.

question: Is there a play room in hospital?
answer: There is usually an area on each ward for children and young people to play. If you would like to play in the play room and meet the play specialist you can ask your nurse.

question: Is there Wi-Fi in hospital?
answer: There is Wi-Fi in the hospital but the connection is quite slow and you have to sign up on a web page to use the Wi-Fi. You would need to ask a grown up to help you with this.

question: Will there be Wi-Fi?
answer: There is Wi-Fi in the hospital. You have to sign up to use Wi-Fi so get a grown up to help you.

question: Who is the best doctor / nurse?
answer: There isn’t a best doctor or nurse. They all work really hard doing different things to help you and other children get better and they’re all brilliant!

question: How many people will be in the blood test room?
answer: There might be a few people there when you have your blood test. There’ll be the person who takes your blood who is called a phlebotomist, a nurse and sometimes an assistant or a student, as well as you, and whoever you take.

question: Are there any books to read in hospital?
answer: There might be some books to read in the waiting room or on the ward. Why don’t you bring some from home in case you don’t find something you like.

question: Will I make new friends when I go for a blood test?
answer: There will be other children and young people in the waiting area so you could talk to them and make friends.

question: What activities can I do in hospital?
answer: There’s loads of activities you can do in hospital - ask one of the team for ideas, or even ask your parents to find out for you.

question: What’s the food like?
answer: There’s loads to choose from and you can even get snacks for when you get peckish.

question: Why is that other kid crying?
answer: There’s lots of reasons why people cry in hospital. Some children can feel scared, some are worried about their illness or treatment, some might feel a bit lonely. It’s okay to feel sad and it’s okay to cry. Why don’t you try to make friends with them so you both have someone to talk to when things make you feel sad.

question: What is there to do in hospital?
answer: There’s lots of things to do. The play specialist will have toys and games you can use as well as books and colouring things. There’s also a TV and you can bring things from home too.

question: Do they push on hard when doing the ultrasound scan?
answer: They are as gentle as possible when they’re doing the ultrasound scan but tell them if they’re pushing too hard for you.

question: How do they know how to get the X-ray lined up?
answer: They are told which bit of your body your doctor would like an X-ray of, they then use the light from the machine to line up the machine and guide them to where the picture will be taken.

question: How will they know I want the spray at my blood test?
answer: They should ask you if you want the spray or the special cream but you can always ask them if you want.

question: How do they get the cast off?
answer: They use a machine called a plaster cutter to get the cast off which looks a bit like a pizza slicer with a hoover attached to it. The circle bit jiggles about and cuts through the plaster without touching your skin. Then the nurse uses scissors to cut the rest off before giving it a quick wash.

question: Can they take too much blood when I have a blood test?
answer: They won’t take too much blood. Different tests need different amounts of blood but they’re experts at taking just enough.

question: Will I have my arm amputated?
answer: This is a chat you should be having with your family or a nurse, they’ll be able to explain things better than me.

question: Will I have my leg amputated?
answer: This is a chat you should be having with your family or a nurse, they’ll be able to explain things better than me.

question: What is tissue?
answer: Tissue is a group of cells that work together to do a certain type of job in the body.

question: How do the monitors tell you what your heart rate is?
answer: To measure your heart rate your nurse will put a clip on your finger or toe which shines light through to your veins. It measures each beat of your heart through your veins and shows your heart rate on the monitor.

question: Are ultrasound machines complicated?
answer: Ultrasound scanners are quite complicated, that’s why the people that do the scan have lots of training. Even though it’s complicated, having the scan is very quick and simple.

question: What are Us and Es?
answer: Us and Es is a type of blood test to see how well your kidneys are working. It stands for urea and electrolytes.

question: How long does an X-ray take?
answer: Usually having an X-ray taken takes less than half a second. Getting into the right position for the X-ray may take a little longer but you are not usually in the x-ray room for longer than 15 minutes.

question: Is an X-ray quick?
answer: Usually having an X-ray taken takes less than half a second. Getting into the right position for the X-ray may take a little longer but you are not usually in the X-ray room for longer than 15 minutes.

question: Are they going to keep me in after my blood test?
answer: Usually when you come to hospital for a blood test you don’t have to stay. If your doctor feels you need to stay in hospital they will tell you before you have your test.

question: Can my mum and dad come with me at my X-ray?
answer: Usually when you have an X-ray one of your parents can come in the room with you. They have to wear a special apron with metal in it so they don’t get x-rayed as well.

question: What is a virus?
answer: Viruses are a type of germ. They’re very tiny, and when they get inside your body, they can make you sick. Viruses cause colds, chicken pox, measles, flu, and many other diseases.

question: What time is bed time?
answer: Visiting time finishes at 8 o’clock so that everyone can start settling down for bedtime. Older children may want to stay up a bit later but the TV must go off at 9 o’clock and remember, you’ll be up early in hospital!

question: What does it feel like after my treatment?
answer: What it feels like after your treatment is different for everybody. You might have good days and bad days and it might take some time to get back to normal again. Whatever it feels like just remember that there is no right or wrong.

question: What shall I bring with me to hospital?
answer: What you bring with you depends on what you are coming to hospital for. If you are going to stay in you should bring some pyjamas, slippers, clean pants or knickers, toothbrush and toothpaste and a facecloth. You could also bring some things to do like your favourite toys or books. You can also bring an iPad or tablet if you have one. Don’t forget to pack the charger!

question: Where do the needles go after they’ve been used?
answer: When a needle has been used it is disposed of straight away. The hospital has special boxes called sharps boxes which they go into before they are destroyed.

question: Can I choose whether to have the needle or the mask for my operation?
answer: When the anaesthetist comes to talk to you they will explain about the needle and the mask. They will tell you which one they think is best for you and you might be able to choose yourself.

question: Does the cannula hurt when it goes in?
answer: When the cannula goes in it can feel a bit pinchy and scratchy but it doesn’t really hurt. Your nurse should put some magic cream on the area before they put the cannula in, which stops you feeling it too much.

question: What does the blood test feel like?
answer: When the needle goes into your skin for a blood test it can feel quite scratchy and pinchy. This only lasts for a few seconds then you get a plaster to cover it over.

question: What will happen when I’m asleep?
answer: When you are asleep you will have your operation, when your operation is finished the anaesthetist, the person who helps you go to sleep, will wake you up.

question: When can I eat in hospital?
answer: When you are coming into hospital you will be told whether you can eat or not before you arrive. You can always ask your nurse when you can eat if you are not sure.

question: Will I get a room or stay in the waiting room for my operation?
answer: When you are waiting for your operation you wait in the waiting area. You will then be taken round to a room to go to sleep and have your operation.

question: When can I go home?
answer: When you can go home is something that your doctor will decide, why don’t you ask them and see what they say?

question: What will happen to me in hospital?
answer: When you come to the hospital a doctor or nurse will explain everything that’s going to happen but if you’re not sure, it’s fine to ask questions.

question: Can I get out of my bed?
answer: When you feel well enough you can get out of bed and have a walk around. If you are not allowed to get out of bed because of the operation you have had, your nurse will let you know. If you are unsure about this it is okay to ask your nurse.

question: Will I come and sit on a bed for my operation?
answer: When you first come into hospital you will sit in the waiting area, usually on a chair. When you go into the room where you go to sleep you will sit on the bed.

question: Do we find out my ultrasound results straight away?
answer: When you get your results depends on when you see your doctor next. It might be straight away or your appointment might not be for a while. If you want, you can ask your family to call the doctors to find out.

question: How many people will be in the CAT scan room?
answer: When you have a CAT scan as well as you, in the room there will be the person you take with you, the person who takes the pictures who is called a radiographer and sometimes they have someone to help them.

question: How many people will be in the CT scan room?
answer: When you have a CT scan as well as you, in the room there will be the person you take with you, the person who takes the pictures who is called a radiographer and sometimes they have someone to help them.

question: Why can’t I drink before my operation?
answer: When you have an operation you will be given medicine to make you sleep and, if you have a drink before it, it can make you be sick so it’s very important not to.

question: What does it feel like when stitches are removed?
answer: When you have stitches removed it will feel like someone tugging gently and it shouldn’t hurt.

question: What will be happening during my operation for my Hickman line?
answer: When you have your Hickman line fitted you will be asleep so you won’t feel anything. While you’re asleep the doctor will put a very thin tube into a vein in your chest so they can give you medicine and take blood samples. When you wake up you will see a small stich near your neck and lower down the tube will be poking out of you and also have stitches to hold it in place. Doctors do this operation all the time, it’s very safe and will be over in no time.

question: Is my operation going to hurt?
answer: When you have your operation you will be asleep so it will not hurt. When you wake up from your operation you may be a bit sore. The nurses on the ward can give you some medicine to stop it from hurting.

question: Do I lay down or sit up for my MRI scan?
answer: When you have your scan you lie down on a special bed that moves in and out of the big metal doughnut hole. If you sat up you wouldn’t be able to fit in the scanner!

question: How many people will be there for my ultrasound scan?
answer: When you have your ultrasound scan there’ll be you, whoever you choose to come with you, and the person doing the scan. Sometimes they have an assistant too.

question: What do I have to do at my ultrasound?
answer: When you have your ultrasound scan you’ll lie down on the bed then the person doing it will put some gel on the area they’re going to scan. They will then move a probe around on the gel to see different parts of your body. They might ask you to take a deep breath and sometimes you’ll be asked to have a big drink before you arrive.

question: Where will I sleep in hospital?
answer: When you stay in hospital you have your own area with your own bed called your bed space. You will sleep here at night time and can rest here during the day.

question: Will I get a bed if I ask?
answer: When you stay in hospital you will get a bed for you to rest and sleep in.

question: What do they mean by a balloon to breathe into?
answer: When you use the mask to go to sleep there is a green balloon at the end of the mask tube. You have to take deep breaths and blow out big breaths so you get enough of the medicine. These breaths can blow up the balloon.

question: Where will I stay when I’m having a stem cell transplant?
answer: When you’re having a stem cell transplant you’ll have a special room of your own which the doctors call isolation. You can have a member of your family stay with you when you’re there.

question: Which animals should I avoid during treatment?
answer: When you’re having treatment try not to go near farm animals, reptiles & amphibians, birds or any animal that is wild or poorly.

question: Do I go to school after my blood test?
answer: Whether or not you go to school after your blood test depends on when it is and if you have any other tests that day. You’ll have to ask the person that brings you.

question: How do they decide if it is your finger or your arm where they take blood from my blood test?
answer: Whether they take blood from your arm or your finger depends on what they’re testing for. If they only need a little bit then it might just be your finger but if they need more they’ll take it from your arm.

question: Can I still do all the same things?
answer: Whether you can do all the same things or not depends on what kind of treatment you’re going to have. There’ll be some things you might not be able to do but others which will be fine. Ask your doctor if they can tell you.

question: Can I go on holiday?
answer: Whether you can go on holiday depends on how your treatment is going. You will have to ask your doctor. You may have to wait until your treatment is finished.

question: What sort of food should I eat while I’m having treatment?
answer: While you’re having treatment you should try to eat lots of different things. You should try to eat stuff with protein in it as well as fruit and veg for vitamins. You can even have some treats too. Ask your doctor or nurse for ideas.

question: What are white blood cells?
answer: White blood cells are a type of blood cell which help you get better when you’re poorly by fighting infections.

question: My brother is 11 and doesn’t understand about my cancer. How can I help him understand?
answer: Why don’t you ask your parents to have a chat with them about it? Maybe they could come and visit you in hospital too.

question: Are X-rays just for kids?
answer: X-rays are for anyone of any age.

question: I’ve finished my treatment but have to go back to hospital for outpatient appointments. Will I be able to take my games console with me?
answer: Yeah it’s fine to take your games console along so you don’t get bored while you’re waiting. Make sure you bring some headphones though!

question: Is the MRI machine big?
answer: Yeah, the MRI machine is quite big. The inside needs to be able to fit a whole person in it and the outside has loads of big magnets in it. It’s about the size of a car.

question: Can my parents stay with me during my treatment?
answer: Yep, your parents can stay with you during treatment. The only time they can’t be with you is when you’re having an operation and just after it.

question: Can my brother and sister come and visit me?
answer: Yes, brothers and sisters are allowed to visit as long as they are with an adult. Ask your nurse what time people can come and visit you.

question: Am I in safe hands?
answer: Yes, you are in safe hands. Everyone at the hospital is an expert and they are trained to look after you and make you as comfortable as possible.

question: Can I bring my iPad to hospital?
answer: Yes, you can bring your iPad with you. Don’t forget to pack the charger in case the battery runs out.

question: Can I bring my phone with me to hospital?
answer: Yes, you can bring your phone with you. Don’t forget to pack the charger in case the battery runs out.

question: Can I bring my phone? iPad?
answer: Yes, you can bring your phone, iPad or tablet. Just make sure you bring the charger so it doesn’t run out of battery.

question: Can I keep my cat while I’m having treatment?
answer: Yes, you can keep your cat. Stroking and playing with your cat can help you relax which is good for you!

question: Can I keep my dog while I’m having treatment?
answer: Yes, you can keep your dog. Dogs are great company and they can help you relax which is really good for you.

question: Can I keep my fish during treatment?
answer: Yes, you can keep your fish just don’t put your hands in the water okay?

question: Can I move my arm after a blood test?
answer: Yes, you will be able to move your arm after your blood test.

question: Will I be able to play?
answer: Yes, you will be able to play but you might have to be careful about what you do while you’re being treated and for a bit afterwards too. Your doctor will let you know what you can and can’t do.

question: Will I be asleep during the operation?
answer: Yes, you’ll be asleep during the operation. You’ll be given special medicine so you sleep right through and don’t feel a thing.

question: Will I be asleep if I need an operation?
answer: Yes, if you have an operation special doctors called anaesthetists will help you go to sleep. They will come and have a chat with you about the different ways you can go to sleep and which one is best for you.

question: Do other kids have blood tests?
answer: Yes, loads of other children have blood tests. The blood test room in a children’s hospital can do over 80 blood tests in one day!

question: Do they have TVs in hospital?
answer: Yes, there are TVs next to the beds. Ask a grown up if you need help with it.

question: Can I bring my teddy?
answer: Yes, you can bring your teddy and anything else you feel will make you feel happier in hospital.

question: Will the doctors explain what will happen to me for my operation?
answer: Yes. One of the doctors, the anaesthetist, will explain what happens when you go to sleep and wake up again and another person, the surgeon, will tell you what will happen during your operation when you’re asleep. Ask as many questions as you want.

question: Are dogs allowed in hospital?
answer: You are not allowed to bring dogs into hospital, as they might poo or wee on the floor! Some children’s hospitals do have their own therapy dog which visits the ward.

question: How come you can’t have breakfast before an operation?
answer: You aren’t allowed to eat for six hours before an operation because it can make you sick. So if your operation is in the morning this means you can’t have breakfast.

question: Who can I ask for help?
answer: You can ask anyone for help but you may feel better asking someone you’ve seen a few times like the nurse or your doctor.

question: What questions can I ask the nurses and doctors?
answer: You can ask the nurses and doctors any questions you like. No question is a silly question and they are happy to answer all of your questions. Usually if they don’t know the answer they will find someone who does.

question: What times can my friends come and visit?
answer: You can ask the ward clerk or a nurse who will be able to tell you what time friends can visit.

question: Can I bring food in to hospital?
answer: You can bring food into the hospital but it has to be kept in a bag so other children can’t see it. Some children aren’t allowed to eat as they are having something done so seeing your food may make them hungry and sad.

question: I need help.
answer: You can call a nurse by pressing the orange button.

question: Can I change my mind about a clinical trial?
answer: You can change your mind about being in a clinical trail at any time you want. Not a problem at all.

question: Can my mum and dad stay with me at my ultrasound?
answer: You can choose one person to come in the room with you when you have your ultrasound scan. This can be your mum or your dad or whoever has brought you.

question: When can I get up after my operation?
answer: You can get up as soon as possible after your operation - it’s a great way to help you get better. Ask your doctor or nurse when you’ll be ready.

question: When can I go home? How long will I be in?
answer: You can go home when your doctor thinks you are well enough and ready to go home. Your doctor usually lets you know before your operation how long they think you will be in hospital for.

question: Can I Google my cancer?
answer: You can google cancer but it’s better to ask your doctor because there’s lots of wrong information on the internet.

question: Can I go to the garden?
answer: You can only leave the ward with an adult and they must tell the nurse in charge where you are going, what time you are coming back and how they can get in touch with you while you’re not there. If the nurse says it’s okay then yes you can go to the garden.

question: Can I pray in hospital?
answer: You can pray in hospital, either in your bed area or if you want you can ask a nurse where the prayer room is.

question: Can my mum hold my hand when removing my cast?
answer: You can take whoever you like into the plaster room with you and they can hold your hand while you have your cast taken off.

question: Who can I talk to?
answer: You can talk to anyone you feel comfortable with - family, friends, doctors, counsellors and nurses will all be happy to listen and chat with you about whatever you want.

question: What should I tell people?
answer: You can tell people as much or as little as you want about what’s happening. Lots of people will want to help you, some will want to know more and some might be confused about it. Just tell people what you’re comfortable with and let others deal with it in their own way.

question: Can I bring my PlayStation / Nintendo?
answer: You can’t bring your games console to the hospital I’m afraid but ask a nurse if they have one on the ward you can use or you might want to bring a tablet in from home which you can use instead.

question: Can I eat the ultrasound jelly?
answer: You can’t eat the ultrasound gel! It would be like eating hair gel - ew!

question: Can I go on my iPad in a CAT scan?
answer: You can’t go on your iPad while you’re having your scan because the metal will affect the picture but you can use it when you’re waiting to go in and afterwards as well.

question: Can I go on my iPad in a CT scan?
answer: You can’t go on your iPad while you’re having your scan because the metal will affect the picture but you can use it when you’re waiting to go in and afterwards as well.

question: Why can’t I go swimming while I’m on treatment?
answer: You can’t go swimming when you’re having treatment because you might get an infection where one of your tubes is if it gets wet.

question: Can I see my insides at my MRI scan?
answer: You can’t see your insides when you’re having your scan because the picture goes straight to the computer behind the glass screen. When you get your results you can ask to look at the pictures if you like.

question: Can I wear makeup?
answer: You can’t wear makeup or nail varnish if you’re having an operation. If you want to wear it on other days ask a nurse if it’s okay first.

question: Can I watch TV after bed time?
answer: You cannot watch TV after 9 o’clock I’m afraid. You might be able to watch a DVD if you use headphones but you’ll need to check with a nurse.

question: Am I going to get better?
answer: You come into hospital so that the staff can try to make you better. You can ask your doctor and nurse what they are going to do to try to make you better.

question: Do I have to see under the cast?
answer: You don’t have to see under the cast or look at anything you don’t want to. You can look away or close your eyes if you want to, it’s not a problem.

question: Will they have to put me to sleep to take my cast off?
answer: You don’t usually have to be asleep when the cast comes off. If for some reason a doctor thinks you should be they’ll talk to you before and you can ask any questions you want.

question: Will I need a drip for a blood test?
answer: You don’t usually need a drip for a blood test but if your doctor thinks you need one they’ll talk to you about it first. It’s okay to ask about it if you’re not sure.

question: What is the bell for?
answer: You get to ring the bell to celebrate when your treatment is finished.

question: When can I ring the bell?
answer: You get to ring the bell to celebrate when your treatment is finished.

question: How will I feel in hospital? Happy or sad?
answer: You may feel lots of different things when you’re in hospital. Some children feel happy because they are going to feel better after their operation. Some sad, scared, or worried. Some children feel both happy and sad at the same time. Whatever you are feeling is completely normal and it is okay to feel these things.

question: Which doctors will I see?
answer: You may see a lot of different doctors, some you have never seen and some that you have. You can ask anyone who comes to talk to you what they do and who they are.

question: I love baking. Will I be able to bake a cake while I’m in hospital?
answer: You might be able to bake a cake in hospital because some hospitals do cooking as part of play club or hospital school. Ask your play specialist if it’s possible.

question: How will I walk after the cast comes off?
answer: You might be able to walk normally straight away after having your cast taken off but you might need crutches or a wheelchair for a bit. The nurse will tell you what’s best and you can ask questions if you’re not sure.

question: Can I swap beds?
answer: You might get to change beds from time to time but I’m afraid you can’t choose. The nurses and doctors decide where you go.

question: Do you get your own room in hospital?
answer: You might get your own room in the hospital but that depends on which ward you are on and if there are any available. If you don’t have your own room you’ll be with a small number of other children who you can make friends with.

question: Will I have stitches?
answer: You might have stitches after your operation or you might have clips instead. Stitches are usually taken out after you’ve left hospital or sometimes they’ll be really cool ones that just dissolve!

question: Does internal radiation hurt?
answer: You might have to have a small operation if you’re having internal radiation but you’ll be asleep so you won’t feel anything. When you’re having it, it won’t hurt but it might make you feel tired or worn out.

question: Do you have to take your clothes off for an X-ray?
answer: You might have to take your clothes off for an X-ray but it depends on where on your body your X-ray is being taken. Like if it’s your arm and you have a t-shirt on it’s fine. You will have to take off any metal from the area being x-rayed.

question: Will I have my birthday in hospital?
answer: You might have your birthday in hospital, it depends on how your treatment is going. If you do everyone will make it as special as possible.

question: Will I need more treatment after my operation?
answer: You might need more treatment after your operation and that’s pretty normal. Ask your doctor, they should be able to tell you.

question: Do I have a needle for an MRI scan? Do I need a needle?
answer: You might need to have some special medicine which will be given to you through a cannula. The cannula involves a small needle being used for a minute on your hand or arm. You can have some cream put on you which stops you from feeling when the needle scratches.

question: How long do I have to wear the radiotherapy mask?
answer: You need to wear the radiotherapy mask while you’re having your treatment. It should be not much more than about ten minutes every day.

question: What do I do before an operation?
answer: You probably won’t be allowed to eat for a few hours before your operation and the nurses might ask you to take a quick bath. Before you go for your operation you’ll be given special socks to wear — they are long and tight and look a bit weird but it’s important to wear them.

question: Where can I get a USB cable / charger?
answer: You should really bring your own charger or USB but if you’ve forgotten ask a nurse if they can help. Also check that it’s okay to charge your device at the hospital before you plug it in.

question: What if my scar is bleeding?
answer: You should tell a nurse or doctor if your scar is bleeding and they’ll help sort it out for you.

question: Do I need money?
answer: You shouldn’t need money but your parents might do to pay for things like the TV.

question: Who will look after me?
answer: You will be looked after by lots of people at the hospital. You’ll quickly get to know some of the doctors and nurses and they’ll become like friends to you.

question: Which nurse or doctor will I meet?
answer: You will meet loads of different nurses and doctors and other staff members. You can ask everyone who comes to talk to you who they are and what their job is.

question: Does a biopsy hurt?
answer: You won’t feel a biopsy because you will be given medicine to make you sleep while it happens. You might feel a bit uncomfortable afterwards but there are medicines to help stop that.

question: Are there things to do in the ultrasound room?
answer: You won’t have much time to do anything because the scan only takes a few minutes but there are usually a few things in the ultrasound room or you can bring something with you if you want.

question: Can I have a fan?
answer: You’ll have to ask a nurse if there are any spare fans you can borrow. You might have to get your family to bring one in for you instead.

question: How many can visit in a day?
answer: You’ll have to check with a nurse, they’ll be able to let you know how many people can visit.

question: Am I allowed to watch TV in hospital?
answer: You’ll probably have a telly next to your bed. There might even be a TV room where you can chill out with your friends - ask someone who will be able to tell you.

question: Will there be a TV?
answer: You’ll probably have a telly next to your bed. There might even be a TV room where you can chill out with your friends - ask someone who will be able to tell you.

question: Can I still watch TV?
answer: You’ll probably have a telly next to your bed. There might even be a TV room where you can chill out with your friends - ask someone who will be able to tell you.

question: Can I eat or drink before my operation?
answer: You’re not usually allowed to eat or drink before an operation because it reacts with the sleeping medicine. Your doctor will let you know how long before you can’t eat or drink.

question: Will my arm work properly after my plaster cast is removed?
answer: Your arm might feel a bit weak when you have the cast taken off and could take a while before it’s as good as it used to be.

question: Do I need another cast? Can I choose the colour?
answer: Your doctor or nurse will let you know if you need another cast. You can choose which colour you’d like it to be. They have blue, red, pink, purple, orange and white.

question: Do I have to go to hospital?
answer: Your doctor will ask you to come into hospital so that they can do tests to find out what’s going on in your body, give you some medicine and make you better. Your doctor can’t do these things if you don’t come to hospital so it is best for you to come in.

question: When can I eat after my operation?
answer: Your doctors and nurses will let you know how long you have to wait before you can eat after your operation. They may ask you to have a drink first to make sure you don’t feel sick. If you are okay when you have a drink they will usually offer you some food.

question: Will I see my friends? When can my family visit?
answer: Your friends and family can come and see you while you are in hospital. Different wards have different visiting times so ask your nurse what the times are on the ward you are on.

question: Are my friends allowed to visit?
answer: Your friends can come to visit whenever you want. They need to come with an adult though. Ask your nurse what time visiting is.

question: Will my leg feel stiff when the cast comes off?
answer: Your leg might feel stiff when the cast comes off because you haven’t been using it for a while. After a few days it should feel back to normal though.

question: Can my mum stay with me at my operation?
answer: Your mum, or anyone you choose, can stay with you right up until you are asleep for your operation. They will be there when you wake up and they are also allowed to stay with you overnight while you are in hospital.

question: Do I have to stay on the ward?
answer: Your nurse will let you know if you can go off the ward. You can only leave the ward with a responsible adult. The nurse may ask you to stay on the ward if the doctor is coming to see you or if you need to rest.

question: Who will wash my clothes?
answer: Your parents should take your clothes home to wash them and bring you in clean ones.

question: Does a cancer vaccine hurt?
answer: A cancer vaccine doesn’t hurt, though the needle might feel a bit sharp and like you’re being pinched but it’s only for a few seconds and it’s not that bad.

question: What is a cannula?
answer: A cannula is a thin tube that goes in your arm or the back of your hand so that nurses and doctors can give you medicines straight into your body.

question: What is a cardiologist?
answer: A cardiologist helps people who have a problem with their heart.

question: What is a CVC?
answer: A Central line or CVC is a tube that goes into your body so doctors can give you medicines easily. CVC stands for Central Venous Catheter.

question: What is a fit?
answer: A fit is sometimes called a seizure. It is when there is a lot of electric activity in the brain at the same time and the brain sends out lots of signals to your body. Fits can make your muscles tense up and make you shake or your body go stiff, they can also make you wee or poo. You might not know that it’s happening as it can make you become unconscious.

question: Does a fungal infection hurt?
answer: A fungal infection doesn’t usually hurt, but it can be a bit itchy.

question: What is a gallbladder?
answer: A gallbladder is a small organ underneath the liver. It stores a liquid called bile which helps break down fat.

question: Does a general anaesthetic hurt?
answer: A general anaesthetic doesn’t hurt. It will either be a gas which you breathe in through a mask or a liquid which is given through a cannula in your hand. If you have a cannula it might feel a bit tingly but it’s only for a few seconds and it’s not that bad.

question: Does an anaesthetic hurt?
answer: A general anaesthetic doesn’t hurt. It will either be a gas which you breathe in through a mask or a liquid which is given through a cannula in your hand. If you have a cannula it might feel a bit tingly but it’s only for a few seconds and it’s not that bad.

question: What is a hospice?
answer: A hospice is a type of hospital that helps people when their illness can’t be cured.

question: Does a local anaesthetic hurt?
answer: A local anaesthetic stops you from feeling anything in a certain area and can be an injection, a cream, gel, spray or ointment. They don’t hurt although the injection can feel a bit sharp and like you’re being pinched but it’s only for a second.

question: What is a lumen?
answer: A lumen is a thin tube (sometimes connected to a Central line or Hickman line) which doctors and nurses give you medicine through.

question: What is a multi-disciplinary team?
answer: A multi-disciplinary team is a group of doctors, nurses and other heath and social workers who all do different things and work together to help make you better. Sometimes it’s called MDT for short.

question: What is a nuclear medicine doctor?
answer: A nuclear medicine doctor finds out how diseases work using radioactivity.

question: What is a PICC line?
answer: A PICC line is a long thin tube that goes into your arm or leg so doctors can give you medicines easily.

question: What is a radiologist?
answer: A radiologist is a doctor that uses X-ray pictures of the inside your body to work out how to look after you.

question: What is a seizure?
answer: A seizure is sometimes called a fit. It is when there is a lot of electric activity in the brain at the same time and the brain sends out lots of signals to your body. Seizures can make your muscles tense up and make you shake or your body go stiff, they can also make you wee or poo. You might not know that it’s happening as it can make you become unconscious.

question: How do the doctors keep track of my illness?
answer: All information about your illness and treatment is written down or kept on a computer system which anyone treating you can look at.

question: What is an antibiotic?
answer: An antibiotic is a type of medicine which helps fight infections caused by bacteria.

question: Does an echocardiogram hurt?
answer: An echocardiogram doesn’t hurt. The doctor will put jelly on your chest, which might be a bit chilly, and then look at your heart by touching a special probe against your chest.

question: Does an infusion hurt?
answer: An infusion doesn’t hurt while you’re having it. You will have a tiny tube attached to you to take the infusion which is put in with a needle. The needle might feel a bit sharp and like you’re being pinched but it’s only for a few seconds and it’s not that bad. If it starts to hurt tell the nurse and they will check everything is OK.

question: What is an operating department practitioner?
answer: An operating department practitioner works closely with anaethetists to look after patients when they are having operations.

question: How do the doctors keep track of my medication?
answer: Any medicine that you are given will be noted down on a special chart which anyone treating you can look at. This means that they can always see what medicine you’re taking and how it’s working out for you.

question: What is bacteria?
answer: Bacteria are tiny organisms (like cells). Most bacteria in our bodies are helpful but some are germs which can make you poorly. The bad ones can be treated with antibiotics.

question: What is a blood count?
answer: Blood count is a test that counts the number of different types of blood cells in your blood. There are three different types of blood cell — white blood cells, red blood cells and platelets.

question: What is a chromosome?
answer: Chromosomes are like tiny threads in your cells which contain information about your body. They are mostly X shaped and made up of a thing called DNA.

question: What does CRP mean?
answer: CRP is a type of blood test which checks for infections.

question: What does distal mean?
answer: Distal means something that’s the furthest away. Doctors use it to mean the end of your arm or leg that is furthest from your body.

question: What is a palliative medicine doctor?
answer: Doctors in palliative medicine make people with illnesses that can’t be cured feel better.

question: What is a heart?
answer: Everyone has a heart. It’s a pump made of muscle, about the size of your fist, which is in your chest, just to the left of the middle. One side of your heart pumps blood from your body to your lungs and the other from your lungs out to your body.

question: Does Febrile Neutropenia hurt?
answer: Febrile Neutropenia doesn’t hurt but you might feel unwell because you have a fever.
