question: Does a drip hurt?
answer: Having a drip can feel a bit like being scratched or pinched when it’s first attached to you because they use a small needle but it’s not too bad and it’s pretty quick. When the needle comes out the tube stays in place and that doesn’t hurt.

question: Does a nasogastric tube hurt?
answer: Having a nasogastric tube put in doesn’t hurt but it’s not very nice I’m afraid. There are ways to make it easier though like swallowing as the tube is put in and thinking about something else to take your mind off it. It shouldn’t take long at all and once it’s in you won’t really notice it much.

question: What standard is this hospital?
answer: Hospital standards are tested by a company called the CQC. They look at how well the hospital is doing then they give it a rating. You’ll have to ask someone from the hospital about the standard here.

question: How big is the hospital?
answer: Hospitals are massive and there’s loads of people coming and going all the time so it’s difficult to say exactly. There are hundreds of beds for children to stay here and then there are lots of others that just come in for a day or a few hours.

question: How many people are in the hospital?
answer: Hospitals are massive and there’s loads of people coming and going all the time so it’s difficult to say exactly. There are hundreds of beds for children to stay here and then there are lots of others that just come in for a day or a few hours.

question: Is a blood test for my own good?
answer: If you are coming to hospital for a blood test it is because it will help your doctor understand what is going on inside your body. The doctors and nurses would not do anything to you that they haven’t agreed with your parents.

question: Why is my chemotherapy being delayed?
answer: It’s not unusual for chemotherapy to be delayed and you shouldn’t worry. It’s often because you have a low number of white blood cells. You should ask your doctor if you want to know more.

question: What is lactulose?
answer: Lactulose is a type of medicine to help you if you’re having difficulty pooing.

question: How will the morphine make me feel?
answer: Morphine might make you feel sleepy and sometimes it might also make you feel itchy or sick.

question: What is a lung?
answer: Most people have two lungs which are in your chest. They’re really big, the one on the right is a bit bigger than the one on the left, and they allow you to breathe fresh air in, get rid of stale air and talk.

question: Do the wards have windows you can open?
answer: Most wards do not have windows that open because they have air conditioning and opening windows would waste energy.

question: What is neutropenia?
answer: Neutropenia is when you don’t have enough of a type of white blood cell called neutrophils.

question: Will the ward look like a normal GP’s?
answer: No, the ward does not look like the GP’s. A ward usually has a long corridor with rooms coming off it where the children staying in hospital sleep and rest. There is also an area where the nurses do their paperwork and a room where medicines are kept.

question: Will the ward be grey and black?
answer: No, the ward will not be grey and black. Our wards are quite colourful! A ward usually has a long corridor with rooms coming off it where the children staying in hospital sleep and rest. There is also an area where the nurses do their paperwork and a room where medicines are kept.

question: Can I feel anything when I’m asleep for my operation?
answer: No, when you are asleep you can’t feel anything. Being asleep for an operation is different from being asleep in bed at home. You are kept asleep with special medicines that make sure you don’t feel anything or hear or see anything during your operation.

question: Can I have birthday presents?
answer: Of course you can have birthday presents! If you are staying in hospital when it’s your birthday your family can bring your presents to you and spend time with you to celebrate.

question: Do petechiae hurt?
answer: Petechiae don’t hurt but you will see red spots on your skin if you have it. You might also bruise easily or have a nose bleed.

question: What is a phlebotomist?
answer: Phlebotomists take blood samples.

question: What does proximal mean?
answer: Proximal means nearest and doctors say it when they’re talking about the part of your arm or leg that is closest to your body.

question: What is serum?
answer: Serum is the liquid part of your blood.

question: What do staff nurses do?
answer: Staff nurses help out the charge nurse on a ward.

question: What are steroids?
answer: Steroids are used for lots of different thing. The doctors & nurses will explain to you why you need steroids if you are given them.

question: Do steroids hurt?
answer: Steroids don’t hurt.

question: Will I wake up again from my operation?
answer: The anaesthetist, who helps you to go to sleep, makes sure you have enough medicine to stay asleep during your operation. They have lots of training to make sure you are safe during your operation and wake up at the end.

question: What is a bladder?
answer: The bladder is a pouch where your body stores wee. When it is full you go to the toilet. The wee comes from your kidneys which makes it after filtering water and waste chemicals out of your blood.

question: How big is the needle for a blood test?
answer: The blood test needle is about the length of half of your little finger, it is a wide as a piece of thin string.

question: What do charge nurses do?
answer: The charge nurse is the nurse that’s in charge of a ward.

question: Can I have a different doctor / nurse?
answer: The doctors and nurses are the best people to help you get better and they want to help you. If you want to talk to someone about one of the doctors or nurses talk to your parents or ask another member of staff.

question: Will I get addicted to the morphine?
answer: The doctors will make sure you get just the right amount of morphine. If you need a lot to keep you comfortable they might need to reduce the dose very slowly when you are better because you may have got used to it. Ask your doctors to explain if you are worried about this.

question: What is the iliac?
answer: The iliac is part of the hip bone.

question: Can they do the thumb prick gently?
answer: The nurses try their best to do the thumb pricks as gently as they can. It will only hurt for a few seconds.

question: What is the process of having a cannula / blood test?
answer: The process for blood tests starts when you are called from the waiting room. You might have a special cream put on your skin, if you do, you’ll need to wait a while till it makes your skin numb. Next the person taking your blood will check your name and birthday then they’ll put a tight band around your arm which helps the veins come to the surface. The area will be cleaned then they’ll put the needle in and let the blood fill up the syringe. When they have enough they will remove the needle and ask you to hold a cotton wool ball on the area. Once it has stopped bleeding they may put a small plaster on it and the blood test is finished.

question: Can I have another pillow / blanket?
answer: There are usually spare pillows and blankets around, ask a nurse if they can help you.

question: What is going to happen to me at my operation? What are they going to do?
answer: When you arrive you’ll go to a waiting room until they call your name, then you’ll have your weight and height checked so they know how much medicine to give you. You’ll have your blood pressure checked with an armband and your heart beat with a peg thing on your finger. You might have some cream put on your arm so they can put the cannula on you, this is how they give you medicine to sleep during your operation. You’ll meet the person who is going to do the operation who will explain everything to you. You’ll also meet the person who makes you sleep during the operation. After everything is explained you’ll go to the room where they make you sleep, you can take someone with you so no need to worry. Next they will help you sleep with special medicine or a mask and you’ll have your operation. Later you will wake up and the person that was with you before your op will be there again. Once you’re fully awake you will go to a ward to get better.

question: Do the doctors take your teeth out or the nurses?
answer: When you come into hospital to have your teeth taken out it will be a dentist who does it. The nurses will look after you before and after your operation has finished.

question: Can cancer be cured?
answer: Yes, many types of cancer can be cured. Don’t be scared to ask your doctor questions about cancer though, they’ll be able to explain everything to you.

question: Is morphine safe?
answer: Yes, morphine is used all the time and it’s safe for children.

question: When will I wake up in the morning?
answer: You can ask a nurse who will be able to tell you when waking up time is.

question: Who do I ask for the blood test cream and how long does the cream take to work?
answer: You can ask any nurse or the person who takes your blood if you would like the cream. The cream takes up to 30 minutes to work.

question: How will I go to sleep for my operation?
answer: You can either go to sleep with a mask which goes over your mouth and nose and has a special gas in it or with a cannula in your arm through which medicine is put into you. The mask will smell a bit like felt tip pens or if you have the cannula then the medicine might make your hand or arm feel cold as it goes in. With either you will fall asleep quickly and wake up again after your operation.

question: How often can I press the PCA button?
answer: You can press the PCA button whenever you need it. If you think it is not helping enough tell your nurse as they will need to check it’s not making you too sleepy.

question: When will I go to hospital?
answer: You will come to hospital on the day of your treatment. You will get a letter in the post with the date and time you have to come in.

question: Does my mum have to wear a heavy dress for my MRI scan?
answer: You will have to ask the radiographer if they can go into the MRI scanner with you. If it’s OK they have to make sure they don’t have any metal on them, but they don’t need to wear anything special.

question: Does a bone marrow test hurt?
answer: Young people have a general anaesthetic when they have a bone marrow test so you will be asleep when it happens and you won’t feel anything. It might be a bit sore afterwards but you can have medicine to stop it from hurting.

question: How is my blood count worked out?
answer: Your blood count is worked out by a special machine in the laboratory.

question: What is a biopsy?
answer: A biopsy is when doctors take a small piece of tissue from the body and look at it under a microscope.

question: What is a blood transfusion?
answer: A blood transfusion is where blood is taken from one person and put into another person.

question: What is a brain tumour?
answer: A brain tumour is a lump in your brain. It can be benign which means it is slow growing or it can be malignant which means it grows faster and can spread to other parts of the body.

question: What is a CAT scan?
answer: A CAT scan takes lots of X-rays, from different angles, to build up a picture of the inside of the body.

question: What is a child and adolescent psychiatrist?
answer: A child and adolescent psychiatrist is a doctor who helps children understand and cope with their feelings.

question: What is a clinical oncologist?
answer: A clinical oncologist is a doctor who helps people with cancer by using radiotherapy and chemo.

question: What is a clinical trial?
answer: A clinical trial is when doctors try a new medicine out to see how well it works or what happens when people take it.

question: What is a CT scan?
answer: A CT scan takes lots of X-rays, from different angles, to build up a picture of the inside of your body.

question: What is a diagnosis?
answer: A diagnosis is when doctors work out what illness someone has.

question: What is a district nurse?
answer: A district nurse is a nurse who comes to your home to help you.

question: How is womb cancer diagnosed?
answer: A doctor will check the woman’s womb and ovaries and then might ask her to see a specialist doctor who will have a closer look with a camera on a tube or do an ultrasound scan. They might also take a small piece of the area they’re looking at to test for cancer.

question: How is acute myeloid leukaemia diagnosed?
answer: A doctor will diagnose acute myeloid leukaemia by checking for bruises or spots of blood under the skin then they’ll do some tests like blood tests or bone marrow tests.

question: What is a donor?
answer: A donor is a person who gives someone else something from their body. It’s usually blood but can also be organs like a kidney.

question: Does an Ewing Sarcoma hurt?
answer: An Ewing Sarcoma can feel like an ache in a bone or joint and sometimes there’s a swelling or lump which can hurt to touch.

question: What is a follow-up?
answer: A follow-up is a meeting with your doctor after an operation when they’ll tell you how it went and what needs doing next.

question: What is a frozen section?
answer: A frozen section is where doctors take out a tiny little bit of the affected area of your body. They then freeze it so they can look at it under a microscope.

question: What is a graft?
answer: A graft is where doctors take a healthy part of your body and use it to replace an unhealthy part.

question: What is a high intensity therapist?
answer: A high intensity therapist looks after people who are upset or sad.

question: What is a key worker?
answer: A key worker is a nurse who will help you understand everything that happens at the hospital.

question: What is a Linac machine?
answer: A Linac machine is what is used to give people radiotherapy. It’s a big machine that gives out energy rays which kill cancer cells.

question: What is a localised cancer?
answer: A localised cancer is one that hasn’t spread to other parts of the body.

question: What’s a lumbar puncture?
answer: A lumbar puncture is when doctors do some tests on you by taking some fluid from your back with a needle.

question: Does melanoma hurt?
answer: A melanoma doesn’t usually hurt although it may be itchy and feel a bit rough, hard or lumpy.

question: What is a monoclonal antibody?
answer: A monoclonal antibody is something that is made by scientists in a lab and it helps fight infections in your body.

question: What is a plastic surgeon?
answer: A plastic surgeon is a doctor that does operations to improve the way someone looks.

question: What is pre-assessment?
answer: A pre-assessment is a quick meeting with a nurse before you have your op. They’ll check things like your blood pressure or what tablets you are taking.

question: What does prognosis mean?
answer: A prognosis is what doctors think will happen to you when you’re poorly.

question: What is a randomised clinical trial?
answer: A randomised clinical trial is when new medicines are tested to see how well they work and the people being tested are split into two groups.

question: What is a regimen?
answer: A regimen is the plan that says which medicines to use to make you better.

question: What does sarcoma feel like?
answer: A sarcoma feels different depending on where it is. If it’s on a bone it can make it ache or make the joint stiff, if it’s in another part of the body it can just feel like a lump which doesn’t really hurt. If the lump grows though it can push against other things near it which can be uncomfortable.

question: How is sarcoma diagnosed?
answer: A sarcoma is diagnosed by testing some of the cells in the lump as well as doing scans like MRI, CT or an ultrasound.

question: What is a second opinion?
answer: A second opinion is when you ask another doctor about your illness.

question: Does a graft hurt?
answer: A skin graft can be uncomfortable, especially if you bang it but it doesn’t really hurt. If you’re having a bone graft you will be asleep when it happens so you won’t feel anything. For both you will have medicine to stop it from hurting afterwards.

question: Does a sarcoma hurt?
answer: A soft tissue sarcoma doesn’t usually hurt but as it gets bigger it might start to put pressure on other parts of your body which you can feel. A bone sarcoma can make your bone ache especially at night.

question: How is a soft tissue sarcoma diagnosed?
answer: A soft tissue sarcoma is diagnosed by taking a small part of the lump to look at under a microscope.

question: What is a stem cell harvest?
answer: A stem cell harvest is when doctors take stem cells from someone and store them for a later date.

question: Does a stem cell transplant hurt?
answer: A stem cell transplant doesn’t hurt. It’s a bit like having a blood transfusion.

question: What is a stem cell transplant?
answer: A stem cell transplant is when doctors use stem cells to replace blood cells that have been destroyed by chemo.

question: What does symptom mean?
answer: A symptom is a feeling or a change in your body that shows that you are poorly.

question: What is a therapeutic radiographer?
answer: A therapeutic radiographer is someone who treats tumours and cancer with radiation.

question: Does a transfusion hurt?
answer: A transfusion doesn’t hurt. You might feel a sharp scratch and a pinch when the needle goes in but it’s very quick.

question: What is a treatment cycle?
answer: A treatment cycle is the time it takes to have treatment then rest afterwards before your next session.

question: What is a tumour?
answer: A tumour is a growth or lump inside your body that shouldn’t really be there.

question: What is a tumour marker?
answer: A tumour marker is something a tumour makes and its found in the blood. It can help doctors understand what the tumour is doing.

question: What is a vaccine?
answer: A vaccine is a medicine which helps give your body a boost against illness, germs or infections.

question: How many people get cancer?
answer: About half of all people get cancer at some point in their life though doctors are getting better at treating it every year.

question: How common is cancer?
answer: About half the people in the UK will get some kind of cancer during their life. There are more than 200 types of cancer though which are all different, some are easier to treat than others.

question: What does acute myeloid leukaemia feel like?
answer: Acute myeloid leukaemia can feel a bit like having flu. It makes you tired, you can get a fever and you might lose your appetite.

question: What is acute myeloid leukaemia?
answer: Acute myeloid leukaemia is a type of cancer which starts in your bone marrow, the spongy stuff that’s inside your bones, and affects your white blood cells.

question: How is acute myeloid leukaemia treated?
answer: Acute myeloid leukaemia can be treated in a number of ways including chemotherapy, radiotherapy and by having a stem cell transplant.

question: Does adrenal cancer hurt?
answer: Adrenal cancer doesn’t really hurt though you might get a tummy ache from it.

question: What is adrenal cancer?
answer: Adrenal cancer is a very rare type of cancer that affects your adrenal glands which are just above your kidneys. It normally forms a lump called a tumour.

question: What is going to happen after the procedure?
answer: After you’ve had your op you will be taken to a room called recovery where you wake up. You can choose one person to be there with you. Once you are awake you will be taken to a ward to get better. How long you are in hospital for depends on what operation you’ve had.

question: What does the medicine taste like?
answer: All medicines taste different. Some taste nice and others don’t taste very nice. You can ask your nurse what the medicine will taste like before they give it to you.

question: Why have I got cancer?
answer: All sorts of people get poorly, it’s nobody’s fault. Just try to focus on getting better.

question: Why have I got it?
answer: All sorts of people get poorly, it’s nobody’s fault. Just try to focus on getting better.

question: Why me?
answer: All sorts of people get poorly, it’s nobody’s fault. Just try to focus on getting better.

question: What is neuroblastoma?
answer: Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer which starts in early nerve cells called neuroblasts. When someone has neuroblastoma, it means their nerve cells are making mistakes and are growing too quickly, creating 'sick cells' in the body. When there are too many sick cells in your body, they make lumps and bumps called tumors. The tumors can hurt and make you sick which is why it's important to receive medicine and treatment to get rid of them.

question: Is it my fault I have cancer?
answer: It is not your fault that you have cancer. Nothing you did caused your cancer.

question: How will my port be accessed? Or How will I get medicine through my port?
answer: Before you go to the hospital, your caregiver will put some special numbing cream on your port. When it is time to have your port accessed, everyone in the room will put on a mask. The nurse will remove the numbing cream with a soft cloth, or you can do this yourself. They will then clean the port area with swabs that look like large q-tips. Once the area is cleaned and has dried, the nurse will feel the port with their fingers so they know exactly where it is. Then they will place a small needle with tubing into the port. Because you have the cream on, you should only feel pressure, or like someone is pushing on the port. The nurse will then place a dressing over the port tubing to keep it in place.

question: Will the treatment make me better?
answer: All treatments are designed to make you better and the doctors are experts at using them.

question: What is Allopurinol?
answer: Allopurinol is a type of medicine that protects your kidneys while you’re having chemo.

question: Does amputation hurt?
answer: Amputation is a very complicated operation which happens when the person is asleep. They won’t feel anything while it’s happening but it might hurt a bit afterwards. Doctors have special medicines to help stop it from hurting.

question: What is an emergency medical dispatcher?
answer: An emergency medical dispatcher takes phone calls from people when there’s an emergency and make sure the ambulance gets to them as quickly as possible.

question: What is an acute internal medicine doctor?
answer: An acute internal medicine doctor looks after people who have a sudden serious illness.

question: What does allogeneic mean?
answer: An allogeneic stem cell transplant is when stem cells are taken from one person and given to someone else.

question: What is an ambulance care assistant?
answer: An ambulance care assistant drives you to and from hospital and looks after you in an ambulance.

question: Does an Askin tumour hurt?
answer: An Askin tumour can make breathing feel a bit difficult and it can hurt a bit in the chest area. Anyone with this will be given special medicine to stop it hurting.

question: What is an Askin tumour?
answer: An Askin tumour is a type of lump which starts in the chest.

question: What does Askin tumour feel like?
answer: An Askin tumour feels like a pain or stiffness in your chest.

question: What is an audiogram?
answer: An audiogram is a simple hearing test. It doesn’t hurt at all, bonus!

question: What is an audiovestibular doctor?
answer: An audiovestibular doctor looks after your hearing and sense of balance.

question: What does autologous mean?
answer: An autologous stem cell transplant means when doctors take some stem cells from you, store them in a fridge and then give them back to you when you need them later.

question: What is an infusion?
answer: An infusion is when medicines, blood or other fluids are given to you through a tube very slowly.

question: What is an injection?
answer: An injection is when medicine is given to you using a needle and syringe.

question: What is an intellectual disability psychiatrist?
answer: An intellectual disability psychiatrist helps people with learning disabilities understand their feelings.

question: What is an investigation?
answer: An investigation is when doctors do tests to find out how your treatment is going.

question: What if I need an IV?
answer: An IV is a little plastic tube that goes into your hand and is attached to a bag of special water.

question: What does the ultrasound machine look like?
answer: An ultrasound machine looks like a computer which can be wheeled about. It has a keyboard and also probes attached to it that look like microphones. At the end of the probes there is a grey bit which they roll on your skin.

question: How long will my ultrasound take?
answer: An ultrasound scan usually takes around 10 minutes. You may have to wait in the waiting area for a short while before which can be a bit boring so bring something to do with you.

question: What does the X-ray camera look like?
answer: An X-ray camera looks like a tube with a big light bulb in it.

question: What’s an X-ray?
answer: An X-ray uses special energy and light to take a photograph of your insides.

question: How is appendix cancer diagnosed?
answer: Appendix cancer is diagnosed by the doctor examining your tummy, then by a biopsy which is when they test a bit of the lump to see if it’s cancer or not. They might also scan you with an MRI, CT or ultrasound scanner to get a picture of your insides.

question: Does appendix cancer hurt?
answer: Appendix cancer sometimes gives you tummy ache and can make you feel sick.

question: How is appendix cancer treated?
answer: Appendix cancer usually grows quite slowly so often an operation to remove it will be enough. Sometimes though you might have some chemotherapy afterwards to kill off any remaining cancer cells.

question: How long will I need to wait for my appointment?
answer: Appointment waiting times are all different, it depends on what the doctors are looking for. It could be a week or two but sometimes it can take longer. Ask your doctor if they can give you an idea.

question: What is aspiration?
answer: Aspiration just means taking liquid from your body with a needle.

question: What does pancreatic cancer feel like?
answer: At first people don’t usually feel pancreatic cancer but when they do it feels like tummy ache or a pain in your back which comes and goes and is worse when you lie down or after food.

question: What should I expect during my first appointment?
answer: At your first appointment you’ll find out what tests the doctors need to do and what sort of treatment you’re going to get.

question: What does spinal cancer feel like?
answer: Because the lumps can press on the nerves in your back, spinal cancer can give you back ache, neck ache, numbness or tingling in your arms and legs.

question: How is bladder cancer diagnosed?
answer: Bladder cancer can be diagnosed first through a check up with your doctor where they’ll check for lumps, then if they think you need it, you’ll have hospital tests. These might include popping a camera into your bladder to look around, a CT scan or an MRI scan.

question: How is bladder cancer treated?
answer: Bladder cancer is treated differently depending on when it is found. There will usually be an operation to remove any lumps as well as some chemotherapy when medicine is put directly into your bladder for an hour at a time. Sometimes radiotherapy will be used too.

question: What is bladder cancer?
answer: Bladder cancer is when there’s a growth or lump in the lining of your bladder. The bladder is where your wee is stored before you go for a wee.

question: Does bone cancer hurt?
answer: Bone cancer can feel like an ache and sometimes it’s a bit sore to touch that part of your body. It may also make it awkward to move the part of your body it’s in, especially if it’s near a joint like your knee, hip or elbow.

question: What is bone cancer?
answer: Bone cancer is a rare type of cancer that starts in your bone.

question: How is bone cancer diagnosed?
answer: Bone cancer is diagnosed first by having a scan which takes pictures of the inside of your body then the doctors will do a test on a small piece of your bone.

question: How is bone marrow cancer treated?
answer: Bone marrow cancer can be treated in different ways. They can include chemotherapy usually as a tablet; steroid tablets, other types of tablet or injections, or a stem cell transplant.

question: What does bone marrow cancer feel like?
answer: Bone marrow cancer can feel like a dull ache in your bones, it can make you feel tired and worn out and sometimes it can make your bone easier to break.

question: Does bone marrow cancer hurt?
answer: Bone marrow cancer doesn’t really hurt but it can feel like a dull ache in the bone where it is which you notice more when you move. It can make you feel tired too.

question: What is bone marrow cancer?
answer: Bone marrow cancer is also known as myeloma and it affects the spongy stuff that’s inside your bones.

question: How is bone marrow cancer diagnosed?
answer: Bone marrow cancer is identified with scans including MRI, CT and X-rays. Doctors will also test some of your bone marrow which they will take with a needle. Don’t worry though, you won’t feel a thing.

question: What does bowel cancer feel like?
answer: Bowel cancer can feel like tummy ache and sometimes like you’re full up. It can also make you feel like you need the toilet more often.

question: Does bowel cancer hurt?
answer: Bowel cancer can make you feel like you have a tummy ache. It can also make you go to the toilet a lot and other times can make it difficult to go for a poo which can be uncomfortable.

question: What is bowel cancer?
answer: Bowel cancer is a type of cancer that usually happens only to older people. It’s sometimes known as colon cancer or rectal cancer or colorectal cancer, depending on where it is found.

question: How is bowel cancer diagnosed?
answer: Bowel cancer is diagnosed with a few tests. First your GP will check up your bottom for any lumps and they’ll also feel your tummy. You will also have a blood test. If they think it’s needed you will then have a small camera on a tube put up your botttom so they can have a proper look. It’s a bit awkward and you might feel embarrassed about it but try not to worry, it’s pretty quick and the doctor will look after you really well. Another thing that might happen is you might have a CT scan so the doctors can get a picture of what your insides look like.

question: What is brain cancer?
answer: Brain cancer is when cells in your brain change when they’re dividing and don’t do what they’re supposed to. They then begin to form a lump and that can be cancerous.

question: Does brain cancer hurt?
answer: Brain cancer itself doesn’t hurt because you don’t feel pain in your brain but what can happen is that as the lump grows it can put pressure on other things in your head like blood vessels or nerves. This can cause a dull headache or a feeling of throbbing.

question: What is breast cancer?
answer: Breast cancer is the most common type of cancer in the UK. Most people who get it are women over the age of 50 but you can get it at a younger age and men can get it too, though that’s quite rare.

question: What does breast cancer feel like?
answer: Breast cancer is when a lump is found in a woman’s breast and it turns out to be cancerous. It doesn’t usually hurt but the lump feels hard when it’s pressed on. Sometimes the skin on the breast becomes thick and sometimes there’s a rash too.

question: What is cancer?
answer: Cancer is a word for lots of different diseases caused by cells not behaving normally.

question: How many children get cancer?
answer: Cancer is pretty rare in children. About one child in every 500 will get cancer by the age of fourteen. Another way to look at it is that only one percent of all people with cancer is a child which is a pretty small number really.

question: Does womb cancer hurt?
answer: Cancer of the womb can sometimes cause some pain in the tummy but it’s unusual for that to happen.

question: What is womb cancer?
answer: Cancer of the womb is also known as uterine cancer or endometrial cancer and it mostly affects women who have passed the age they can have children.

question: What does womb cancer feel like?
answer: Cancer of the womb is usually noticed because there is some bleeding which shouldn’t be happening. Sometimes there can be some pain in the tummy but that’s quite unusual.

question: What is CAR-T therapy?
answer: CAR-T therapy is a treatment where doctors take some T cells from your blood and change them to make them kill cancer cells.

question: How will be Carboplatin make me feel?
answer: Carboplatin might make you feel tired or sick, sometimes it can make your hands and feet feel tingly.

question: How is carcinoma treated?
answer: Carcinoma can be treated by having a little operation to remove it, it can also be frozen or sometimes creams can be used.

question: What does carcinoma feel like?
answer: Carcinoma can feel like rough skin and it can be itchy or sometimes bleed.

question: What is a carcinoma?
answer: Carcinoma is a type of cancer that starts in the skin and is sometimes in organs like the liver or kidney.

question: How is carcinoma diagnosed?
answer: Carcinoma is diagnosed by removing the lump from your skin then looking at it under a microscope.

question: Will a CAT scan be scary?
answer: CAT scans aren’t scary. It’s like a big metal doughnut with a bed in the middle of it. There’s nothing to worry about and you can take someone with you so you’re not on your own.

question: What is chemotherapy?
answer: Chemotherapy is a type of medicine which is used to treat cancer.

question: What is chemo made of?
answer: Chemotherapy, or chemo for short, is the name used for loads of types of medicine which kill cancer. Some are made from plants, some are antibiotics, and some are made from metals and other things. They are all designed to stop cancer cells from growing and help you get better.

question: What is Cisplatin?
answer: Cisplatin is a type of medicine used to treat bone cancer.

question: How is CNS cancer diagnosed?
answer: CNS cancer is diagnosed by having pictures taken of your insides with a big machine called a scanner. It doesn’t hurt so there’s nothing to worry about.

question: What is CNS cancer?
answer: CNS cancer is when your brain and spine grow extra cells which turn into a lump called a tumour. CNS stands for Central Nervous System.

question: What does colon cancer feel like?
answer: Colon cancer can feel like a tummy ache and sometimes like you’re full up. It can also make you feel like you need the toilet more often.

question: Does colon cancer hurt?
answer: Colon cancer can make you feel like you have a tummy ache. It can also make you go to the toilet a lot and other times it can make it difficult to go for a poo which can be uncomfortable.

question: What is colon cancer?
answer: Colon cancer is a type of cancer that usually happens only to older people. It’s sometimes known as colorectal cancer or rectal cancer or bowel cancer, depending on where it is found.

question: How is colon cancer diagnosed?

question: What does colorectal cancer feel like?

question: Does colorectal cancer hurt?
answer: Colorectal cancer can make you feel like you have a tummy ache. It can also make you go to the toilet a lot and other times it can make it difficult to go for a poo which can be uncomfortable.

question: What is complementary and alternative medicine?
answer: Complementary and alternative medicines are ways of looking after people that don’t involve normal medicine or operations.

question: What is cryopreservation?
answer: Cryopreservation is when doctors save some of your cells and keep them at a really low temperature so they can use them again in the future.

question: Will a CT scan be scary?
answer: CT scans aren’t scary. It’s like a big metal doughnut with a bed in the middle of it. There’s nothing to worry about and you can take someone with you so you’re not on your own.

question: What is cyclophosphamide?
answer: Cyclophosphamide is a medicine which slows down cancer in bones.

question: What is Daunorubicin?
answer: Daunorubicin is a medicine used to treat leukaemia and some other types of cancer too.

question: Does CNS cancer hurt?

question: What is Dexamethasone?
answer: Dexamethasone is a medicine which stops the side effects of chemo.

question: Will the medicine hurt?

question: Will I be here all day?

question: How long will it take?

question: What food is good for energy?

question: Why do I need a bone marrow test?
answer: Doctors can tell all sorts of things about your blood from a bone marrow test.

question: How is gastrointestinal cancer diagnosed?

question: How is Askin tumour diagnosed?

question: How is Ewing Sarcoma diagnosed?
answer: Doctors find Ewing Sarcoma with X-rays and MRI scans.

question: What is a general internal medicine doctor?

question: How is brain tumour treated?

question: How is brain cancer treated?

question: What is a donor carer?
answer: Donor carers look after blood donors when they go to the clinic.

question: What is Doxorubicin?

question: How long does the Linac machine last?

question: Is it good to eat fatty foods or bad?

question: What is Epirubicin?

question: What is Etoposide?

question: Will I get well?

question: Will anything go wrong?
answer: Everyone at the hospital has done a lot of training to make sure all the children in their care are safe and nothing goes wrong. If you are worried you should ask your doctor or nurse to explain what they are doing and if anything could go wrong.

question: How would you react to the treatment I am going to receive?
answer: Everyone reacts slightly differently to different treatments so it’s difficult to say how I would react.

question: How long will my therapy last for?
answer: Everyone’s therapy is different and unique to them. The length of time it takes can change as it goes on depending on how well it works so you’ll have to check with your doctor about that.

question: What does Ewing Sarcoma feel like?
answer: Ewing Sarcoma feels like a pain or stiffness in the area that it’s found in.

question: What is Ewing Sarcoma?

question: What is external radiation?
answer: External radiation is a type of radiotherapy which comes from a big machine.

question: What food is good for vitamins?
answer: Fruit and vegetables are full of vitamins and minerals. They also have lots of fibre which is very filling.

question: What is gastrointestinal cancer?
answer: Gastrointestinal cancer is the name given to a number of different cancers which affect the organs which help you digest food. They include the stomach, the throat, the bowel and the pancreas.

question: Does gastrointestinal cancer hurt?
answer: Gastrointestinal cancer can be in a few different places so it’s difficult to say whether or not it will hurt. It might be that you have a tummy ache or a sore throat or maybe heartburn.

question: What does grade mean?
answer: Grade is a way of telling doctors what a lump or growth in the body is doing.

question: What is Graft Versus Host Disease?
answer: Graft Versus Host Disease is when someone has donated bone marrow or stem cells to you and it doesn’t quite work properly.

question: What is haematology?
answer: Haematology is when doctors study blood.

question: What will a CAT scan feel like?
answer: Having a CAT scan is just like lying down on a bed which can move. The machine makes a sound but it won’t hurt you.

question: What will a CT scan feel like?
answer: Having a CT scan is just like lying down on a bed which can move. The machine doesn’t make much noise and it won’t hurt you.

question: What does a feeding tube feel like?
answer: Having a feeding tube doesn’t hurt but it’s not a very nice experience when you have it put in. Don’t worry though, if you need one it only takes a minute to put it in.

question: Does a pump hurt?
answer: Having a pump doesn’t hurt. It depends on what kind of pump you’re having as to what to expect. If you’re having an infusion, the pump is attached to a tube which goes into your arm. When the tube is being attached they use a small needle so it might feel like a scratch or a pinch for a few seconds. If you’re having a morphine pump, sometimes called an intrathecal pump, you will have an operation and you will be asleep so you won’t feel anything.

question: Does a urinary catheter hurt?
answer: Having a urinary catheter put in can be a bit uncomfortable but it’s quite a quick job and it shouldn’t actually hurt. Once it’s in place you will get used to it being there in no time.

question: What will my MRI scan feel like?
answer: Having an MRI scan is just like lying on a bed. It’s a bit cramped but you’re not in there for long so don’t worry.

question: Why are you not as active during treatment?
answer: Having treatment can be tiring for a number of reasons which can make you less active. It’s normal though and not a problem if you need to rest more.

question: What is head and neck cancer?
answer: Head and neck cancer is the name given to a group of cancers which affect places like the mouth and lips, your voicebox, throat, salivary glands, nose and sinuses and the area at the back of your nose and mouth.

question: What does hereditary cancer mean?
answer: Hereditary cancer is one that has passed down through the family from a parent to their children.

question: What does Hodgkin lymphoma feel like?
answer: Hodgkin lymphoma can make the glands in your neck or the top of your legs swell up a bit and ache. You might also lose weight, feel itchy and sweat more at night.

question: What is Hodgkin lymphoma?
answer: Hodgkin lymphoma is a cancer which starts in glands around your body called lymph nodes.

question: How is Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosed?
answer: Hodgkin lymphoma is diagnosed by a doctor looking at a small part of one of your glands under a microscope.

question: What is hormone therapy?
answer: Hormone therapy is a way of treating cancer which changes the way your body reacts to it.

question: What is the cancer registry?
answer: Hospitals share information about people with cancer with other hospitals so they can get an idea of what is happening across the whole country and it’s known as the cancer registry.

question: How is breast cancer treated?
answer: How breast cancer is treated all depends on when it is found. It might need an operation to remove a lump, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, biological therapy, hormone therapy or more than one of these. The doctors will be able to say which one is best.

question: How long will I have to wait?
answer: How long you wait depends on why you’re there. They’ll tell you if it’s going to be a long wait but just in case, bring something from home to do to stop you being bored.

question: How long will I be in hospital?
answer: How long you will be in hospital depends on why you have come into hospital. Your doctor and nurse will be able to tell you how long they think you will be in hospital for.

question: How often will I have to come for treatment?
answer: How often you come for treatment depends on what you’re having. Sometimes it’s every day sometimes it’s not as often. Ask your doctor and they will explain everything.

question: How often will I have my treatment?
answer: How often you have treatment is different for everyone so you’ll have to check with your doctor.

question: How often will I need to see the doctor?
answer: How often you see a doctor depends on what is wrong. You will have to see doctors as often as it takes to make sure you’re better.

question: What’s on the food menu today?
answer: I’m afraid I don’t know what’s on the food menu today but if you ask a nurse they’ll be able to tell you.

question: Can my dog still lick my face?
answer: I’m afraid not. You shouldn’t let your dog lick you if you’re having treatment, especially on the face or if you have any cuts or scars.

question: What is Idarubicin?
answer: Idarubicin is a medicine used to treat leukaemia and some other types of cancer too.

question: What does malignant mean?
answer: If a lump is malignant it means it has cancer in it and can move around to other parts of the body.

question: What is recurrent cancer?
answer: If cancer is recurrent it means it comes back again after treatment has ended.

question: What is relapsed cancer?
answer: If cancer is relapsed it means it has come back again after treatment has ended.

question: What does sporadic cancer mean?
answer: If cancer is sporadic it means that it has just happened and it’s not been passed through the family.

question: What does genetic mean?
answer: If something is genetic it has been inherited from your family.

question: Does a PNET hurt?
answer: If the PNET is in the brain it can sometimes give you headaches or make you have seizures or fits. It can make you feel sick or weak too. If it’s in a bone then it can feel like an ache and it might be tender when you touch that area.

question: What happens if I don’t like the food they give me in hospital?
answer: If you don’t fancy your hospital food when it comes, ask if you can swap it for something else. Your family can bring some tinned or packet foods that you like into hospital as well.

question: What if I forget to take a tablet at home?
answer: If you forget to take a tablet you should ask your doctor what to do. Don’t take extra tablets though, that can be bad for you.

question: Does a lumen hurt?
answer: If you have a lumen it will be attached to a Hickman line or a Wiggly, it doesn’t hurt.

question: What does the melanoma treatment feel like?
answer: If you have a melanoma you’ll have a small operation to take it away and then be given some medicine to stop it hurting afterwards. You might have a little scar from the op but they fade away eventually.

question: Does a PEG hurt?
answer: If you have a PEG tube put in, you will be asleep when it happens so you won’t feel anything. It might feel a bit uncomfortable right afterwards but there are medicines which can help with that so just ask.

question: Does a PICC line hurt?
answer: If you have a PICC line, it will be attached when you are asleep so you won’t feel anything. Once it’s in it doesn’t hurt and you won’t really notice it.

question: Does a portacath hurt?
answer: If you have a portacath put in, you will be asleep when it happens so you won’t feel a thing. You might have some bruises afterwards and it may be a little uncomfortable for a bit but it won’t last long and you can have medicine to help if you want.

question: Does a resection hurt?
answer: If you have a resection, you will be asleep when it happens so you won’t feel a thing. Afterwards you will be given medicine to stop it hurting.

question: Does an autograft hurt?
answer: If you have an autograft, you will be asleep when it happens so you won’t feel anything. You might feel a bit uncomfortable afterwards but there are medicines to help stop that.

question: Will I be radioactive after radiotherapy?
answer: If you have external radiotherapy, you will not be radioactive after your treatment but if you have internal radiotherapy you will be while it’s happening.

question: Will I need medicine for leukaemia?
answer: If you have leukaemia the doctors will give you some chemotherapy medicine which will help fix it.

question: How is liver cancer treated?
answer: If you have liver cancer the doctors will give you some medicine called chemotherapy that helps to shrink the cancer. After that you might need to have an operation to take away what’s left. It’s different for everyone though so ask your doctor.

question: Will I need medicine or treatment for thyroid cancer?
answer: If you have thyroid cancer you’ll proably have some radiotherapy or an operation to take it away. Ask your doctor - they will be able to tell you.

question: What does thyroid cancer feel like?
answer: If you have thyroid cancer you might have a lump on your neck which slowly gets bigger over time. It doesn’t usually hurt though.

question: Does total parenteral nutrition hurt?
answer: If you have total parenteral nutrition, or TPN for short, you will be asleep when it is put in so you won’t feel anything. Afterwards it might take a bit of time to get used to but it won’t hurt.

question: Will you have to do a CAT scan again?

question: Will you have to do a CT scan again?
answer: If you move and the picture is blurry you’ll have to have the scan again so it’s important to stay as still as possible when you have it.

question: What if I move a bit? Will I have to get the X-ray done again?
answer: If you move when you’re having your X-ray you might have to have it done again so you must try to stay really still. It only takes a few seconds.

question: What will the blood do at my blood transfusion?
answer: If you need to have a blood transfusion, the blood will go into your veins and mix with your own blood. The new blood will have special things in it that will give your body what it needs and help you feel better.

question: What can I eat to help me put on weight and is healthy?
answer: If you want to put on weight and stay healthy, you could try dairy foods like milk, cheese or yogurt. They’re good for you.

question: How is oral cancer diagnosed?
answer: If your doctor or dentist thinks you might have mouth cancer they will check for sores in your mouth and then get you checked at the hospital. The doctor there will take a very small sample of the sore to check in a laboratory and if it shows that there is cancer you will then have a scan to see what stage it’s at.

question: How is pancreatic cancer diagnosed?
answer: If your GP thinks you might have pancreatic cancer they will check your tummy for a lump or see if your liver is swollen. They will also check your eyes and skin for any colour changes and may ask for a blood test or some wee to test. If your GP thinks it’s needed they will send you to hospital for a scan. This will be an ultrasound, MRI, CT or PET scan. They might also pop a camera inside you to get a better look.

question: Will I need medicine and treatment for the melanoma?
answer: If your mole has cancer in it you might need a little operation and there’s a possibility you might need some chemo or radiotherapy.

question: My skin is really sore and itchy where I had my radiotherapy. What can I do?

question: What is Ifosfamide?

question: What is an imaging support worker?
answer: Imaging support workers help out when you’re having an X-ray.

question: What is immunotherapy?
answer: Immunotherapy is a type of treatment for cancer which helps your own body fight against it better.

question: What will the ultrasound room look like? / What colour are the walls?
answer: In the ultrasound room there is a bed to lie on while you have your scan. This has paper on it to make sure it is clean between patients. There are a few chairs, one for the person who does your scan, and one for who you have chosen to come with you.

question: What is Intrathecal methotrexate?
answer: Intrathecal methotrexate is a type of chemo used to treat leukaemia.

question: What does intravenous mean?
answer: Intravenous is when medicine is given straight into your body through a tube.

question: What does remission mean?
answer: It means the doctors can’t see any signs of your illness any more.

question: Will the ultrasound be quiet?

question: Can my friend / parent / sibling sit on my bed?

question: What does leukaemia feel like?

question: What will happen to me?

question: How many children are waiting before me?

question: Will I get ill again after the CNS cancer has been treated?

question: Will I get ill again after the bone cancer has been treated?

question: Can I eat chocolate?
answer: It’s ok to eat chocolate but it’s important to try and eat healthy food too, like fruit and vegetables.

question: Am I allowed to eat sweets?

question: What if I’m misdiagnosed?

question: How long will my treatment take?

question: What does kidney cancer feel like?

question: Does kidney cancer hurt?

question: What is kidney cancer?

question: How is kidney cancer diagnosed?

question: How is kidney cancer treated?

question: What is laser therapy?
answer: Laser therapy uses very strong light to treat or kill cancer cells.

question: What are late effects?

question: Do late effects hurt?

question: What is leukaemia?

question: How is leukaemia diagnosed?

question: What is a liaison psychiatrist?

question: Does liver cancer hurt?

question: What is liver cancer?

question: How is liver cancer diagnosed?

question: What does liver cancer feel like?

question: How did I get cancer?
answer: Lots of people get cancer, it’s nobody’s fault and it’s pretty common. It can seem unfair but the truth is that cancer can just happen.

question: Does lung cancer hurt?
answer: Lung cancer can hurt when you cough or take deep breaths and it might also make you feel tired or weak.

question: How is lung cancer diagnosed?

question: What is lung cancer?
answer: Lung cancer is when there is unusual cell growth in one or both of the lungs and lumps form.

question: What are lymph nodes?

question: Does lymphoma hurt?

question: What is lymphoma?

question: What is medical microbiology and virology?

question: What is a melanoma?

question: What does melanoma feel like?

question: What is Mesna?

question: What is a metabolic medicine doctor?

question: Why can’t I wear zips for an X-ray?

question: What does metastasis mean?

question: What is Methotrexate?

question: What is Metoclopramide?

question: Does breast cancer hurt?

question: How is osteosarcoma treated?

question: What is a neoplasm?

question: Will it be sore from my CT scan?

question: What causes liver cancer?
answer: Nobody knows what causes liver cancer I’m afraid, it can just happen.

question: Why do you get chemo brain?

question: Will anything bad happen at my X-ray?
answer: Nothing bad will happen when you have your X-ray. The doctors are experts at how to do it and know just how to keep you safe.

question: What is oesophageal cancer?

question: Why do I have to stay in hospital when I don’t feel ill?

question: Does oral cancer hurt?

question: What is oral cancer?

question: What does oral cancer feel like?

question: What is an orthotist?
answer: Orthotists help you if you have problems with nerves, muscles or bones.

question: Does osteosarcoma hurt?
answer: Osteosarcoma can make your bones or joints ache or be painful.

question: What is osteosarcoma?

question: What does osteosarcoma feel like?
answer: Osteosarcoma makes your bones or joints ache and hurt.

question: What are the side effects of Paclitaxel (PTX)?

question: What does paediatric mean?
answer: Paediatric means medicine and treatment which is to do with babies and children.

question: Does pancreatic cancer hurt?
answer: Pancreatic cancer feels like a tummy ache or back pain.

question: How is pancreatic cancer treated?

question: What is pancreatic cancer?
answer: Pancreatic cancer usually only affects people aged 50-80 years old. The pancreas is part of your digestive system and is just underneath your liver.

question: What is pathology?
answer: Pathology is a way for doctors to understand how diseases work.

question: Why do I need to go to hospital?

question: Why am I in hospital?
answer: People go to hospital to understand why they’re poorly and to get better. Hospitals treat all sorts of people for lots of different things.

question: How is Askin tumour treated?
answer: People with an Askin tumour are treated with chemotherapy.

question: How is Ewing Sarcoma treated?
answer: People with Ewing Sarcoma are treated with chemotherapy and sometimes they have an operation too.

question: What are peripheral blood stem cells?
answer: Peripheral blood stem cells make blood cells and they’re found in your blood stream.

question: Why are the physiotherapist visits so important?
answer: Physiotherapist visits are important for a number of reasons. Physiotherapy can help stop tiredness and swelling, it can even slow down cancer and help stop it coming back in the future. Also it can help you get used to doing everyday things again and make you feel better about yourself.

question: What is a physiotherapy assistant?
answer: Physiotherapy assistants help you keep to your exercise plan.

question: What are platelets?
answer: Platelets are tiny cells in your blood which form a scab when you cut yourself and stop you from bleeding.

question: What is PNET?
answer: PNET is a group of cancers which can be found in the bone or the brain.

question: What is primary cancer?
answer: Primary cancer is the place where the cancer first starts in the body.

question: What does prostate cancer feel like?
answer: Prostate cancer can take a long time to appear and when you eventually notice something it’s usually because you need to wee a lot more than usual and sometimes it’s difficult to wee too.

question: Does prostate cancer hurt?
answer: Prostate cancer doesn’t really hurt but it can be uncomfortable and annoying because you feel like you need to wee a lot, then struggle to do it when you get to the toilet.

question: How is prostate cancer diagnosed?
answer: Prostate cancer is diagnosed by testing your wee and blood as well as a doctor checking to feel if the prostate gland is swollen. This might then be followed by an MRI scan and testing a small piece of the gland in a laboratory.

question: What is prostate cancer?
answer: Prostate cancer only affects men and usually those older than 50. The prostate is a small gland, about the size of a satsuma, found near the bladder and which wraps around the urethra, which is the tube that wee travels down before it leaves your body.

question: What is a protocol?
answer: Protocol is a set way of doing things for doctors and nurses when they’re working out what’s the matter with you or if they’re doing an operation.

question: What is the difference between proton beam and linac?
answer: Proton beam therapy gives out a type of energy called a proton and a Linac machine gives out high energy X-rays instead. They are both used to kill cancer cells.

question: What is a psychological wellbeing practitioner?
answer: Psychological wellbeing practitioners look after people who are upset or sad and show them how to take care of themselves.

question: What is radiation?
answer: Radiation is a type of energy which is used to fight cancer cells.

question: What is radiation therapy?
answer: Radiation therapy is a type of energy ray that doctors use to treat cancer. Sometimes it comes out of a machine and other times they put something in your body to get the energy rays nearer to the cancer.

question: What is radiotherapy?
answer: Radiotherapy is a type of energy ray that doctors use to treat cancer. Sometimes it comes out of a machine and other times they put something in your body to get the energy rays nearer to the cancer.

question: What is a rehabilitation medicine specialist?
answer: Rehabilitation medicine specialists help peoople with complicated illness or a disability get on with a normal life.

question: What is sarcoma?
answer: Sarcoma is the name for types of cancer that start in muscles, bones, nerves, and other parts of the body.

question: How is sarcoma treated?
answer: Sarcoma is usually removed with an operation. This is sometimes followed with radiotherapy and occasionally chemotherapy.

question: What does screening mean?
answer: Screening is when healthy people are tested for early signs of a disease like cancer.

question: What is secondary cancer?
answer: Secondary cancer is when cancer has spread from its original place to somewhere else in the body.

question: What does skin cancer feel like?
answer: Skin cancer can be a rough patch of skin which is a funny colour or it could be a lump on the skin. It can be itchy or sore.

question: Does skin cancer hurt?
answer: Skin cancer doesn’t really hurt but it might feel a bit sore or itchy.

question: How is skin cancer diagnosed?
answer: Skin cancer is diagnosed by removing the lump from your skin then looking at it under a microscope.

question: What is skin cancer?
answer: Skin cancer is one of the most common types of cancer. There are two types, melanoma which usually start as moles and non-melanoma which appear as patches or a lump on the skin.

question: How is skin cancer treated?
answer: Skin cancer is usually treated by having it removed with an operation then there might be some radiotherapy and sometimes chemotherapy.

question: Does soft tissue sarcoma hurt?
answer: Soft tissue sarcoma is a lump which sometimes hurts and sometimes doesn’t. Often you first notice something as the lump gets bigger and it affects things near to it.

question: What is a soft tissue sarcoma?
answer: Soft tissue sarcomas are cancers that grow from muscles, fat, or blood vessels.

question: Will I get a bead?

question: Why don’t I get sweets?
answer: Some children might choke on sweets and others might be allergic. Also, sweets can be bad for your teeth so they give out stickers instead.

question: When do I have the wires out for my broken bones?
answer: Some children need special wires when they break their bones, if you have them your doctor will let you know if and when you will have them out. You can ask them this at your appointment.

question: Will I have to give the boot back?
answer: Some children who hurt their leg use a special boot while it is getting better. The nurse will let you know if you have to give it back.

question: Why can’t I have it as a tablet?
answer: Some medicines only come as a drip and sometimes you need a drip because it works quicker.

question: Why do some people need a feeding tube and some people don’t?
answer: Some people need a feeding tube because they find it difficult to eat or swallow.

question: Will I need a wheelchair?
answer: Some people need a wheelchair and some don’t. If you ask your doctor or a nurse they’ll be able to tell you what they think.

question: Will I have metal on my bone forever?
answer: Some people need to have a small metal pin to help their bone mend. Sometimes it’s taken out and sometimes it stays forever. Your doctor will let you know.

question: Does Hodgkin lymphoma hurt?
answer: Some people with Hodgkin lymphoma have swollen glands in their neck and very occassionally they can ache but for most people it doesn’t hurt.

question: Will the treatment hurt?

question: What does lung cancer feel like?
answer: Someone with lung cancer might have a cough that doesn’t go away, they might be breathless or they might have some pain in their chest.

question: How is lung cancer treated?
answer: Someone with lung cancer will usually have an operation to remove it, they might also have some radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

question: Why do they use staples instead of stitches?
answer: Sometimes a doctor will use staples instead of stitches because it’s quicker. Sometimes staples help a cut heal quicker and with a smaller scar too.

question: Does acute myeloid leukaemia hurt?
answer: Sometimes acute myeloid leukaemia can hurt. It is usually in the joints or bones because of a build up of leukaemia cells. Other than that you might feel tired, have a high temperature or bruise easily.

question: Will the cancer come back?
answer: Sometimes cancer comes back and sometimes it doesn’t. Your doctor will keep you up to date with how your treatment is going and you’ll have regular check-ups after to keep an eye on it.

question: Does cancer hurt?
answer: Sometimes cancer hurts and sometimes the treatment can hurt too but the good news is that the doctors and nurses are experts at knowing which medicines to give you to stop it hurting. It’s really important to tell them if something is uncomfortable or starts to hurt so they can help you.

question: Does leukaemia hurt?
answer: Sometimes leukaemia can hurt. It is usually in the joints or bones because of a build up of leukaemia cells. The doctors and nurses can give you medicine to stop this so make sure you tell them if you start to feel uncomfortable or if something hurts. Other than that you might feel tired, have a high temperature or bruise easily.

question: Why did I have to give my wee in?
answer: Sometimes the doctors want to test your wee to check there’s nothing in it which shouldn’t be or it might be to check you haven’t got an infection. Why don’t you ask the radiographer or a doctor?

question: What is spinal cancer?
answer: Spinal cancer is a rare cancer which happens when lumps grow on your spine. They can cause problems because they push on the nerves that run from your brain, down your spine, to the rest of your body.

question: What does stage mean?
answer: Stage means how big a lump is or whether it’s moved to another part of the body.

question: How long will my stem cell transplant take?
answer: Stem cell transplants usually take about six weeks though sometimes it can be a bit longer. Ask a doctor, they’ll be happy to talk to you about it.

question: What are stem cells?
answer: Stem cells are found all over the body. They are what all other types of cells are made from - pretty cool hey?

question: What are stitches made out of?
answer: Stitches are made of a few different things. Some are made of special plastics that dissolve over a few weeks, some are made of a type of silk and others are made from plastic called nylon or polyester just like some clothes.

question: What does stomach cancer feel like?
answer: Stomach cancer can feel like lots of other things so it’s tricky to notice. It can make you have heartburn or feel like acid indigestion, it can also make you feel really full up after a meal, and you might burp more than usual.

question: Does stomach cancer hurt?
answer: Stomach cancer doesn’t really hurt at first. It feels like having acid indigestion or heartburn a lot.

question: What is stomach cancer?
answer: Stomach cancer is also known as gastric cancer and it usually affects the lining of your stomach. It’s quite common and more often affects men over the age of 55.

question: What are the statistics of the treatment becoming successful?
answer: Success rates for cancer treatment in children has more than doubled in the last 40 years and are now more than 80% which is brilliant!

question: Does targeted therapy hurt?
answer: Targeted therapy doesn’t hurt but you may get some side effects which include the runs and a skin rash. Your doctor will be able to let you know what to expect depending on which medicines they give you.

question: What is a targeted therapy?
answer: Targeted therapy is when you are given medicines which stop the cancer growing.

question: What does terminal mean?
answer: Terminal means that a disease can’t be cured.

question: What is Thalassaemia?
answer: Thalassaemia is when your blood doesn’t have enough of the stuff that carries oxygen round your body in it.

question: What does the blood pressure machine do?
answer: The blood pressure machine measures how hard your heart is working. You have a strap put around your arm which fills with air and feels tight. The air is then let out and a number will come up on the screen which tells the doctor what they need to know.

question: Will the CAT scan be noisy?
answer: The CAT scan can be a bit noisy, but it’s only as loud as a hair dryer and it doesn’t last a very long time.

question: What is the difference between a CAT scan and a MRI?
answer: The CAT scanner is much smaller and quieter than the MRI scanner.The MRI uses magnets instead of X-rays and the picture is usually clearer.

question: What does the circle bit on the CAT scanner do?
answer: The circle bit on the CAT scanner is the camera. Inside it there are lots of little X-ray cameras which take loads of pictures which then make a 3D picture of your insides.

question: What does the circle bit on the CT scanner do?
answer: The circle bit on the CT scanner is the camera. Inside it there are lots of little X-ray cameras which take loads of pictures which then make a 3D picture of your insides.

question: Will the CT scan be noisy?
answer: The CT scan sounds a bit like a hair dryer and it doesn’t last a very long time.

question: What is the difference between a CT scan and an MRI?
answer: The CT scanner is much smaller and quieter than the MRI scanner.The MRI uses magnets instead of X-rays and the picture is usually clearer.

question: When is my ultrasound appointment?
answer: The date and time of your ultrasound appointment will be on the letter your doctor sent you. You might have a bit of a wait when you get to the clinic so bring something with you to keep you busy.

question: What’s the difference between an X-ray and a CT scan?
answer: The difference between an X-ray and a CT scan is that X-rays are a flat picture and CT scans make a 3D picture.

question: What does the doctor look for in the X-ray picture?
answer: The doctor looks on your X-ray picture for anything unusual like a broken bone or an infection. You can ask the doctor what they’re looking for before the X-ray.

question: How will I know if my treatment is working?
answer: The doctor will be able to tell you how well the treatment is working. It might be that they need to try something else as well.

question: Will the doctors ask me lots of questions?
answer: The doctors may ask you some questions so they know why you have come to see them and how they can help you.

question: What does it mean when the drip machine beeps?
answer: The drip machine can beep for lots of reasons. Sometimes it beeps because your medicine has finished, or the line is a bit bent and the medicine can’t get through.

question: What is Enneking system?
answer: The Enneking system is a way for doctors to understand cancer and decide the best treatment for you.

question: Will the feeding tube choke me?
answer: The feeding tube doesn’t choke you. It’s not very nice when it’s put in but it’s over very quickly so try not to worry. You can have someone with you while you have it done too.

question: What does a soft tissue sarcoma feel like?
answer: The first thing people notice with a soft tissue sarcoma is a lump that doesn’t hurt but carries on growing and doesn’t go away.

question: What’s the green bear called?
answer: The green bear is called Humphrey and he’s named after Humphrey Booth, the man that opened the first children’s hospital in Manchester over a hundred years ago.

question: What is the hard plate that goes behind under your arm leg for an X-ray?
answer: The hard plate is the X-ray film. It is used to catch the X-ray beams to make the picture.

question: Will I get any treats?
answer: The hospital doesn’t give out treats to children and young people. They do have stickers though so if you would like one ask your nurse.

question: What conditions do you treat?
answer: The hospital treats hundreds of conditions! We are one of the largest children’s hospitals in the country, and we see children from all over the country and even from abroad. There’s not much we don’t treat here.

question: Why do they put a magnet in the MRI machine?
answer: The magnet in the MRI machine helps make the pictures.

question: How is Hodgkin lymphoma treated?
answer: The main treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma is chemotherapy, sometimes followed by radiotherapy.

question: How is lymphoma treated?
answer: The main treatment for lymphoma is chemotherapy, sometimes followed by radiotherapy.

question: How is stomach cancer treated?
answer: The main treatments for stomach cancer are chemotherapy and radiotherapy or an operation depending on whereabouts the cancer is. Sometimes you’ll have more than one of these treatments.

question: How is adrenal cancer treated?
answer: The main ways adrenal cancer is treated are by having an operation to remove it, having radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Your doctor mighty give you more than one type of treatment.

question: Will the barium milkshake make me better?
answer: The milkshake won’t make you better but it will let the doctor see what is going on inside your tummy.

question: What is an MRI scan?
answer: The MRI is a machine that uses a magnet to take pictures of the inside of your body.

question: What noise does the MRI scan make?
answer: The MRI scanner makes a very loud whooshing sound. It sounds a lot like a lawnmower or a loud hairdryer.

question: Will the needle hurt?
answer: The needle can feel a bit like a scratchy, pinching feeling, but you will have some magic cream on, so that you can’t really feel the needle. The magic cream takes around 40 minutes to work.

question: Does the patient monitor hurt?
answer: The patient monitor doesn’t hurt. When you’re having your blood pressure taken the arm band squeezes tightly and the pulse oximeter grips your finger but it’s nothing to worry about.

question: Does a PCA hurt?
answer: The PCA pump is attached to a tube called an IV which goes into your arm. Having an IV means that you’ll have a needle with a tube on it put in your arm or leg. It can feel a bit like being scratched or pinched when the needle first goes in but it’s not too bad and it’s pretty quick. When the needle comes out the tube stays in place and that doesn’t hurt.

question: What is the person taking the X-ray picture feeling?
answer: The person taking the X-ray could be feeling all sorts of things, like you. They’re experts at this and have lots of training so they’ll be kind and calm and make you feel safe.

question: Will it be dark in the ultrasound room?
answer: The radiographer, who takes your picture, turns the lights down when you’re having an ultrasound so they can see the screen better. It is dark enough for them to see the screen but it’s not too dark that you can’t see.

question: What is the radiotherapy mask for?
answer: The radiotherapy mask helps keep your head still when you’re being treated. It can be decorated or painted as your favourite TV character if you like.

question: How do they make the radiotherapy mask?
answer: The radiotherapy mask is dipped in warm water to make it go soft then it’s placed over your face when you’re lying on a table. It feels warm and damp like a wet face cloth. The edges of it are pulled down and clipped to the table and then the mask is carefully smoothed on your face to make sure it’s snug. It takes a few minutes to cool down and go hard which feels a bit tight on your face but don’t worry, it doesn’t take long, it doesn’t affect your breathing, and the whole thing should take about 20 minutes from beginning to end.

question: What will the ultrasound results be?
answer: The results of the ultrasound scan depends on why you’re having it. You’ll have to ask your doctor about that.

question: What are the risks of radiotherapy?
answer: The risks of radiotherapy are side effects which might include tiredness, sore skin, a change in skin colour or losing some hair in the area that’s being treated.

question: What will the CAT scan room be like?

question: What will the CT scan room be like?
answer: The room with the CT scanner in is a big, plain room and the scanner looks like a giant metal doughnut with a bed in the middle of it, which you lie on. It makes a whizzing sound and just takes a few minutes.

question: What is the ultrasound rubbing thing called?
answer: The rubbing thing on the ultrasound scanner is called a transducer probe. There are different shaped ones for different parts of your body.

question: What is the X-ray screen for?
answer: The screen is for the person taking the picture to stand behind so the X-ray beams don’t reach them.

question: Does the sun cause cancer?
answer: The sun can cause cancer if you are not careful so it’s important to make sure you don’t burn by using sunscreen, staying in the shade when the sun’s out and covering up with hats and clothes.

question: Will the tattoos come off?
answer: The tattoos will not come off but they’re so tiny you’ll hardly notice them.

question: Will the needle hurt? Will the nurses hurt me?
answer: The things the doctors and nurses do while you are in hospital are to make you feel better. If you need a blood test or to have a cannula put in, it can feel a bit scratchy and pinchy. The nurses will put special cream on so that it does not hurt as much.

question: What is the treatment for bone cancer?

question: What will the ultrasound feel like?

question: Will the ultrasound be scary?
answer: The ultrasound scan isn’t scary. The room might be a bit dark so the person doing the scan can see the screen properly. It’s okay to be a bit worried but it’s very easy, it won’t hurt and you can take someone in with you.

question: What will my ultrasound show?
answer: The ultrasound scan will show the inside of your body so the doctor can see what’s going on in there.

question: What will the X-ray machine look like?
answer: The X-ray machine looks like a big camera attached to a moveable robot arm that hangs down from the ceiling. It has a light that shines on the area you are having x-rayed.

question: Why is the X-ray room dark?
answer: The X-ray machine uses a special light to take its pictures. The room has to be a bit darker so the pictures are as clear as they can be.

question: Where does the X-ray picture go when it has been taken?
answer: The X-ray picture goes to a computer so the doctors can look at it.

question: What is the X-ray pinny for?
answer: The X-ray pinny is for the person who comes in with you so the X-ray beams don’t reach them.

question: What does the X-ray room look like?
answer: The X-ray room is quite plain, there’s a bed for anyone who needs to lie down for their X-ray and the machine which is a big camera hanging down from the ceiling. There’s also a glass screen in the corner where the person who takes your X-ray will stand.

question: What does the X-ray picture look like?
answer: The X-ray shows a black and white picture of your insides. You can see your bones and other things like your lungs.

question: Will an X-ray hurt?

question: What things will keep me safe?
answer: There are loads of things to keep you safe. The staff are well trained and you can also have your parents with you in hospital.

question: How is prostate cancer treated?

question: Why can’t I have it done in my room?

question: Why is there a bed in the X-ray room?
answer: There is a bed in the X-ray room for people who need to lie down to have their X-ray.

question: Will there be games to show what is going to be done at my ultrasound?

question: What type of equipment will be at my X-ray?

question: How should I feel about having cancer?

question: How is gastrointestinal cancer treated?

question: Who will the people be at my ultrasound?

question: Will I have to come back to hospital?

question: Will I need to have more tests?

question: What does bone cancer feel like?

question: What does CNS cancer feel like?
answer: With CNS cancer you might get headaches or funny vision or you might be a bit wobbly when you walk - it’s different for everyone. Ask your doctor, they’ll be able to tell you.

question: How is breast cancer diagnosed?
answer: Women over the age of 35 have regular tests to look for breast cancer and it is often noticed then. Sometimes a woman will notice a lump herself and see her doctor. When this happens the doctor will check for lumps then if they think it’s needed the woman will go to the hospital for more tests.
