At the hospital they might have an X-ray called a mammogram, or an ultrasound scan. After this doctors might do tests on part of the lump and look at it under a microscope to see if it is cancerous.

question: What if I need an X-ray?
answer: X-rays don’t hurt, it’s just a way of taking picture of inside your body. It’s really easy and a nurse will tell you everything you need to do. Simple!

question: Will the X-ray affect me?
answer: X-rays only cause problems if you have loads of them so you will only have X-rays when you really need them.

question: Will you definitely get the results from the ultrasound test?
answer: Yes, the doctor will let you know what the ultrasound scan has shown. They might tell you when you next see them or they might send you a letter.

question: Why am I having an X-ray?
answer: You are having an X-ray so your doctor can see what it looks like inside your body. If you would like to know more ask your doctor.

question: Why am I here in hospital?
answer: You are in the hospital because the doctors want to find out what’s making you poorly and then make you better. You can ask a doctor or nurse at any time about your illness and your treatment.

question: What times are the appointments?
answer: You can ask the ward clerk or a nurse who will be able to tell you what time appointments are.

question: Who comes with me to my MRI scan?
answer: You can chose one person to come into the MRI scan room with you. If more than one person has come with you to the hospital the other person can stay in the waiting area.

question: Can I still kiss my pet?
answer: You can still have your pets around when you’re at home but you shouldn’t kiss or snuggle them till you’re better in case you pick up germs.

question: Why am I not allowed to eat or drink before my X-ray?
answer: You can’t eat or drink before your barium X-ray because it could affect the pictures. If you have food or drink in your tummy they may not get clear X-ray pictures.

question: Why can’t I have a drip at home?
answer: You can’t have a drip at home unfortunately because the nurses need to look after you while you have it and keep it clean.

question: Does bladder cancer hurt?
answer: You can’t usually feel anything when you have bladder cancer but instead you will see blood in your wee.

question: What does bladder cancer feel like?
answer: You can’t usually feel anything when you have bladder cancer but instead you will see blood in your wee.

question: Will I get sweets at a CAT scan?
answer: You don’t get sweets when you have a CAT scan but afterwards you’ll get a sticker!

question: Will I get sweets at a CT scan?
answer: You don’t get sweets when you have a CT scan but afterwards you may get a sticker!

question: Why do I have to wear a gown for my MRI scan?
answer: You have to wear a gown for your MRI scan so your clothes don’t show up on the picture and make it blurry. Also, there are lots of magnets inside the machine which can pull zips and buttons towards it.

question: What will happen in the ultrasound scan? How do they do the scan?
answer: You might have to get changed into a gown before you go into the ultrasound scan room. Then you’ll lie on a bed and the person doing the scan will put some gel on the area they’re looking at. They will then use a probe and slide it around on the gel to see inside different parts of your body. After that you can go and change back into your clothes.

question: What does adrenal cancer feel like?
answer: You only really feel adrenal cancer if the tumour gets big because it starts pushing on other parts of your body. Because of this it can make you feel full or give you a tummy ache.

question: Can I still go swimming if I have a Central line?
answer: You probably can’t go swimming with a Central line fitted I’m afraid because you might get an infection if one of your tubes gets wet.

question: Is there any food I shouldn’t have?
answer: You shouldn’t eat raw or soft eggs, soft cheese, pate or shellfish while you’re being treated.

question: Should I have vitamin tablets?
answer: You shouldn’t need to take vitamin tablets if you eat lots of different types of food but if you’re worried about it ask a doctor or nurse.

question: Will I have to be held down for a CAT scan?
answer: You won’t need to be held down when you have a CAT scan but if it’s of your head you might need something on your forehead to stop you wobbling it. You will need to lie very still when you’re having the scan but there’s nothing to worry about, it’s very quick and you’ll always have someone with you while it’s happening.

question: Will I have to be held down for a CT scan?
answer: You won’t need to be held down when you have a CT scan but if it’s of your head you might need something on your forehead to stop you wobbling it. You will need to lie very still when you’re having the scan but there’s nothing to worry about, it’s very quick and you’ll always have someone with you while it’s happening.

question: What’s the Wi-Fi password?
answer: You’ll have to ask the ward clerk or one of the nurses for the Wi-Fi code, they’ll be able to help you.

question: Will I need medicine and treatment for soft tissue sarcoma?
answer: You’ll probably have an operation to take away the soft tissue sarcoma then you might need some chemo or radiotherapy.

question: What am I having treatment for?
answer: You’re having treatment to make you better. If you’re not sure exactly what your illness is you can ask a doctor, nurse or your parents.

question: What is appendix cancer?
answer: Your appendix is a small tube which is attached to your bowel which doesn’t really do very much. Sometimes growths can appear on it which are either benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). Often they aren’t noticed for quite a while because of where they are.

question: Will my arm always be broken?
answer: Your arm won’t always be broken. The cast is put on so your arm can mend. The bone grows again over the broken bit.

question: Why does chemo make me sick?
answer: Your body thinks the chemo is bad even though it is being used to treat you. Because of this your body tries to get rid of it and makes you sick. The doctors can give you other medicine to stop you from feeling sick though.

question: If you don’t have to have your teeth taken out today do you have to stay?
answer: Your doctor should be able to tell you if you need to stay when they come to see you. It’s okay to ask questions if you don’t understand anything.

question: Will I get better?
answer: Your doctor will be able to explain everything they’re doing to help you get better. You should ask them.

question: Will I be catheterised?
answer: Your doctor will be able to tell you if you will need a catheter, a special tube for your wee, during and after your operation.

question: Why is my treatment being changed?
answer: Your doctor will be able to tell you the reasons for your treatment being changed but it’s usually because of the way it is affecting you or your illness. It’s nothing to worry about.

question: If the blood in my mouth has not stopped, will I have to stay overnight?
answer: Your doctor will be able to tell you whether you have to stay overnight when they come round to talk to you about your operation. If there is anything that doesn’t make sense or you don’t understand then it is okay to ask questions.

question: How is stomach cancer diagnosed?
answer: Your doctor will check you for lumps or tenderness in your tummy and if they think you might have stomach cancer they’ll send you to hospital for more tests. The tests will include X-rays and an endoscopy which is a tiny camera on a tube which goes into your stomach so the doctor can have a look around.

question: How is throat cancer diagnosed?
answer: Your doctor will have a look at your throat and if they think you might have throat cancer you will be asked to go and see an ear, nose and throat doctor at the hospital. They will get a closer look at your throat with a special camera. The camera will either go up your nose or through your mouth and you might have to be put to sleep while they do it. After that you might be asked to have a scan, either a CT, an MRI, a PET or an ultrasound, so the doctors can get a 3D picture of your throat.

question: How will I know if the cancer has stayed away?
answer: Your doctor will have regular meetings with you after your treatment has ended and they will do blood tests to check that the cancer has stayed away.

question: How do I know if I’m eating enough?
answer: Your nurses will keep an eye on your weight and height and make sure you’re eating enough. If you’re not sure though, ask them, they’ll be happy to help.

question: What does my treatment do?
answer: Your treatment is designed to make you better. Your doctor will be able to tell you exactly how it works so feel free to ask them.

question: Where do you have your X-ray?
answer: Your X-ray is usually done in the radiography or X-ray department. The people at the hospital will be able to tell you where it is and make sure you go in the right room.

question: Will lots of people see my X-ray?
answer: Your x-ray will be seen by the person taking the picture and then your doctor. If they have any questions about it they might ask another doctor but that’s it.

question: Does a catheter hurt?
answer: A urinary catheter can feel a bit funny when it goes in but it doesn’t hurt. Once it’s in you might feel like you want to wee but don’t worry it will take care of that.

question: Does limb sparing surgery hurt?
answer: If you have surgery you will be given special medicine to make you sleep during the operation, so you don’t feel anything. You might feel a bit funny afterwards but there are medicines to help stop that.

question: Are the doctors boys or girls?
answer: Anyone can be a doctor or a nurse.

question: Will my proton therapy treatment be straight after the scan?
answer: Your proton therapy treatment isn’t usually straight after your scan because there’s loads of behind the scenes planning to be done first. It’s usually a couple of weeks later but you’ll be given a date when you have your CT scan.

question: When do I find out the results of my proton therapy CT scan?
answer: The CT scan is for the doctors to use and plan your proton therapy treatment so there’s not really anything to find out. If you’ve got any questions though you can ask your key worker.

question: What are the benefits of an MR scan for proton therapy?
answer: An MR scan shows the inside of your body in lots of detail so doctors can see exactly where the proton beams need to treat.

question: Why do I need an MR scan for proton therapy?
answer: An MR scan is needed to help the doctors and planning radiographers plan your proton therapy treatment.

question: When do I find out the results from my MR scan for proton therapy?
answer: You won’t automatically be given results from your MR scan because they’re used by the doctors to help plan your proton therapy treatment. If you want to know just ask your key worker who can tell you.

question: Why do I need contrast with my MR scan for proton therapy?
answer: Contrast helps to make the MR images clearer, which makes it better for your consultant and planning radiographers to plan your proton therapy treatment.

question: How long does it take to plan Proton Beam Therapy treatment?
answer: It normally takes between one and two weeks to plan Proton Beam Therapy treatment. You will be given a list with your first Proton Beam treatment appointment which will be around two weeks after your CT and MR scan.

question: Who plans my proton therapy treatment?
answer: Planning radiographers, physicists and your consultant will plan your Proton Beam Therapy treatment.

question: How is Proton Beam Therapy planned?
answer: A special computer programme is used to plan your Proton Beam Therapy treatment by planning radiographers, physicists and your consultant. Your treatment plan is designed using results from your CT and MR scans to help to decide what dose to give you and to exactly where in the body.

question: What is used to plan my Proton Beam Therapy treatment?
answer: Your Proton Beam Therapy is planned using images from your CT and MR scan. The tiny marks that are put on you when you have your CT are used to help with the planning process so the treatment happens in exactly the same place every day.

question: Why do I need to have another CT and MR scan for proton therapy?
answer: Sometimes your consultant might decide you need another CT or MR scan if the treatment area in your body changes shape. If that happens they’ll make a new proton therapy plan for you which will need more scans.

question: How do the tattoos help in the planning process of my proton therapy treatment?
answer: The tiny tattoos from when you have a CT scan are used so the machine knows where to give you your proton therapy treatment so it’s in exactly the same place every day.

question: Why is Proton Beam Therapy treatment planning so important?
answer: Proton Beam Therapy treatment planning is very important so a very high dose of radiation can be directed at the cancer without hitting other parts of your body. This helps reduce side effects as well as treating you.

question: Who should I contact if I have any questions whilst my proton therapy treatment is being planned?
answer: If you have any questions whilst your proton therapy treatment is being planned you can ask your key worker and they’ll be happy to help.

question: How is Proton Beam Therapy delivered?
answer: Proton Beam Therapy is given to patients using a machine called a gantry which aims the proton beam to the area of the body needing treatment.

question: What is a proton?
answer: A proton is a really tiny, positively charged particle that is found in the middle of an atom.

question: Can my parents stay with me when I have proton therapy treatment?
answer: Your parents can’t go into the Proton Beam treatment room but they’ll be with you right up until you go in. The radiographers will look after you in the treatment room and they’ll talk you through what to do.

question: Will I be on my own during proton therapy treatment?
answer: When the machine is giving you the proton beam therapy you’ll be in the room on your own but don’t worry, it won’t be for long, and the radiographers can see and hear you from just outside the room and they can talk to you too.

question: What type of cancers can be treated with Proton Beam Therapy?
answer: Proton Beam Therapy is usually used for cancers that have not spread to other parts of the body but it can be used for lots of different types of cancer.

question: What side effects will I have from proton therapy treatment?
answer: There can be side effects from Proton Beam Therapy which depend on which part of your body is being treated. Your doctor or key worker will be able to explain them to you.

question: Is the proton therapy treatment room dark?
answer: The room lights are dimmed while the radiographers get you into the position for the proton beam treatment but it’s fine to have the lights back on while the machine is working.

question: How often will I need to have proton therapy treatment?
answer: How many treatments of Proton Beam Therapy you need depends on the area you are having treated. Your doctor and key worker will be able to let you know.

question: How long will my proton therapy treatment take each day?
answer: Proton Beam Therapy treatment can take between 20-45 minutes each day.

question: Will I feel anything during proton therapy treatment?
answer: No, Proton Beam Therapy treatment does not hurt and is completely painless.

question: Can I move during my proton therapy treatment?
answer: No, you can’t move when you’re having Proton Beam Therapy treatment so it’s important to stay as still as possible.

question: Will my proton therapy treatment make me feel sick?
answer: Sometimes Proton Beam Therapy can make you feel sick but that depends on which part of your body you are having treatment. The doctors can give you medicine to help stop you feeling sick.

question: How long does the radiation remain in my body after proton therapy treatment?
answer: Radiation does not stay in your body after the Proton Beam Therapy has finished.

question: Will I have general anaesthetic during my proton therapy treatment?
answer: Some children need an anaesthetic during their proton beam treatment to help them stay still. Your doctor or key worker will be able to tell you if you need one or not.

question: What happens during proton therapy treatment?
answer: During your proton therapy treatment you’ll lie on the bed, in the same position as you were for your CT scan, then the radiographers will stay in the room with you while they take some X-ray images to make sure you’re in the right position. Once everything has been checked then they will leave the room and switch the machine on. They can talk to you over the speaker if you want or they can turn up your favourite music.

question: What is a proton therapy treatment image?
answer: A proton therapy treatment image is an X-ray picture. Some are taken with the machine in one position, others are taken with the machine moving around in a circle. It can sound a bit noisy when the images are taken but you won’t feel or see anything.

question: How long does a proton therapy image take?
answer: How long the proton therapy treatment image takes depends on how many pictures you need. The radiographers can tell you when you see them.

question: What can you see on a proton therapy image?
answer: When you have a proton therapy treatment image you can see the part of your body being treated.

question: Does it hurt when you take a proton therapy image?
answer: Having a proton therapy treatment image does not hurt at all. It’s just like having an X-ray.

question: Why do you need to take a proton therapy treatment image?
answer: Treatment images are used to check your position and your body before you have Proton Beam Therapy.

question: When do you take a proton therapy image?
answer: You will have treatment images every day before your proton beam therapy treatment.

question: How will I feel after my proton therapy treatment?
answer: You won’t feel anything after your first few treatments but if you do start to get side effects later it will be in the area you are having treated. Most people feel tired from Proton Beam Therapy but again this only starts about half way through your treatment.

question: Will the proton therapy treatment hurt?
answer: The Proton Beam Therapy treatment doesn’t hurt. The machine makes a buzzing noise when it’s on but you won’t be able to feel or see anything.

question: Can my mum/dad stay in the room with me when I have proton therapy?
answer: Unfortunately nobody can be in the room when you are having the Proton Beam Therapy treatment but you can see your parents as soon as it’s finished.

question: Will I be in the proton therapy treatment room on my own?
answer: When you are actually having the Proton Beam Therapy you will be on your own in the room but don’t worry, the radiographers can see you at all times and you can chat with them through a speaker.

question: Will I be given medicine to help with the side effects of proton therapy?
answer: If you have side effects from the Proton Beam Therapy treatment one of the doctors or nurses can give you some medicines to make you feel better.

question: How long will I get side effects for after proton therapy?
answer: Side effects from Proton Beam Therapy usually start half way through your treatments so you won’t have any to begin with. They can last for two or three weeks after the treatment has finished.

question: What side effects will I get from proton therapy?
answer: Side effects from proton therapy all depend on the area of your body you’re having treated. Your doctor or key worker will talk to you about what might happen.

question: Is normal to be nervous before my first proton therapy treatment?
answer: It is normal to feel nervous before your first proton therapy treatment, just because you don’t know what to expect but don’t worry the radiographers will talk you through everything and look after you so you’ll be okay. The treatment is the same every day so after the first one you’ll know what to expect.

question: How long does the proton beam treatment last?
answer: The proton beam treatment itself only lasts a few minutes but your appointment will take longer while the equipment is set up and they get you in the right position. Proton beam treatment usually happens five times a week for a few weeks.

question: What is Proton Beam Therapy?
answer: Proton Beam Therapy is a way of giving people a special type of radiotherapy which kills cancer.

question: Does the proton beam machine hurt?
answer: The proton beam machine and therapy doesn’t hurt when you’re having it done. You might feel a little bit sore in the area being treated near the end of your treatment but it’s not so bad.

question: Will I get a tattoo when I have Proton Beam Therapy?
answer: Some people have a tiny dot tattoo when they have Proton Beam Therapy so the machine can line up perfectly and treat the right place. Other people don’t need a tattoo, especially if they have to use a mask when they’re being treated.

question: What is the meaning of life?
answer: The meaning of life is different for everyone. For you it might be to live a happy life, for me it’s to answer as many questions as possible.

question: What mood are you in?
answer: I’m in a great mood thanks. What can I help you with today?

question: What does research mean?
answer: Research means doing tests to find something out.

question: What is processed food?
answer: Processed food is food that has been changed during its preparation. It might have added ingredients to make it last longer or taste different.

question: What is junk food?
answer: Junk food is pre-prepared food that isn’t very good for you because it’s not very nutritious.

question: I’m scared.
answer: I’m sorry you’re scared, try not to worry. Why don’t you ask me some questions about why you’re scared?

question: When will I meet my key worker?
answer: You will meet your key worker when you have your assessment visit.

question: Who will I meet during my assessment visit?
answer: When you have your assessment visit you’ll meet your key worker, your doctor, radiographers and nurses who will be involved in your treatment. You might also meet health play specialists and specialist workers coordinators who will help support you during your treatment.

question: What happens during my assessment visit?
answer: At your assessment visit you’ll meet your key worker, your doctor and anyone else that will help with your treatment. You’ll also have either a mask or a vac-bag made and have scans to help plan your treatment.

question: What is consent?
answer: Consent is when you (or your parent / guardian) gives permission for something to happen.

question: What is a consent form?
answer: A consent form is a form signed by you (or your parent / guardian) before an operation or treatment, that gives permission for it to be done.

question: What is the mould room?
answer: The mould room is where you go to have equipment made which will be used to help you keep still during treatment.

question: What is a vac-bag?
answer: A vac-bag is a bit like a bean bag. You lie on it when it’s soft then a pump is used to suck out all the air. It moulds to your shape and is then used everyday for your treatment.

question: What material is the mask made out of?
answer: The mask is made of a special type of plastic that softens when it’s warm and hardens when it cools down. It’s called thermoplastic.

question: Can I take my mask home?
answer: You can take your mask home when you’ve finished your treatment but before you do the nurses would love to see if you’ve decorated it.

question: Can I take my vac-bag home?
answer: I’m afraid you can’t take the vac-bag home. They are cleaned and used again for other people.

question: How long does it take to make a mask?
answer: It only takes a couple of minutes to make your mask then you’ll wear it every time you have radiotherapy.

question: Will I be able to breathe in the mask?
answer: There are holes in the mask, it may feel snug but you can breathe through it, no problem.

question: Who will make my mask?
answer: The radiographers will make your mask in the mould room.

question: Will I be able to keep my eyes open in the mask?
answer: You should close your eyes when the mask is being made because it’s wet when it goes on and you don’t want to get water in your eyes.

question: Do I have to have my eyes closed in the mask?
answer: It’s probably more comfortable to have your eyes closed when you have the mask on but it’s fine to open them if you want, unless the radiographers ask you not to.

question: Where does the mask go after it is made?
answer: When the mask has been made it has your name, address and birthday marked on it and is sent to the machine where you’ll be having treatment.

question: Why do I need to have a CT scan?
answer: You’ll have a CT scan so your doctor and the radiographers can see inside your body and plan your treatment.

question: When will I have my CT scan?
answer: Your CT scan could be a couple of weeks after you first meet your doctor. Your key worker will let you know the exact date.

question: Can my parents be with my while I have my scan?
answer: You parents can’t actually be in the room when you have your scan but they’ll be with you before and they’ll be right outside the room. The radiographers will be with you in the room and they’ll take very good care of you.

question: Can I breathe during my CT scan?
answer: Yes, you can breathe normally during your CT scan although the radiographers might ask you to hold you breath every now and again.

question: What is contrast?
answer: A contrast is a special liquid which is injected into your body through a cannula and makes your organs and blood vessels show up better on a scan. That way the doctors can work out the best way to treat you.

question: Will there be music on during the CT scan?
answer: If you want music on during your scan you can have. You can even bring your own music if you want.

question: Will I be on my own during the CT scan?
answer: The radiographers will be with you while they help you get in the right position then they will leave the room and go behind a screen while the scan happens. They’ll be able to see you all the time though so it’s not really like being on your own at all!

question: What can I wear during my CT scan?
answer: Just wear your normal clothes when you come to the hospital. The radiographers might give you a gown to change into before you have your scan.

question: Are there any side effects of the CT scan?
answer: There aren’t usually side effects with a CT scan.

question: Are there any side effects of the contrast?
answer: Some people can have side effects to a contrast like feeling dizzy, sick or sometimes itchy. Before you have a contrast, the radiographers will check your blood tests to make sure it’s safe for you to have and go through some questions with you.

question: What does the CT scan sound like?
answer: The CT scan doesn’t make a noise. All you’ll hear is the bed moving in and out and the tube turning inside the doughnut.

question: Am I allowed to eat or drink as normal before my CT scan?
answer: The radiographers will let you know before your CT scan if you need to change the way you eat so, unless they say so, you can eat and drink as normal.

question: Can I go straight home after my CT scan?
answer: You can usually leave right after your CT scan unless you’ve had a contrast in which case you’ll be asked to stay for a bit just to check you’re okay.

question: Will the CT scan room be dark?
answer: Sometimes the CT scan room will be darkened but just ask if you want the lights to stay on.

question: Are there any risks of having an MR scan?
answer: Having an MR scan is not risky and you’ll be perfectly safe. Before you have your scan the radiographers will ask you some questions to make sure it’s right for you.

question: Am I allowed to eat and drink normally before my MR scan?
answer: Whether you can eat or drink before depends on which part of your body you’re having an MR scan on. Your consultant will let you know before you come along.

question: Can I move during my MR scan?
answer: You shouldn’t move during your MR scan because it can make the pictures blurred. If you feel like you’re struggling during your scan then you can press a button to let the radiographers know and they will check that everything is okay and that you are okay to carry on.

question: Will I have general anaesthetic during my MR scan?
answer: Some children need to have general anaesthetic for their scans. Your consultant will talk to you about this before you have any scans.

question: Will I be on my own during my MR scan?
answer: The radiographers will be with you while they help you get in the right position then they will leave the room and go behind a screen while the MR scan happens. They’ll be able to see you all the time though so it’s not really like being on your own at all!

question: Can I have music on during my MR scan?
answer: Yes, you can have music on during your MR scan. The radiographers will put some headphones on you before they leave the room. Bring your favourite music with you so they can play it whilst you have your scan.

question: Will the MR room be dark?
answer: The lights are turned down a little bit in the MR room. The radiographers will be with you and talk through what they are doing until you are ready for the scan and they have to leave the room. Don’t worry though, they will be watching you all the time through the screen and you can press the button if you need them.

question: Are MR scans safe?
answer: MR scans are safe. Before you are given an MR scan appointment your consultant will check that it’s right for you and then before the scan itself you’ll be asked some more questions to double check. This is because some people can’t have an MR scan if they have metal in their body.

question: Are there any side effects after having an MR scan?
answer: There are no side effects to having an MR scan but sometimes lying flat for some time might make you feel a bit dizzy when you get up.

question: What does an MR scan sound like?
answer: MR scans are quite noisy and make loud banging noises. This is normal so don’t be frightened. The radiographers will put headphones on you before they leave the room so you can listen to music during your scan. Don’t forget to bring your favourite music with you!

question: What can I wear to my MR scan?
answer: You’ll be told before your appointment what you can and can’t wear because you can’t have things that contain metal in the MR room.

question: What happens during my MR scan?
answer: When you go for your MR scan the radiographers will first get you in the best position to see what they’re looking for. They’ll also explain why it’s important to stay very still. Once you’re in the right position the treatment couch which you’re lying on will move into the scanner. It can feel a bit cramped in the MR scanner but don’t worry, this is normal and the radiographers will talk to you during the scan and make sure you’re okay. When the scanner starts it’s noisy and makes banging noises so you’ll be given some headphones with music on. You can’t feel the scan so all you need to concentrate on is staying still while it happens.

question: Is it normal to feel nervous before my MR scan?
answer: It is normal to feel nervous before your MR scan just because you don’t know what to expect but don’t worry the radiographers will talk you through everything and look after you so you’ll be okay.

question: Do I have to get changed for my MR scan?
answer: You might need to get changed into a gown for your MR scan but it all depends on what part of your body is being scanned.

question: Why do I have to answer a questionnaire before my MR scan?
answer: The radiographers go through a questionnaire with you to check you are okay to have an MR scan. Some people can’t have one because they have metal in their body after an operation.

question: Is an MR scan noisy?
answer: MR scans are quite noisy and make loud banging noises. This is normal so don’t be frightened. The radiographers will put headphones on you before they leave the room so you can listen to music during your scan. Don’t forget to bring your favourite music with you!

question: What is a blastoma
answer: A blastoma is a type of cancer which mostly affects children and is found in areas of the body which are still developing like the liver or kidney or lungs. There are different types of blastoma which affect different parts of the body.

question: Does a blastoma hurt?
answer: What a blastoma feels like depends on where it is. If there is a lump or swelling it can push against parts of your body and be uncomfortable. It might make you feel full up if it’s near your tummy; it could make you dizzy if it pushes on important veins in your chest; or it might press against nerves and change the way other parts of your body work. It’s different for everyone.

question: How is a blastoma diagnosed?
answer: A doctor will do different types of tests to diagnose a blastoma depending on where it is. They will use blood tests, taking a sample to check in the laboratory, and scans like MRI or CAT scans.

question: How is a blastoma treated?
answer: Treatments for blastoma depend on what type it is, where it is, the person being treated and its stage. Treatment might include an operation, radiotherapy, chemotherapy or more than one of these. Blastomas respond well to treatment and are considered to be curable.

question: What is Xploro?
answer: Xploro is a brilliant app which helps you understand what’s going on when you’re in hospital.

question: What causes a brain tumour?
answer: Nobody knows what causes brain tumours, unfortunately. If we did they could be treated better or even stopped from happening at all.   Some people can get them because of a genetic problem and sometimes it might be because of environmental factors.   If someone has radiotherapy to the head, that can make it more likely for them to have a brain tumour too.

question: What are the different parts of the brain?
answer: There are three major parts of the brain: the cerebrum, the brainstem and the cerebellum.

question: What is a cerebrum?
answer: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is split in two parts. The cerebrum controls different functions of the body.

question: What are the lobes of the cerebrum?
answer: The cerebrum is made up of different parts. They are called the pons, medulla, spinal cord, frontal lobe, parietal lobe, occipital lobe and temporal lobe.

question: What does the brainstem do?
answer: The brainstem controls things like heart rate and breathing, and also sends messages from the brain to the spinal cord.

question: What does the cerebellum do?
answer: The cerebellum is at the back of the brain. It helps you move and controls balance.

question: What is the frontal lobe?
answer: The frontal lobe is a large part of the brain at the front of the head. It controls behaviour, personality and part of your sense of smell. It also tells the body to move and helps you speak.

question: What is the parietal lobe?
answer: The parietal lobe is in the middle of the head. This part of the brain helps you understand what someone is saying to you and controls senses such as touch, pain and temperature. It also interprets signals like vision, hearing, movement, sensory and memory.

question: What is the occipital lobe?
answer: The occiptal lobe is at the back of the head and controls vision.

question: What is the temporal lobe?
answer: The temporal lobes are the sides of the brain and help your memory, speech and hearing.

question: What is a craniotomy?
answer: A cranitomoy is type of brain surgery to take out a brain tumour

question: What is a neurosurgery?
answer: Neurosurgery is an operation done to the brain or spinal cord.

question: What is brain surgery?
answer: Brain surgery is an operation done to the brain.

question: Does brain surgery hurt?
answer: You don’t feel anything during brain surgery because you are asleep when it happens. Afterwards, when you wake up, you may have a headache or feel dizzy but there are lots of healthcare professionals to help you feel better again.

question: Does neurosurgery hurt?
answer: You don’t feel anything during neurosurgery because you are asleep when it happens. Afterwards, when you wake up, you may have a headache or feel dizzy but there are lots of healthcare professionals to help you feel better again.

question: Does a craniotomy hurt?
answer: You don’t feel anything during a craniotomy because you are asleep when it happens. Afterwards, when you wake up, you may have a headache or feel dizzy but there are lots of healthcare professionals to help you feel better again.

question: What is a shunt?
answer: A shunt is a tube that is placed in the brain to relieve pressure from a brain tumour. The patient is asleep when it’s done so they don’t feel anything.

question: What is cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?
answer: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is a clear liquid that is produced by the brain. It flows in and around the surface of the brain and spinal cord and helps cushion them.

question: What is hydrocephalus?
answer: Hydrocephalus is the build up of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) around the brain and the spinal cord. This can sometimes feel like having lots of pressure in your head.

question: Why do I need brain surgery?
answer: Brain surgery is often done to remove as much of a tumour as possible. Sometimes it is done to get a small part of a tumour to test it, this is known as a biopsy.

question: Why do I need neurosurgery?
answer: Neurosurgery is often done to remove as much of a tumour as possible. Sometimes it is done to get a small part of a tumour to test it, this is known as a biopsy.

question: Will I have a scar after brain surgery?
answer: Brain surgery does leave a scar but don’t worry, it heals in time.

question: What is watch and wait?
answer: Watch and wait happens when someone has a slow growing tumour that is usually non-cancerous or non-malignant. The doctor will treat them and keep an eye on the tumour for any changes. This is also called active surveillance.

question: What are astrocytoma and glioma?
answer: Astrocytoma and glioma are tumours that grow from brain cells called astrocytes—a type of cell which makes up the supportive tissue of the brain. Often the words astrocytoma and glioma are used to mean the same thing. Astrocytoma are the most common type of brain tumour and spinal cord tumour in children and they can develop at any age.

question: what is a anaplastic astrocytoma
answer: An anaplastic astrocytoma is a type of tumour which can grow in any part of the central nervous system.   They grow faster than gliomas but are unlikely to spread to other parts of the central nervous system.

question: What is a glioblastoma multiforme or GBM?
answer: A glioblastoma multiforme or GBM for short, is a high grade tumour that grows quickly.

question: what is a pilocytic astrocytoma?
answer: A pilocytic astrocytoma is usually a slow growing, non-malignant tumour made of spindle-like cells.

question: What is a brainstem glioma?
answer: A brainstem glioma is a type of tumour that develops in the brainstem. They behave differently depending on which part of the brainstem they are in.

question: What is an optic pathway glioma?
answer: An optic pathway glioma is a slow growing tumour that occurs along the nerves between the brain and the eyes. They are also known as optic nerve tumours and optic gliomas.

question: What is a choroid plexus tumour?
answer: A choroid plexus tumour forms near the centre of the brain, where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is produced.

question: What is a craniopharyngioma?
answer: Craniopharyngiomas grow around the bottom of the brain, just above the pituitary gland. These tumours are usually low grade or non-malignant (non-cancerous), and they don’t usually spread.

question: What is a medulloblastoma?
answer: Medulloblastoma is the second most common type of brain tumour in young people. These tumours form at the back of the brain, in the cerebellum. Sometimes this tumour can be found in the spine.

question: What is an ependymoma?
answer: Ependymoma is a tumour which children get that can appear anywhere in the brain or spine. They start in the ependymal cells which make cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Ependymal cells are a type of glial cell, so you might sometimes hear the tumour being called a glioma.

question: what is an acquired brian injury?
answer: An acquired brian injury is when a brain tumour or its treatment causes damage to the brain itself.

question: Why does my head feel pressure?
answer: Sometimes you can feel pressure in your head after radiotherapy because it makes the brain swell a bit and this can lead to headaches and sickness. Your healthcare team will watch for signs of swelling and have medicines to help if that happens.

question: What is brain swelling?
answer: Sometimes radiotherapy can make the brain swell a bit which can feel like pressure in the head and can lead to headaches or sickness. Your healthcare team will watch for signs of swelling and have medicines to help if that happens.

question: Why do I need Radiotherapy for brain and spine
answer: Brain tumours don’t usually spread to other parts of the body but they can spread within the brain and through the fluid that surrounds both it and the spinal cord, otherwise known as the central nervous system, or CNS for short. If that happens you might need radiotherapy for the brain and spine.  Some common CNS tumours are called astrocytoma, ependymoma and medulloblastoma.

question: What is craniospinal irradiation?
answer: Radiotherapy to the central nervous system (CNS) can also be called craniospinal irradiation.   If you need CNS radiotherapy, the special treatment mask will stretch from the top of your head down to the middle of your chest. This is to make sure the top of the spine is kept straight by stopping the shoulders, neck and head from moving.   To stop the lower spine from moving, Radiographers need to make sure that the your hips stay still during treatment. To help do this, you may need to have some small, permanent skin marks around your waist. These are like tiny tattoos and are made at the planning appointment. They’re used to line up with marks on the mask to make sure the radiotherapy is given to exactly the right place.   It involves a drop of ink being put on the skin, then a small piercing of the skin’s surface is done with a needle. It feels like a sharp scratch, and it is over very quickly.

question: What is Stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT)?
answer: Stereotactic radiotherapy, or SRT, is a type of radiotherapy treatment used to treat some brain tumours. It can be delivered through a specialised linac or by other machines, known as CyberKnife or Gamma Knife.

question: How many treatments does stereotactic radiotherapy have?
answer: The number of times you have stereotactic radiotherapy depends on the type of tumour you have and how well you are. It is usually delivered in a small number of sessions over a few days or weeks.

question: What is Stereotactic radiosurgery?
answer: Stereotactic radiosurgery is when stereotactic radiotherapy is delivered in one session, on the same day. It’s usually done like this for small tumours that are less than 4cm in size.

question: What is Gamma knife?
answer: Gamma Knife is a type of stereotactic radiosurgery. It is another type of radiation treatment.

question: What is CSF?
answer: CSF stands for Cerebrospinal fluid. It’s a watery liquid that is continuously produced and absorbed, and that flows through the vessels in the brain and around the surface of the brain and spinal cord.

question: What is metastic brain cancer?
answer: Metastic brain cancer is a brain tumour that doesn’t originally start in the brain but has spread from another part of the body.

question: What is metastic brain tumour?
answer: A metastic brain tumour is a brain tumour that doesn’t originally start in the brain but has spread from another part of the body.

question: What is neuro oncology?
answer: Neuro oncology is the science that deals with tumours of the nervous system.

question: What is whole brain radiotherapy?
answer: Whole-brain radiotherapy is a type of external beam radiotherapy that is given to the whole brain.

question: What is epilepsy?
answer: Brains work on electrical activity and epilepsy is a condition where there is a sudden burst of that electrical activity which disrupts the way it works. It can make the body and brain act strangely which is called a seizure. Seizures come in many different types.

question: Will I be able to talk properly again?
answer: Sometimes a brain tumour can affect the way a person speaks because the tumour and treatment have made changes in the brain. If this happens to you, you will get help from a speech and language therapist that will help you talk properly again.

question: Why does it take ages for me to answer questions?
answer: Sometimes after a brain tumour, the brain may take a little longer to process information. This is because it is still recovering from the tumour and treatment. If this hapens to you, take your time and answer when you feel ready.

question: Why can’t I concentrate?
answer: Sometimes because of where the brain tumour is, it can slow down how you think. On top of this you might feel super tired which could also stop you from paying attention to things. If this happens to you, talk to your parents or teacher and they can help.

question: Why do I forget things?
answer: Some people with a brain tumour forget things, this is because the area that stores information or memories is affected by the brain tumour. Forgetting can also be called memory loss.

question: Can I get help at school?
answer: If you are struggling at school, let your parents and teachers know. They will help create a plan so that you can manage the work better. Sometimes you can get extra help at school too.

question: What is SEND?
answer: SEND stands for Special Education Needs and Disability. Sometimes after a brain tumour it can take a little longer to process information, speak, move or write which means you can’t keep up with school work. For this reason you may get extra support at school from a SEND coordinator who will help you keep on top of things at school.

question: What is EHCP?
answer: EHCP stands for Educational Health Care Plan. They are for children who need extra help at school if they are struggling to keep up because of health problems or a disability.

question: What is a ear, nose and throat surgeon?
answer: An ear, nose and throat surgeon is a doctor who helps treat any problems with your ears, nose or throat, as well as your head and neck. Sometimes, we call them ENT surgeons.

question: What is a scrub nurse?
answer: A scrub nurse is like a special helper in the operating room. They make sure that everything is clean and organised, and help the doctor to do their job.

question: What do a sister do?
answer: A sister is the nurse who is in charge of a hospital ward and makes sure that it runs well. If a male nurse has this job, they're called a charge nurse.

question: What does a charge nurse do?
answer: A charge nurse is a nurse who is in charge of a hospital ward and makes sure that it runs well.

question: What is the person called who makes you go to sleep during the operation?
answer: The doctor who gives you medicine to make you go to sleep during the operation is called an anaesthetist.

question: Why does the surgeon wear a hat?
answer: Surgeons do operations or surgeries in an operating room. This room must be kept very clean. They wear hats to stop their hair getting in the way or falling onto equipment during operations. This also helps to prevent infection.

question: Who is the best doctor or nurse?
answer: There isn't a best doctor or nurse. They all work hard doing different things to help you and other children get better. All our doctors and nurses are good at their jobs.

question: Are the doctors and nurses men or women?
answer: Anyone can be a doctor or nurse.

question: Are the nurses, doctors and other hospital staff friendly?
answer: The nurses, doctors and other hospital staff are all friendly. They try to make your time in hospital as happy and comfortable as possible.

question: What is my doctor's name?
answer: Lots of doctors work at the hospital. When you next see your doctor, just ask them their name. They won't mind.

question: What is my nurse's name?
answer: Lots of nurses work at the hospital. When you next see your nurse, just ask them their name. They won't mind.

question: What are analgesics?
answer: Analgesics are medicines that stop you feeling pain. They're also called painkillers.

question: How does the nurse know how much medicine to give me?
answer: The nurse is given a note called a prescription. This tells them what medicine you should have and how much you need.

question: What does the doctor use to listen to my chest?
answer: The doctor uses a piece of equipment called a stethoscope to listen to the inside of your chest. This is like a pair of headphones with a round, metal part attached. The round part might feel a bit cold when it first touches your skin.

question: What is the hand gel for?
answer: The gel is called hand sanitiser. You put this gel on your hands to keep them clean and stop germs spreading.

question: Why do I need a cannula needle?
answer: The nurse may give you a cannula to give you some medicines. The cannula is a needle with a thin plastic straw over it. The nurse uses the needle to put in the cannula. They then remove the needle and leave the plastic straw behind.

question: What does the cannula or blood test needle do?
answer: The nurse puts the needle gently into your arm. They can then remove a small amount of blood and arrange for it to be tested. If you have a cannula, this is left in so that the nurse or doctor can give you medicine too.

question: What is the process of having a blood test?
answer: The doctor or nurse will put a tight band around your arm which helps the veins come to the surface. The area will be cleaned then they'll put the needle in and let the blood fill up the syringe. When they have enough they will remove the needle and ask you to hold a cotton wool ball on the area. Once it has stopped bleeding they may put a small plaster on it and the blood test is finished.

question: Why can't I move my hand when I have a cannula?
answer: If you need to have a cannula, your hand might feel a bit stiff. It's OK to move your hand but keeping it still while the cannula is there may make it feel more comfortable.

question: Where do the needles go after they've been used?
answer: When a needle has been used, we throw it away safely. The hospital has special boxes called sharps bins. We put used needles in here before they are destroyed.

question: Will I need a catheter?
answer: Your doctor can explain if you need a catheter, which is a special tube for your pee.

question: Why did I have to give a sample of my pee or urine?
answer: Sometimes, the doctors want to test a sample of your pee. They can then check if you are pregnant or for anything unusual in it like an infection.

question: Will I be OK when I go to sleep for my operation?
answer: The doctor who helps you go to sleep called an anaesthetist has done lots of training to keep you safe. They stay with you and check that you're OK during your operation.

question: How will I feel in hospital?
answer: Everyone feels differently about coming to hospital. However you feel is OK. You always have someone with you when you're in hospital. Everyone is there to look after you and tries to make you as comfortable as possible. You can ask questions about anything that you want.

question: I'm scared.
answer: Being in hospital can sometimes feel scary but try not to worry. Everyone is here to look after you and wants you to be as comfortable as possible. If you take a few gentle breaths or think about something nice, this can help you to relax. It's also a good idea to tell your parents, grown-up, doctor or nurse how you feel. They can then comfort and reassure you.

question: What if I feel too unwell to eat?
answer: Even if you feel too unwell to eat, it's important to try so that you stay healthy and strong. You could try to have a small amount of something that you like to eat. But there's no need to worry. If you really don't want to eat, we won't force you.

question: Does it hurt when I have my stiches removed?
answer: It shouldn't hurt when your stitches are removed and this is a quick process. The stitch is cut at the top and then pulled out gently. You might feel a bit of tugging when this happens.

question: Can I shout if it hurts when my plaster cast is removed?
answer: Taking your plaster cast off shouldn't hurt. If it does feel uncomfortable, you can tell the nurse and they will stop.

question: Will it tickle when you take off my cast?
answer: The machine used to take off your cast has a circle part. This moves from side to side quickly and can make it feel tickly when we remove the cast.

question: Can my mum or dad hold my hand when my cast is removed?
answer: You can take any grown-up that you want into the plaster room with you. They can hold your hand while we take off the cast.

question: Why do I have to come to the hospital on a Saturday?
answer: Sometimes you have to go to the hospital on a Saturday because it gets busy during the week.

question: Will I come and lie on a bed for my operation?
answer: When you first come into hospital, you sit on a chair in the waiting area. We then take you to a different room, where you lie on the bed and go to sleep before your operation.

question: How come you can't have breakfast before an operation?
answer: You aren't allowed to eat for 6 hours before an operation because it can make you be sick. This means that you can't have breakfast if your operation is in the morning.

question: Will I wake up feeling fresh after my operation?
answer: You might wake up feeling fresh after your operation, but you're likely to be tired. This is because you need time to recover after having the sleeping medicine. Our team at the hospital look after you while you rest and recover.

question: When can I go home? How long will I be in hospital?
answer: You can go home when your doctor thinks you're well enough. Your doctor usually explains how long you're likely to be in hospital.

question: What can I do in the day?
answer: There are lots of things to do at the hospital when you're not having treatment. We have play areas with games, toys and books. If you're staying in hospital, you will have your own TV and radio at your bed. You can ask a nurse or one of our play specialists to give you ideas about what to do. It's also a good idea to bring things from home to keep you entertained. They might include a toy, book and mobile phone or tablet.

question: Will the staff look after me?
answer: The doctors, nurses and other members of staff look after you when you're in hospital. They make you feel safe and comfortable.

question: Can I have a different doctor or nurse?
answer: The doctors and nurses are the best people to help you get better. They want to help you. If you need to talk to somebody about one of the doctors or nurses, you can speak with your parents or grown-up, or ask another member of staff.

question: I need help. What should I do?
answer: You can call a nurse by pressing the orange button near your bed.

question: How do I call a nurse?
answer: If you want to call a nurse but it's not urgent, press the round orange button near your bed. In an emergency, pull the red triangle on the wall and a loud alarm will sound.

question: What are bowels?
answer: The bowels, also called the intestines, are part of your body's digestive system. This is where the remains of your food go after passing through the stomach. Your bowels help the body to absorb water and goodness or nutrients from food. They also get rid of any leftover waste that the body cannot use. This waste passes out of your body as poo.

question: What is the colon?
answer: The colon is also called the large bowel or large intestine. It helps your body to absorb liquid from food. Your colon also has bacteria, which help break down what's left into poo.

question: Will I get a room or stay in the waiting area for my operation?
answer: When you wait for your operation, you stay in the waiting area. We then take you to a different room, where you prepare to go to sleep and have your operation.

question: What if there's a fire?
answer: Fires are rare in hospital. If you hear a fire alarm, it's important to do exactly what the nurses tell you. They have been trained what to do and make sure that you are taken out of the hospital to safety.

question: Is there WiFi in hospital?
answer: If you want to go online on your phone or tablet, we have free WiFi available at Evelina London. To connect, you need to search for the NHS WiFi network on your device. You can ask your nurse or a grown-up to help you get online.

question: Will there be WiFi?
answer: If you want to go online on your phone, iPad or tablet, we have free WiFi available at Evelina London. To connect, you need to search for the NHS WiFi network on your device. You can ask your nurse or a grown-up to help you get online.

question: How can I get a top-up or more data on my phone?
answer: If you need a top-up or more data on your phone, you'll have to ask your parents or grown-up.

question: Where can I charge my phone, iPad or tablet?
answer: If you need to charge your electronic device, please check with a nurse first. We need to test all charging cables for safety before you can use them in the hospital.

question: Can I download films, TV shows or games?
answer: The WiFi at the hospital can be slow. If you want to download something like a film, it's best to ask your parents or grown-up to do this at home and bring it in for you. We have a bedside television service at Evelina London Children's Hospital. You can watch some television channels from 7am to 9pm and listen to the radio for free. If you want to watch films that are not on the free television channels, your parents or grown-up would need to pay for this.

question: Is there a bed for my parent or grown-up to sleep in at night?
answer: There is a bed where a parent or grown-up can sleep overnight. Only one of them can stay at a time.

question: Does the table go up or down and move?
answer: The table can move around on wheels and go up or down. This means that the table can go over your bed. Ask a member of staff or one of your visitors to help if you can't manage this.

question: Will the ward look like a normal GP surgery?
answer: No, the ward does not look like a GP surgery. A ward usually has a long corridor and rooms where the children staying in hospital can sleep and rest. There is also an area where the nurses do their paperwork and a room where we keep medicines.

question: I'm a bit embarrassed about the scar I have from surgery.
answer: It can take a while to get used to having a scar but try not to worry. This shows that your skin is healing and the scar fades with time.

question: How can I tell my school friends what is happening when I am not at school?
answer: If you want to tell your school friends what is happening while you're away from school, you could text or phone them. You could also ask your school if they can put you in touch with your class.

question: I'm going back to school soon. What can my school do to help me settle back in?
answer: There are lots of ways that your school can help you get into a routine again when you return. Don't be afraid to ask for support. Just ask if you need someone at school to help you. It's important to tell your teachers if you're worried about anything.

question: It's been a long time since I played any sport. What if I can't do it as well?
answer: If you haven't played any sport for a while, it's best to start doing some gentle exercise first. You can do this when you're well enough. It should help you to feel fitter again. You could ask the people looking after you in hospital when you can start doing a bit more activity.

question: What's the food like?
answer: We have lots of nice food and snacks that you can choose from at the hospital. The food might be a bit different from what you eat at home, but we try to find something that you like.

question: Can I get vegetarian or vegan food?
answer: The hospital kitchens make food for everyone, no matter what they eat. This includes vegetarian or vegan food.

question: What things do I need to bring for my day surgery procedure?
answer: You can bring a toy and a tablet to play with if you want.

question: Can you see my dreams?
answer: No, we can’t see your dreams, only you can. Sometimes the staff can tell if you're awake or asleep, but that's all.

question: Will the sensors hurt me?
answer: No, the sensors shouldn't hurt at all. The thin tube in your nose called a nasal cannula might tickle a bit, but you'll probably get used to this. After a while, you might even forget it's there.

question: What should I do if a sensor feels uncomfortable?
answer: If a sensor is uncomfortable, just tell the sleep physiologist or nursing assistant. They'll help you and make it feel more comfortable.

question: Can my grown-up stay with me?
answer: Yes, your grown-up will stay with you and they’ll have a bed right next to yours.

question: Will I have my own room?
answer: Yes, you'll have your own room and there'll be a bed for your grown-up too.

question: Can I go to the toilet with the equipment on?
answer: Yes, you can go to the toilet with the equipment on as many times as you want. The sensors are bundled together, so it's easy. If you're in bed and need the toilet, just press the buzzer above your bed. The sleep physiologist or nursing assistant will then come to help you out of bed.

question: What if one of the sensors falls off?
answer: Don't worry if a sensor falls off. The sleep physiologist and nursing assistant can tell when this happens and they'll come to put it back on.

question: Can I eat with the sensors on?
answer: Yes, you can eat with the sensors on. You can bring your own food or we'll give you a food box with sandwiches and other snacks in it.

question: Can I move around with the sensors on?
answer: Yes, you can move around but only before the recording starts. After it starts, the sensors are attached to a quiet machine. This means you can't get out of bed but can still move about. If you want to get out of bed, press the buzzer. The sleep physiologist or nursing assistant will come to help you.

question: Can I sleep in any position?
answer: Yes, you can sleep in any position that is comfortable for you.

question: Can I bring things with me from home?
answer: Yes, you can bring things from home like games, toys, books, pillows or blankets.

question: Will it hurt when the sensors are taken off?
answer: It shouldn't hurt when we take off the sensors. Some of the stickers and tape might be a bit sticky on your body. The physiologist and nursing assistant use special wipes and liquid to help take off the sensors without them hurting.

question: What happens if I find it hard to sleep?
answer: It can feel strange when you try to go to sleep away from home. It might take a bit longer to fall asleep or you might get up a few times. This is fine and the sleep physiologist will understand. Don't worry, just try to think about things that make you feel happy and calm.

question: When should I go to bed?
answer: It's best to go to bed at your normal bedtime or when you feel tired. If it gets late, the sleep physiologist will ask you to try to go to sleep.

question: What are protons?
answer: Protons are positively charged particles in the centre of atoms. Proton therapy is a type of radiation therapy which uses protons to treat some cancers very precisely.

question: Where will the parents be when I have proton beam therapy?
answer: When you're having proton therapy you can't have anyone else there because radiation is used, so parents and caregivers wait nearby. The medical team keep a close eye on everything in the room using cameras to make sure everything goes as planned.

question: What is the Leo proton therapy room like?
answer: The Leo proton therapy room is just like a normal hospital room. In the room there is a chair with a big hula hoop above it. The hula hoop is a CT scanner and it moves up and down to take special pictures of you before treatment. The hula hoop doesn't ever touch you. There is a proton machine one one of the walls where the protons come out of. Check out the Leo Proton Gantry in Xploro's Hospital Rooms area.

question: Is the proton therapy room cold or warm?
answer: It can feel a bit cold in the proton therapy room because the temperature is kept low to stop the machines overheating. You'll be asked to keep very still during treatment and have to wear a thin hospital gown so that can make you feel a bit cold too.

question: Is the Leo proton therapy room light or dark?
answer: The Leo proton therapy room is light most of the time but your medical team might dim the lights when they're getting you ready for treatment. When they dim the lights, it helps them see a special red or green light which helps them position you properly.

question: What are the side effects of proton therapy?
answer: Side effects of proton therapy depend on the part of the body being treated, the size of the tumour, and the types of healthy tissue near it. Proton therapy itself doesn't hurt but you might feel tired afterwards and maybe have some skin problems like: redness, dryness, irritation, swelling and occasionally some peeling or blistering. Sometimes there can be other side effects, especially if you're having chemotherapy too. If you have proton therapy your health and care team will be able to tell you which side effects you might feel.

question: How close is the Leo proton therapy machine to you?
answer: Most of the time, the Leo proton therapy machine is far away from you, then, before treatment begins, a big hula hoop moves up and down around you to take special pictures, but it doesn't touch you. During treatment, part of the machine, shaped like a box, is programmed to move close to you but it automatically stops at a safe distance and it doesn't touch you. Your medical team is in control of the proton therapy machine all the time and they make sure it never touches you.

question: Can my parents be there when the mask is being made?
answer: Yes, your parents can be there when your mask is being made. You can talk to them and hold their hand if you want to.

question: What do I have to say when the mask is being fitted?
answer: You don't really have to say anything while the mask is being fitted. The team will explain everything when it's being done and you can ask questions if you like.

question: What questions will they ask me when the mask is being fitted?
answer: You don't usually have to answer any questions while the mask is being fitted. The team will explain everything to you when it's being done.

question: What can I do to stay still during proton therapy?
answer: You are helped to stay still during proton therapy with special devices that keep your body in the right position. The medical team will make sure you're as comfortable as possible before the therapy starts. Play specialists have some brilliant ways of helping you stay still and they'll tell you the best ones depending on which part of the body is being treated. Sometimes you might be given some medicine to make you sleep through the treatment and you might be able to take a teddy with you to hold while it's happening. It's different for everyone.

question: Will my mum be with me during proton therapy?
answer: Unfortunately, parents can't be in the room during proton therapy treatment so they'll be in another room close by. The medical team keeps a close watch on everything during treatment on a screen in the next room.

question: What happens if I move during proton therapy?
answer: It's really important to stay still during proton therapy. The radiotherapists will help you do this by using things to keep your body in the same position.

question: How long does proton therapy take?
answer: Proton therapy only takes a few minutes but the set-up time can be up to 45 minutes.

question: Do I spin around during Leo proton therapy?
answer: You don't spin around during Leo proton therapy but the chair you're positioned on moves slowly while the proton beam stays still. It moves so slowly that you might not even feel it moving. Your movement is controlled from another room by your radiation therapy team and how often it moves depends on your treatment.

question: Do I spin around during proton therapy?
answer: You don't spin around during proton therapy. The table you're on will move into position and the proton therapy gantry moves around you while you stay still in the circular opening of the machine.

question: What if I need to take a break during proton therapy?
answer: Proton therapy is pretty quick so you shouldn't need a break but if you need anything you can talk to the medical team at any time.

question: Will I be safe during proton therapy?
answer: Proton therapy is very safe. It's been scientifically proven to be a brilliant type of radiotherapy and the radiotherapists who treat patients are experts.

question: Will proton therapy hurt?
answer: Proton therapy itself doesn't hurt. Sometimes there are some side effects because of where on the body the treatment happens or the radiation dosage used, and it can feel a bit weird because of the position you have to be in during treatment. It's different for everyone though and the medical team are able to explain what might happen.

question: What does proton therapy feel like?
answer: You shouldn't feel anything during proton therapy treatment.

question: Do young children have an anaesthetic during proton therapy?
answer: Sometimes anaesthetic is used to help children stay still during treatment. The medical team will say whether or not someone needs anaesthetic and they'll explain everything.

question: Do you lie down during Leo proton therapy?
answer: You do not lie down during Leo proton therapy, instead you sit upright on a chair or perch. The proton beam is fixed and you will move around slowly during treatment.

question: Do you lie down during proton therapy?
answer: Yes, it's most likely you will lie down during proton therapy and the machine, called a gantry, moves around you.

question: What happens if I am poorly during proton therapy and I need to stop?
answer: If you feel poorly during proton therapy you can easily let the medical team know because you can see and hear them at all times. They're in complete control and can safely stop the treatment at any time.

question: Will I see the proton therapy beam?
answer: The proton beam is invisible to the human eye.

question: Can I bring a toy with me to the proton therapy?
answer: A play specialist can say what you can and cannot take into the treatment room.

question: Can I bring a teddy bear with me to the proton therapy?
answer: A play specialist can say what you can and cannot take into the treatment room.

question: Can I bring a cushion with me to the proton therapy?
answer: The medical team will say whether you can take a cushion into the treatment room. Often they have a special type of cushion that keeps you still during proton therapy.

question: Do you outgrow the Leo proton therapy chair?
answer: You don't outgrow the Leo proton therapy chair. The company that makes the special chair, has designed it so it can be adjusted to be comfortable for anyone. You have the chair set up especially for you so it's just right and you're in the best position for your treatment.

question: Can I scratch an itch during proton therapy?
answer: Itches are so annoying but unfortunately you can't move during treatment — even to scratch an itch. It's okay though, treatment is over in no time at all.

question: Is there an emergency stop code during proton therapy?
answer: It's unlikely there'll be an emergency because proton therapy is very safe but the medical team are in complete control and can stop the machine if they need to.

question: Is Leo proton therapy as effective with the chair as the traditional way?
answer: Having Leo proton therapy in the chair is just as effective as lying down and even has some additional benefits. It is often more accurate when you're sitting upright meaning less healthy tissue is affected, it's more comfortable, and you have a better experience.

question: Does anything touch me during Leo proton therapy?
answer: When you have Leo proton therapy you will be sitting upright in a chair. Sometimes there'll be immobilisation devices in place to keep you in the best position. Other than those things, nothing else will touch you.

question: Does anything touch me during proton therapy?
answer: When you have proton therapy you will be lying on a table, sometimes called a couch even though it doesn't look like a couch at home. There might be some immobilisation devices in place to help keep you in the best position. Other than those things, nothing else will touch you.

question: Do you need to wear a mask for Leo proton therapy on the chair?
answer: Not everyone needs to wear a mask during Leo proton therapy. They're mainly used for patients being treated for a tumour in the head, neck or eye. Masks are custom-made for each patient's face and sometimes they can decorate them too.

question: Can I ask questions after the proton therapy has started?
answer: You should ask any questions before treatment has started because talking can make you move and it's important to stay still. The medical team can hear and see you at all times so if it's urgent, you can be heard.

question: What noises does the Leo proton therapy chair make?
answer: The Leo proton therapy chair is very quiet. There's a slight hum and some mechanical noises during set up but compared to the traditional proton therapy machines it's much quieter. If you are sensitive to sound ask the medical team if you can have some music played during treatment.

question: What if I sneeze or cough during proton therapy?
answer: The therapist can see you while you're having treatment. If you sneeze or cough during proton therapy, they will pause the treatment. They will then check you're still in the right position before starting the proton therapy again.

question: What if I need to blow my nose after the proton therapy has started?
answer: If you think you might need to blow your nose you should do it before treatment begins because it's very important to keep as still as possible during proton therapy. Treatment is very quick though so it shouldn't be too long before you can grab a tissue.

question: Who will be on the other side of the glass window during proton therapy?
answer: On the other side of the glass window, during proton therapy, might be an oncologist or a member of their team who will supervise the treatment. There might also be a radiographer or a specialist nurse.

question: What happens when the proton therapy finishes?
answer: When proton therapy finishes the medical team removes the things used to keep you still and helps you get up. After that you can usually go home unless you need more treatment or the medical team needs to keep an eye on you.

question: Can I see my parents during proton therapy?
answer: Unfortunately, parents can't be in the room during proton therapy treatment so they'll be in another room close by. You will see them just before treatment then straight after it.

question: Can my parents see me during proton therapy?
answer: Unfortunately, parents aren't allowed in the control room during treatment so they won't be able to see you during proton therapy but they'll be in another room close by.

question: Can my parents hear me during proton therapy?
answer: Unfortunately, parents aren't allowed in the control room during treatment so they won't be able to hear you during proton therapy but they'll be in another room close by.

question: If you're sitting up for Leo proton therapy will you feel the weight of the mask?
answer: If you're sitting up for Leo proton therapy the mask is attached to the chair and takes its weight so you don't feel it.

question: Are there any considerations for people who aren't neurotypical (who are having proton therapy)?
answer: Lots of treatment centres have specialist staff who can work with non-neurotypical people. They will often meet them before treatment to find out what they are comfortable with and if there is anything the staff can do to make the experience better. It is important to let your medical team know if something makes you uncomfortable or if you need information in a different format so you can understand your treatment.

question: Do I wear my own clothes during proton therapy?
answer: During proton therapy you wear a hospital gown.

question: Do I have to get changed for proton therapy?
answer: When you have proton therapy you have to get changed into a hospital gown.

question: Where do I get changed for proton therapy?
answer: There will be a changing room or a private area to get changed before proton therapy.

question: What does the proton therapy room smell like?
answer: The proton therapy room will probably smell of the cleaning products that are used to keep the hospital very clean.

question: What is the purple light during proton therapy?
answer: Some people who have proton therapy to their head or neck, see a purple light. It's called Cherenkov light and is made by the protons. It's perfectly normal and safe.

question: Can I make choices about proton therapy?
answer: Yes you can make choices about proton therapy. Your oncologist will tell you about the benefits of each treatment option and let you know which are best for you. It's important that you understand why you need treatment and agree to having it.

question: Can I customise the mask?
answer: Sometimes it's possible to customise your mask. The medical team or play specialist will tell you if it can be done.

question: Is the mask scary?
answer: The mask is there to help keep you still during treatment. It is close-fitting, so can feel a little strange at first, but you get used to wearing it quickly. When the mask is fitted for the first time it feels damp and warm as it has been heated in warm water to allow it to mould itself around your face, many people have compared it to feeling like a facial. Mask fitting takes around 10-20 minutes.

question: How often is the proton therapy treatment?
answer: How often proton therapy happens depends on your treatment plan. Your medical team will let you know exactly when each session is.

question: Is proton therapy tiring?
