answer: After a treatment session you can sometimes feel tired. Proton therapy side effects are a bit like those of other radiation treatments but because the technique can mean less exposure to radiation, side effects can be less.

question: Will I have proton therapy at the same time as chemotherapy?
answer: Some patients have proton therapy at the same time as chemotherapy but it's different for everybody. Your medical team will explain everything and let you know if that's going to happen or not. It's important to ask any questions they have.

question: Does proton therapy affect your appetite?
answer: Proton therapy can affect your appetite and makes some patients feel sick. It's important to let the medical team know about any side effects you have because they may be able to help reduce the symptoms.

question: What can I do if the proton therapy information isn't right for me?
answer: If the proton therapy information isn't right for you, ask your medical team who will be able to help. They can give you information in a number of ways and find one that's best for you. That way you can understand it better and make the right decisions for you.

question: How does proton therapy work?
answer: Proton therapy uses protons, which are tiny parts of atoms, rather than high energy X- rays. This type of radiotherapy allows high energy protons to be targeted directly at a tumour and reduces the dose to surrounding healthy tissues and organs.

question: How many people put the mask on me?
answer: There'll be one or two people who will help put your mask on.

question: Can I watch something on the Leo proton beam chair?
answer: Leo is looking into ways patients can watch videos while they're in the treatment chair. In other radiotherapy rooms there is usually music playing during treatment.

question: Is there sensory lighting in the Leo proton therapy room?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible there might be sensory lighting in the Leo proton therapy room. Leo is looking at the use of lighting in their treatment rooms to create an immersive experience.

question: Is there sensory lighting in the proton therapy room?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible there might be sensory lighting in the proton therapy room.

question: Can you change the colour of the lights?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible the lights might change colour.

question: Can there be smells during Leo proton therapy?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible there might be smells during Leo proton therapy. Leo is looking at the use of smells to create an immersive experience but it's tricky because people react differently to them depending on their treatment.

question: Can there be smells during proton therapy?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible there might be smells during proton therapy.

question: How long does it take to prepare Leo proton therapy?
answer: Preparation for Leo proton therapy can take up to 45 minutes for each session even though the treatment itself only takes a few minutes.

question: How long does it take to prepare proton therapy?
answer: Preparation for proton therapy can take up to 45 minutes for each session even though the treatment itself only takes a few minutes.

question: Can the lights be turned up?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible the lights can be turned up.

question: Can the lights be turned down?
answer: Different treatment centres have different experiences so it's possible the lights can be turned down.

question: Can you breathe in the mask?
answer: The mask has lots of small holes in it, like a mesh, it also has gaps around the mouth and nose to make sure you can breathe comfortably. The mask is close-fitting, so may feel a little weird at first but most people get used to it quickly.

question: Can I eat or drink before proton therapy?
answer: You can't eat or drink for at least two hours as you need to have an empty stomach before proton therapy and planning sessions.

question: Do I need to do anything to prepare for proton therapy?
answer: There are a few things that happen to prepare for proton therapy. The medical team will find the best position for you to be in when treatment is happening and help you feel as comfortable as possible. They might use special cushions or things to help you stay still. The team will also makes some marks on your skin which help them line up the machine accurately. You might have to have MRI scans or CT scans too. It can seem unusual at first so it's important to ask any questions while it's happening.

question: Is there information I can read before proton therapy?
answer: The medical team will give you all the information you need to read before treatment and let you know exactly what to expect. You can also use Xploro to find out more.

question: Will I need an MRI scan?
answer: Sometimes you might need MRI scans or CT scans to work out which part of the body needs treating and how best to reach it with proton therapy.

question: What can make it feel less daunting?
answer: The best way to feel better about proton therapy is to understand as much as possible about it beforehand. The medical team has lots of information and Xploro can really help. It's important to ask questions too.

question: Can you hear the iPad during Leo proton therapy?
answer: The Leo proton therapy room is quiet. If the iPad is hard to hear, someone from the clinical team can increase the volume.

question: How editable is the position you're in?
answer: The medical team will choose the best position for you to be treated in and there'll be things to help you stay in that position during proton therapy.

question: Can I bring food to the hospital?
answer: You can bring food into the hospital but need to keep this in a bag until after your operation.

question: Do I need to be calm in hospital?
answer: If you are calm and relaxed when you come into hospital, this can help you to feel better. But not everyone is calm when in hospital. Whatever you feel when you come into hospital is OK. You can speak to the hospital staff about any of your worries and they will try to help.

question: Can I bring my mobile phone with me to hospital?
answer: Yes, you can bring your mobile phone with you. Don't forget to pack the charger in case the battery runs out.

question: Can I bring my phone or iPad?
answer: Yes, you can bring your phone, iPad or tablet with you to the hospital. Make sure that you bring the charger so it doesn't run out of battery.

question: Can I have another pillow or blanket?
answer: There are usually spare pillows and blankets on the ward. If you would like another pillow or blanket, just ask a nurse.

question: How come I get the medicines at different times?
answer: We give you some medicines at different times because they don't work properly if you mix them together. If you need more than one medicine, the doctors and nurses might plan a gap between them.

question: How long does the magic cream take to work?
answer: It takes 30 minutes for the magic cream to work. It is put on at least 30 minutes before you have a needle of cannula.

question: What is the process of having a cannula or blood test?
answer: The process of having a blood test starts when we call you from the waiting room. We might put a magic cream on your skin. If so, you'll need to wait a while until it makes your skin numb. We check your name and birthday, and put a tight band around your arm to help the veins show better. After cleaning the area, we put in the needle and let blood fill the syringe. When there is enough blood, we remove the needle and ask you to hold a cotton wool ball on the area. We may put a small plaster on this area when it stops bleeding. Your blood test is then finished.

question: Will someone explain what is happening for my surgery?
answer: The doctor explains everything about your surgery when they come round to talk to you. If anything isn't clear, you can ask them questions.

question: What do they mean by breathing into a balloon?
answer: When you use the mask to go to sleep for your operation, there is a balloon at the end of the mask tube. You have to take deep breaths and blow out big breaths to get enough of the sleeping medicine. These breaths can blow up the balloon.

question: Can I feel anything when I'm asleep for my operation?
answer: No, you can't feel anything when you're asleep. Being asleep for an operation is different from being asleep at home. We use special medicines to keep you asleep and make sure that you don't feel, hear or see anything during your operation.

question: Why can't I drink before my operation?
answer: When you have an operation, we give you a medicine to make you sleep. It's important not to have a drink before you take the medicine because this can make you be sick.

question: Can my mum or dad stay with me during my operation?
answer: Your parent or grown-up can stay with you right up until you're asleep for your operation. They'll be there when you wake up and can stay with you overnight while you're in hospital.

question: What happens after the procedure?
answer: After your operation, we take you to a recovery room where you wake up. You can choose one grown-up to be there with you. When you're awake, we take you to a different area of the hospital called a ward to get better. How long you stay in hospital depends on what type of operation you have.

question: Do I have to bring my own clothes to hospital?
answer: If you're staying in hospital, you need to bring some of your own clothes with you. During your operation, you may wear a gown but you need to change into some clothes when you go home. It's useful to bring some comfy clothes like pyjamas or tracksuit bottoms.

question: Which doctor or nurse will I meet?
answer: You meet lots of different doctors, nurses and other members of staff. They're here to help look after you and make your stay in hospital comfortable. You can ask anyone who comes to talk to you who they are and what job they do.

question: What questions can I ask the doctors and nurses?
answer: You can ask the doctors and nurses any questions that you like. No question is a silly question and they're happy to explain anything. If a doctor or nurse doesn't know the answer, they will usually find someone who does.
